column1: 433	SBS	940858	Australia	NSW coronavirus death toll hits 18 as cases rise to 2637	"NSW has now recorded 18 COVID-19 deaths as the state's total number of cases rises to 2637.
NSW Health said on Monday the state had recorded 57 new cases - a drop on the previous day which was partly explained by fewer tests being done over the weekend.
The death toll rose to 18 after the deaths of an 86-year-old man and an 85-year-old man on Sunday.

It comes after NSW Police Commissioner Mick Fuller on Sunday announced an investigation into the circumstances surrounding the docking and disembarkation of passengers from the ill-fated Ruby Princess cruise ship.
The investigation - led by the NSW police homicide squad - aims to identify how passengers were allowed to disembark from the ship in Sydney
column2: which is linked to 622 COVID-19 cases and at least 11 deaths across the country.

column1: The only way I can get to the bottom of whether our national biosecurity laws and our state laws were broken is through a criminal investigation
column2: Mr Fuller said.

column1: Mr Fuller told reporters transparency regarding patient health on board the cruise ship was a key question for the investigation.
The ship will dock in Port Kembla
column2: near Wollongong on Monday.

column1: It's expected to spend up to 10 days docked for medical assessments
column2: treatment or emergency extractions of the crew
column3: NSW Police say.

column1: The investigation will cover the actions of the port authority
column2: ambulance
column3: police
column4: the NSW Health department and Carnival Australia.

column1: The NSW government on Sunday urged young people to take the COVID-19 pandemic seriously
column2: revealing more than a quarter of the state's current coronavirus cases are in people aged under 29."

column1: 645	New Zealand Herald	945097	Newsfeeds@nzherald.co.nz	Covid 19 coronavirus: Huge price hikes for essential goods during lockdown	"A freezer that cost $949 on March 1 shot up to $1499 by March 31 as lockdown conditions limited trade across the country.
This is just one of a number of products to have seen significant price hikes during the lockdown
column2: according to price comparison site PriceSpy.

column1: The indexed price across all 108
column2: 000 products listed on PriceSpy increased by 5 per cent in March 2020.

column1: READ MORE:
• Covid 19 coronavirus lockdown: The Warehouse experiences huge demand for essential products
• Covid 19 coronavirus: Briscoes
column2: Mitre 10 join companies selling essential items

column1: • Covid 19 coronavirus: Essential goods expansion brings reprieve for struggling Kiwis
• Coronavirus: Anger over Kmart selling fake tan as essential item but not stocking winter pyjamas

The biggest growth was seen in chest freezers which surged by 28 per cent between March 1 and 31. What's more is that 90 per cent of the chest freezers listed were found to cost more by the end of the month.
Webcams
column2: heating and cooling products
column3: washing machines
column4: desktop PCs and ebook readers all shot up in price over this period.

column1: ""Shockingly
column2: the findings revealed 90 per cent of the top 10 most-click-on chest freezers cost more to buy on 31st March compared to 1st March
column3: before the national Covid-19 alert system was implemented
column4: said Liisa Matinvesi-Bassett
column5: New Zealand country manager for PriceSpy.

column1: ""Similarly
column2: over three quarters [80 per cent] of the top 10 most-clicked-on webcams were more expensive to purchase at the end of the month compared to the start. A similar trend was also apparent for whiteware goods
column3: with 70 per cent of the top 10 most-clicked-on items costing more on 31st March compared to 1st March.""

column1: The price hikes have been applied across categories. Photo / File
Matinvesi-Bassett said that while fluctuations in pricing are to be expected
column2: the price hikes in this instance have been ""extraordinary"".

column1: ""If we are to compare like-for-like and look at the biggest savings offered across the top 10 most -clicked-on products across the same shopping categories
column2: the most substantial saving found was for the Apple Mac Mini (2018)
column3: which cost $190 less on 31st compared to 1st March
column4: she said.

column1: There have been massive differences in prices. Photo / File
""During such unprecedented times
column2: our key piece of advice to consumers who need to make an essential purchase right now is to be vigilant and conduct important price research before they commit and buy
column3: as our insights suggest many products have received a price hike over this last month.""

column1: This data comes off the back of the Government's decision to allow certain retailers to sell a number of essential goods to get New Zealanders through the lockdown.
The move allowed the likes of the Warehouse
column2: Noel Leeming
column3: Briscoes and Mitre 10 to sell essential goods
column4: such as heaters
column5: whiteware and computers.

column1: A number of products have seen a big lift in prices. Image / PriceSpy
The decision was made in recognition of the need for people to safely isolate
column2: stay connected to one another and work or study from home.

column1: The stores have
column2: however
column3: faced massive demand as Kiwis rushed online to get their hands on essentials.

column1: Key products include heaters
column2: dehumidifiers
column3: light bulbs and globes
column4: hand tools
column5: padlocks
column6: firewood
column7: batteries
column8: sealants and silicones
column9: work boots and gumboots
column11: torches
column12: spouting
column14: smoke alarms
column15: child safety items and small household appliances.

254	Philippine Daily Inquirer	956626	Besguerra	Holy Week rites worldwide disrupted
column2: but not spirit	"Attendees sit by palm branches as Pope Francis celebrates Palm Sunday Mass behind closed doors in St. Peter’s Basilica
column3: at the Vatican
column4: Sunday
column5: April 5
column7: during the lockdown aimed at curbing the spread of the COVID-19 infection
column8: caused by the novel coronavirus. (AP Photo/pool/Alberto Pizzoli)

column1: MANILA
column2: Philippines s— For Pope Francis at the Vatican
column3: and for Christians worldwide from churches large and small
column4: this will be an Easter like none other: The joyous message of Christ’s resurrection will be delivered to empty pews.

column1: Worries about the coronavirus outbreak have triggered widespread cancellations of Holy Week processions and in-person services. Many pastors will preach on TV or online
column2: tailoring sermons to account for the pandemic.

column1: Many extended families will reunite via Face Time and Zoom rather than around a communal table laden with an Easter feast on April 12.
“I’ll miss Mass and the procession
column2: ” said Aida Franco
column4: a retired teacher from Quito
column5: Ecuador. “But God knows better.”

column1: Near-empty basilica
Pope Francis
column2: the first Pontiff from Latin America
column3: will be celebrating Mass for Palm Sunday
column4: Holy Thursday and Easter in a near-empty St. Peter’s Basilica
column5: instead of in the huge square outside filled with Catholic faithful.

column1: In the Pope’s native Argentina
column2: the archbishopric of La Plata encouraged the faithful to use any type of plant at home for a “virtual” blessing that will be live-streamed during Palm Sunday services this weekend.

column1: The pandemic has prompted the cancellation of a renowned annual tradition of sawdust and handmade flower carpets coating the streets of Antigua
column2: a colonial Guatemalan city
column3: during its Holy Week procession. Instead
column4: some residents will make smaller carpets to display outside their homes.

column1: “We know this is happening because of some message from God
column2: ” said Cesar Alvarez
column3: who has been making the multicolored carpets with his family for 28 years. “But we’re taking it with a lot of sadness.”

column1: In some communities
column2: there are innovative efforts to boost Easter time morale.

column1: Distancing at egg hunt
At Asbury United Methodist Church in Prairie Village
column2: Kansas
column3: family ministries director Heather Jackson is organizing an Easter egg hunt that embraces social distancing.

column1: Parents and children are creating colorful images of Easter eggs to display in windows or on garage doors
column2: and the “hunt” will entail families driving around in their cars
column3: or strolling on foot
column4: trying to spot as many eggs as possible.

column1: “It’s about keeping people safe while maintaining that sense of joy
column2: ” Jackson said. “It will be a difficult time because it’s a time for families to come together and right now we just can’t do that.”

column1: If not for the virus
column2: 32-year-old Chris Burton—a writer
column3: teacher and devout Baptist in Brooklyn
column4: New York—would be planning a trip to Maryland for Easter dinner with his family. Instead
column5: he plans to watch the online service of his church
column6: Trinity Baptist
column7: and then catch up with relatives by phone.

column1: Burton
column2: who has experienced five bouts of pneumonia since 2011
column3: has blogged about the need to shelter in place. Yet he still hopes this Easter will rekindle the uplifting emotions he’s cherished since wearing his Easter suit in childhood.

column1: “All that’s happening doesn’t mean we need to be somber
column2: ” he said.

column1: Priest-carrying vehicles
In Venezuela
column2: Catholic officials said that after the Holy Week liturgies
column3: some priests would try to take the Blessed Sacrament—the wine and bread of Holy Communion—on a vehicle and
column4: using loudspeakers
column5: invite congregants to join in spirit from their windows and balconies.

column1: A similar use of priest-carrying vehicles was adapted in the Philippines
column2: Asia’s bastion of Catholicism. Locals lined up in front of their homes in several districts of Manila and Quezon City
column3: which are entering its fourth week of a lockdown that has brought the frenetic metropolis nearly to a halt.

column1: The priests made signs of the cross as they rolled past waving residents marking Palm Sunday
column2: the start of the week that culminates with the observance of Easter.

column1: “This celebration will continue despite the spread of the virus
column2: ” said Bong Sosa
column3: who attended wearing a mask crafted from a water cooler bottle.

column1: In Brazil
column2: the world’s biggest Catholic country
column3: Rio de Janeiro’s huge Christ the Redeemer statue has been closed indefinitely. Large Holy Week gatherings are banned in several states after a federal court overruled a decree by President Jair Bolsonaro exempting religious services from quarantine measures.

column1: Many faithful across Latin America say they’ll miss Holy Week’s observances
column2: yet there is acceptance of the cancellations.

column1: Health first
“It’s sad because we can’t be with our Lord in his Calvary
column2: but it’s fine
column3: ” said Felipe Navarrete of Santiago
column4: Chile. “The health of the population comes first
column5: and we have to be responsible with older people who join these rituals the most.”

column1: Many pastors are pondering their upcoming Easter sermons
column2: including the Rev. Steven Paulikas of All Saints Episcopal Church in Brooklyn. His sermon will be transmitted online but delivered in an empty church.

column1: “It’s started me thinking about the empty tomb
column2: ” he said
column3: referring to the biblical account of Christ’s resurrection after his crucifixion.

column1: “That emptiness was actually the first symbol of this new life
column2: ” Paulikas said.

column1: On the evening of April 9—Holy Thursday commemorating the Last Supper of Jesus and his apostles—Paulikas is organizing a communal supper for his congregation
column2: hoping members will join via Face Time.

column1: Sounds and images
At St. Ambrose Catholic Church in Brunswick
column2: Ohio
column3: Father Bob Stec is organizing a pre-Easter initiative
column4: arranging for each of the parish’s 5
column5: 500 families to get a friendly call from another member.

column1: He’s expecting upwards of 20
column2: 000 people to watch the online Easter service.

column1: “We’re going to try to flood their senses visually and audibly with the sounds and images that will give them hope
column2: ” he said.

254	Philippine Daily Inquirer	956626	Besguerra	Crucifixion site on lockdown to block penitents	"Local tourists pose by crosses before a re-enactment of the crucifixion of Jesus Christ for Good Friday celebrations ahead of Easter in the village of Cutud near San Fernando
column2: north of Manila on April 14

column1: Devotees in the fervently Catholic Philippines nailed themselves to crosses and whipped their backs in extreme acts of faith that have become an annual tourist attraction. / AFP PHOTO / NOEL CELIS
CITY OF SAN FERNANDO
column2: Pampanga
column3: Philippines — The new coronavirus is poised to bring to a stop this Holy Week the crucifixion rites in the village of San Pedro Cutud here.

column1: Barangay Cutud
column2: where some 5
column3: 000 penitents would end their flagellation and crucifixion on Good Friday
column4: has been placed on total lockdown since Palm Sunday to stop the spread of infection.

column1: Six policemen were sent to the area to guard the three entrances to the village
column2: said Cutud chair Remegio de la Cruz. “I do not want foreigners and local spectators to come
column3: ” he told the Inquirer by phone.

column1: The village’s Good Friday events
column2: ending on a version of Calvary
column3: had been drawing 30
column5: 000 spectators annually due to real-life crucifixion rites.

column1: Hardheaded villagers
“This coronavirus disease must be stopped from being transmitted
column2: ” De la Cruz said. “There are some villagers who are hardheaded
column3: but I am strict. So they better obey me or else.”

column1: Ruben Enaje
column3: a house and billboard painter
column4: regularly took on the role of Jesus Christ in “Via Crucis” (Way of the Cross)
column5: the play staged on the streets of Cutud.

column1: But local officials have asked Enaje and other penitents to drop the crucifixion rites after President Duterte ordered a stop to the gathering of people in big numbers to curb the spread of COVID-19.
Enaje said he would just carry a 37-kilogram wooden cross from his house to the hill on Good Friday.
—TONETTE OREJAS

254	Philippine Daily Inquirer	956626	Besguerra	COVID-19 patients to waive confidentiality	"COVID-19 patients to waive confidentiality
By:  Dona Z. Pazzibugan
-		47 seconds ago
MANILA
column2: Philippines — No less than the country’s top medical and legal groups have called on authorities to disclose the identities of COVID-19 patients and so-called persons under investigation (PUIs)
column3: saying many patients continue to withhold their true medical history thus endangering the thinning ranks of healthcare workers.

column1: The Philippine Medical Association and Philippine College of Surgeons together with the Integrated Bar of the Philippines appealed to COVID-19 patients and PUIs to voluntarily waive the confidentiality of their medical information and inform those they have recently been in close contact with.

They also urged the Department of Health to “prudently use and promptly share the medical information” to all concerned so they could take precautionary and remedial measures. Justice Secretary Menardo Guevarra said he “strongly” supported the call and affirmed the “ethical and legal basis” laid down by the Philippine Medical Association and the Data Privacy Commission to justify waiving the medical confidential rule “in times of public health emergency.”
He also strongly supports the call of the Integrated Bar of the Philippines on COVID-19 positive individuals and PUIs “for the waiver of confidentiality of their medical condition
column2: ” Guevarra told reporters on Sunday.

column1: “This will enable other people they have been in close contact with to take the necessary precautions or remedial measures to protect themselves
column2: without having to further burden the Department of Health with the tedious task of contact tracing
column3: ” he added.

column1: The three medical and legal groups made the appeal in a joint statement on April 4
column2: three weeks since the enhanced community quarantine to contain the outbreak.

column1: In justifying their call to waive the medical confidentiality rule
column2: they reported increasing incidents in which COVID-19 patients continue to withhold their true medical condition when seeking treatment or hospital admission “thereby compromising the health institutions and the health workers
column3: ” many of whom have died or fell ill from the infectious disease.

column1: Even without the individual waiver
column2: they said
column3: existing laws and rules grant the government “sufficient authority and basis” to lift the confidentiality of the medical condition of COVID-19 patients and PUIs.

column1: These include Republic Act 11332 or the 2018 Law on Reporting of Communicable Diseases
column2: which makes illegal the “non-cooperation of persons and entities” in times of public health emergencies.

column1: The confidentiality of a patient’s medical data and details is “not absolute” and can be lifted “when the public health and safety so demand” or “when the patient waives his right
column2: ” the three groups pointed out.

column1: Article III Section 3 of the Code of Ethics of the Medical Profession
column2: they said
column3: exempts a physician from keeping private and highly confidential a person’s medical information “when required by law
column4: ordinance or administrative order in the promotion of justice
column5: safety and public health.”

column1: The Health Privacy Code specifying the Joint Administrative Order No. 2016-0002 or the privacy guidelines for the implementation of the Philippine Health Information Exchange
column2: also allows that “in case of emergency where time is of the essence
column3: disclosure may be made even without court order.”

254	Philippine Daily Inquirer	956626	Besguerra	Bishop: Holy Week is about love
column2: not rituals	"A Roman Catholic priest riding on a tricycle and wearing a face mask blesses the faithfuls holding coconut leaves during Palm Sunday event in Borongan town
column3: Eastern Samar province
column4: central Philippines on April 5
column6: as part of the Easter observance. - Church authorities have asked the catholic faithfuls not to go to churches for the Palm Sunday blessing
column7: but instead to stay in front of their houses as priests will go around their communities for the blessing
column8: to observe social distancing as part of the government efforts to combat COVID 19 pandemic. (Photo by Alren BERONIO / AFP)

column1: MANILA
column2: Philippines — The new coronavirus failed to keep Filipino Catholics from observing Palm Sunday.

column1: Priests went around communities in lockdown to bless palm fronds waved by people from the front of their houses or delivered blessing from the back of trucks and motorized tricycles.
In a photo posted on CBCP­News
column2: the official news service of the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of the Philippines (CBCP)
column3: a priest blesses palm fronds from a tricycle in Borongan City
column4: Eastern Samar.

column1: Manila Auxiliary Bishop Broderick Pabillo
column2: in his homily during Palm Sunday Mass at Manila Cathedral that was live-streamed on Facebook
column3: said liturgical activities this year would be a lot different
column4: “but Holy Week must continue.”

column1: Bright side
Catholics in many parts of the world may miss the “externalities” of the celebrations
column2: he said
column3: but “this may be a good chance for us to go into the essence of what we are doing.”

column1: “There is always a bright side in what is happening even in this COVID-19 pandemic
column2: ” he said.

column1: Pabillo urged the faithful to spend the remaining days of the Luzon lockdown in prayer and reflection.
“Let us not mind so much that we are already in the fourth week of the lockdown. Let us not complain. But let us use this silence and inactivity of the lockdown this Holy Week to reflect and to pray
column2: ” he said.

column1: He encouraged the faithful to think of the difficulties brought about by COVID-19 as a way of being one with Jesus
column2: who died for mankind.

column1: “Of course
column2: after four weeks
column3: there are already lots of complaints
column4: not only of inconvenience
column5: not only of boredom
column6: but
column7: even for some
column8: because of great need. They might be hungry already. Let us join all these sufferings to that of Jesus. He loves us so much that he suffered for us
column9: ” Pabillo said.

column1: “We welcome him today
column2: let us continue to welcome him. We recognize him and he still comes to us in the ordinariness of our lives even when we are under quarantine. It’s good to pause and see how is the Lord coming to us during these days
column3: ” he added.

column1: This Holy Week is a good time to reflect on why Jesus suffered so much and that his suffering should “lead us to sorrow and gratitude—sorrow for our sins
column2: for our indifference
column3: and gratitude for his great love and solidarity with us
column4: ” Pabillo said.

column1: Not less holy
“We may be celebrating this year’s Holy Week differently
column2: but hopefully
column3: more deeply
column4: ” he said
column5: adding that the absence of traditional religious activities does not make Holy Week less holy.

column1: Lingayen-Dagupan Archbishop Socrates Villegas echoed Pabillo’s views
column2: saying Holy Week is about love
column3: not rituals.

column1: “Love makes us holy. Love
column2: not rituals
column3: is the spirit of Holy Week
column4: ” he said.

column1: Fr. Jerome Secillano
column2: executive secretary of the CBCP public affairs committee
column3: also said Holy Week “shouldn’t be less holy since what makes it really holy is the sacrifice of Christ and not the participation of people.”

254	Philippine Daily Inquirer	956626	Besguerra	Christianity’s most somber time spent somberly	"Christianity’s most somber time spent  somberly
By:  Ador Vincent Mayol
column2: Joey Gabieta

column1: -		3 hours ago
LIVESTREAM The Mendoza family of Bagong Silangan village in Quezon City attends Palm Sunday Mass via online broadcasting or livestreaming
column2: amid the spread of the coronavirus disease that has forced the government to put the entire island of Luzon on lockdown. (Photo by NIÑO JESUS ORBETA / Philippine Daily Inquirer)

column1: TACLOBAN CITY
column2: Leyte
column3: Philippines — Zenaida Oledan woke up at 5:30 a.m. on Sunday determined to do one thing.

column1: “I want to have my palm fronds blessed
column2: ” said the 54-year-old mother of four.

column1: Oledan was among several residents who lined the city streets of Barangay 6 to observe Palm Sunday
column2: the start of Holy Week—the most somber time of the year in Christianity.

column1: Going to the community
But unlike in previous years
column2: the Catholic faithful were requested to stay at home in a bid to contain the spread of the new coronavirus
column3: which causes the deadly COVID-19.

column1: Msgr. Erlito Maraya
column2: head priest of Sacred Heart Parish in Tacloban
column3: went out to the community to bless the people’s homemade palm fronds.

column1: Oledan was glad about Maraya’s bringing the Palm Sunday tradition to people’s homes. “At least even during this time of COVID-19
column2: we’re still able to observe Palm Sunday
column3: ” she said
column4: holding the palm she had bought.

column1: In Cebu
column2: Archbishop Jose Palma presided over Palm Sunday Mass at an empty Cebu Metropolitan Cathedral. But Gov. Gwendolyn Garcia was there to see him consecrate Cebu to the Our Lady of Guadalupe
column3: the island’s patroness.

column1: “In the midst of fear and anxiety caused by COVID-19
column2: even great nations are at a loss about what to do. We have no solution. [The best we can do] is to bend down our knees in prayer
column3: ” Palma said in his homily.

column1: Gratitude to medical workers
He expressed gratitude to all medical workers who
column2: he said
column3: were like Jesus who sacrificed his life for the good of many.

column1: “These people exposed themselves to risk and yet they are there. We admire people who are willing to take the risk knowing that life is precious. This is the image of Jesus who offered his life so that others may live
column2: ” Palma said.

column1: “In time of COVID
column2: we should be serious in giving value to life. We’re confronted with a serious case and I hope people will follow what authorities are implementing
column3: ” he added.

column1: On March 17
column2: Palma ordered the suspension of Masses in Cebu amid increasing COVID-19 cases. He urged parishes in the archdiocese to use technology to bring church services to people
column3: especially those who are in quarantine.

column1: On Negros Island
column2: people attended services — Catholic and Protestant — through television.

column1: Some of them put palm fronds on their gates as a reminder of Palm Sunday.
—WITH A REPORT FROM CARLA GOMEZ

254	Philippine Daily Inquirer	956626	Besguerra	Fighting a pandemic: When healers need healing themselves	"THE BEST AND WORST IMPULSES Risking infection by the coronavirus as they provide care for patients on their watch
column2: medical workers also face discrimination by people afraid for their lives. —PHOTO COURTESY OF KATH VALDEZ

column1: MANILA
column2: Philippines — “You really need to be strong in this profession
column3: ’’ said Kath Valdez
column4: a ward nurse at the Philippine General Hospital (PGH) in Manila
column5: who has seen how the usually crowded halls of PGH turned empty and eerily quiet
column6: except for the muffled suffering of patients battling a virulent disease that has also taken its toll on health workers like her.

column1: “(You have) to put so much heart into it so that you can help people (deal)
column2: not only with their physical pain but also the emotional and mental challenges they are going through
column3: ” she said.

column1: After PGH was designated by the Department of Health as an “end referral hospital” for COVID-19 cases
column2: Valdez recalled
column3: she started taking care of one patient whose condition was made worse by bouts of depression. Two of the patient’s family members had died from COVID-19
column4: while the rest were recovering.

column1: “She is isolated and alone in PGH
column2: and cannot do anything. It’s too sad to see patients like that. All I can offer is myself
column3: a person who will listen to her
column4: ” said Valdez.

column1: Health workers get so invested in their work that they sometimes forget to take care of themselves
column2: she said
column3: and “this eventually leads to burnout and similar challenges.”

column1: Another source of anguish
But lately
column2: another source of their mental anguish has surfaced — one that stalks nurses and health workers the moment they step out of the hospital.

column1: Valdez has experienced it herself: One day as she walked home
column2: her neighbors hurried back inside their houses
column3: avoiding her like the plague. She has also heard stories of health workers being forced out of their rented places because of fear that they could infect the entire community.

column1: “I know (people) are just being careful
column2: ” she said. “But I wish they would be kinder and more considerate to us
column3: especially during this time of crisis
column4: ” Valdez said.

column1: Support groups
To help themselves cope
column2: nurses in the state-run hospital turn to their support group—“PGH Care Society”—to help each other out of emotional and psychological lows through professional and peer interventions.

column1: Other groups
column2: such as Ugat Foundation and the University of the Philippines Diliman’s PsycServ (UPD PsycServ)
column3: have been offering telepsychotherapy and psycho-emotional counseling services for front-line health workers and people experiencing stress or anxiety during the COVID-19 pandemic.

column1: Like other PGH nurses
column2: Valdez has developed the fear of getting the virus and infecting others
column3: as well as a sense of helplessness for not being able to do everything for the patients.

column1: “We’ve also faced (cases of) infectious diseases in the past
column2: but this is something that we didn’t expect to blow up like this. It totally changed our working environment. There is fear
column3: anxiety
column4: and uncertainty all around
column5: ” said Valdez
column6: who lives with friends in Manila while her entire family is abroad.

column1: The PGH Care Society
column2: a mental health advocacy group whose members include Valdez
column3: provides a platform for nurses to freely express their feelings as a form of unburdening and release. Through online exchanges
column4: they can hopefully unload negative feelings and deal more strongly with “one of the most challenging times of their career
column5: ” Valdez said.

column1: Online counseling
Ugat Foundation
column2: meanwhile
column3: is a group helping Filipino families
column4: overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) and marginalized individuals cushion the physical and psychological impact of the coronavirus outbreak.

column1: On April 2
column2: it launched Ugat Sandaline
column3: an online platform that provides psycho-emotional counseling services to people affected by the pandemic
column4: especially medical front-liners and other responders deployed by the government.

column1: “They need a lot of support now
column2: and hopefully
column3: crisis counseling empowers them in their valiant efforts to fight COVID-19 and ensure the safety and health of the Filipino people
column4: ” the group said.

column1: Ugat Sandaline volunteers include psychologists
column2: mental health professionals
column3: and psychology graduate students who are trained to listen to and empathize with those needing emotional support
column4: whether through video
column5: voice call or online chat.

column1: “In cases such as pandemics
column2: when compliance is critical to the nation’s efforts to ‘flatten the curve
column3: ’ feeling heard or having an outlet to ventilate feelings will hopefully also enable more (people) to comply with national and local government efforts
column4: ” the group said in a statement.

column1: For other ‘essential’ workers
A third help group
column2: UPD PsycServ
column3: has expanded its free telepsychotherapy services to reach out not only to health workers but also to persons under investigation or monitoring for coronavirus symptoms
column4: and COVID-19-positive individuals and their relatives.

column1: It also offers a comforting hand to security guards
column2: store cashiers
column3: janitors and other “essential” workers who still have to go to work—and face the risk of being infected—while the Luzon-wide lockdown is in effect.

column1: Online sessions with the group can be scheduled through text
column2: Viber or an online form posted on the group’s Facebook page.

column1: Sometimes a simple “kumusta” (how are you?) suffices to renew their strength
column2: Valdez said.

column1: “As health workers
column2: we’re used to asking others: Kumusta ka? So it’s time that we also take care of our fellow nurses and front-liners
column3: ” she said. “That one simple question can totally change someone’s perspective and feelings.”

9	Ars Technica	963482	Timothy B. Lee	Zoombombing is a crime
column2: not a prank
column3: prosecutors warn	"Coronavirus-related social distancing measures have given a big popularity boost to Zoom
column4: a video conferencing platform that's known for its ease of use but not necessarily strong security or privacy protections. Internet trolls and other troublemakers have responded with ""Zoombombing"": joining Zoom meetings uninvited and disrupting them. Zoombombers have exposed themselves to schoolchildren and shouted racial slurs.

column1: In a Friday statement
column2: federal prosecutors in Michigan warned the public that Zoombombing isn't a harmless prank; it's a crime.

column1: Hackers are disrupting conferences and online classrooms with pornographic and/or hate images and threatening language
column2: wrote the US Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Michigan. ""Anyone who hacks into a teleconference can be charged with state or federal crimes.""

column1: Possible charges include ""disrupting a public meeting
column2: computer intrusion
column3: using a computer to commit a crime
column4: hate crimes
column5: fraud
column6: or transmitting threatening communications
column7: the prosecutors warn. All of these charges come with the potential for fines and jail time
column8: the authorities say.

column1: The exact charges a Zoombomber faces would presumably depend on how they gained access to a Zoom meeting and what they did to disrupt it. For example
column2: some Zoom meetings are advertised publicly
column3: which might make it hard to make a computer intrusion charge stick. But someone could still be prosecuted for things they said or did to disrupt the meeting after joining it.

column1: “You think Zoombombing is funny? Let’s see how funny it is after you get arrested
column2: ” Michigan US attorney Matthew Schneider said in Friday's release. “If you interfere with a teleconference or public meeting in Michigan
column3: you could have federal
column4: state
column5: or local law enforcement knocking at your door.”

column1: In a recent story
column2: Ars Technica security reporter Dan Goodin explained how Zoom users can protect themselves from Zoombombing attacks. He noted that meetings can be password-protected
column3: and he advised against announcing login information on social media or other public channels.

column1: Goodin notes that hosts can disable Zoom's ""Join Before Host"" setting to ensure that the host is in control of a meeting from the outset. Zoom also has a ""waiting room"" feature
column2: allowing a host to verify participants before allowing them to join the meeting."

1451	Slate	972353	Daniel Politi	Bronx Zoo Tiger Is First of Its Kind to Test Positive For Coronavirus	"Nadia
column2: a four-year-old female Malayan tiger at the Bronx Zoo
column3: is seen in an undated photo provided by the zoo in New York.

column1: Wildlife Conservation Society
Nadia
column2: a four-year-old female Malayan tiger at the Bronx Zoo
column3: has become the first tiger in the world to test positive for the coronavirus. It is the first known case of an animal contracting the coronavirus in the United States.  Nadia’s sister Azul
column4: two Amur tigers
column5: and three African lions have also developed a dry cough
column6: a symptom that is typical of COVID-19 patients. Because of the difficulty of obtaining samples from big cats
column7: only one was tested. Besides a bit of loss of appetite all the Bronx Zoo animals are doing well
column8: the Wildlife Conservation Society’s Bronx Zoo said in a statement. The zoo has been closed since March 16.

column1: The U.S. Department of Agriculture confirmed the finding and said it marked the first case of a tiger testing positive for COVID-19. The big cats were likely infected by an asymptomatic staff member.

Even though all the big cats infected with COVID-19 are expected to make a full recovery the positive test raises fresh questions about how the virus is transmitted to animals. No pets in the United States have tested positive for the virus and there is no evidence to suggest that animals can transmit COVID-19 to people. A dog in Hong Kong tested positive
column2: which led officials to conclude animals could test positive if they had been exposed by humans but could not transmit the virus to humans.

column1: The USDA says anyone who is sick with the coronavirus should restrict contact with animals as much as possible. If someone who is sick with the coronavirus must take care of a pet or be around animals
column2: “they should wash their hands before and after the interaction
column3: ” notes the USDA. Experts also recommend that pets of owners who are infected with COVID-19 should be kept inside as much as possible."

column1: 1476	Straits Times	941192		Ecuador city runs out of coffins amid coronavirus crisis	"QUITO (AFP) - Soaring numbers of coronavirus deaths in Ecuador's second city Guayaquil have led to a shortage of coffins

column1: 15	CBS News	4496		Why John Dickerson wrote about acknowledging each other's grief as the coronavirus takes its toll	"Amid the confusion and anxiety of coronavirus news
column2: John Dickerson wants people to take time to acknowledge what has been lost. For an increasing number of Americans

column1: Behind the growing numbers of people who have died from COVID-19

column4: passed it around
column5: either because they were experiencing grief
column6: or because they knew somebody that was

column1: Part of what makes this moment so confusing

column1: For Dickerson

column4: goes beyond the intended message.

column9: at the very basic level

466	News	955084	Ap	Tiger tests positive for coronavirus at NYC’s Bronx Zoo	"A tiger at the Bronx Zoo has tested positive for the new coronavirus in what is believed to be the first known infection in an animal in the US or a tiger anywhere
column2: federal officials and the zoo said Sunday.

column1: The four-year-old Malayan tiger named Nadia – and six other tigers and lions that have also fallen ill – are believed to have been infected by a zoo employee who wasn’t yet showing symptoms
column2: the zoo said. The first animal started showing symptoms on March 27
column3: and all are doing well and expected to recover
column4: a zoo spokesman said. The zoo has been closed to the public since March 16 amid the surging coronavirus outbreak in New York.

column1: “These are extremely hard days for all of us – no matter where we live and work. We will ensure that whatever we can learn from these circumstances will be used to better understand and combat this disease
column2: ” zoo director Jim Breheny said in a statement.

column1: The finding raises new questions about transmission of the virus in animals. The US Department of Agriculture
column2: which confirmed Nadia’s test result at its veterinary lab
column3: says there are no known cases of the virus in US pets or livestock.

column1: “There doesn’t appear to be
column2: at this time
column3: any evidence that suggests that the animals can spread the virus to people or that they can be a source of the infection in the United States
column4: ” Dr Jane Rooney
column5: a veterinarian and a USDA official
column6: said in an interview.

column1: A USDA spokesperson said on Sunday it was not recommending routine coronavirus testing of animals in zoos or elsewhere or of zoo employees. Still
column2: DR Rooney said a small number of animals in the US had been tested through the USDA’s National Veterinary Services Laboratories
column3: and all those tests came back negative except Nadia’s.

column1: The coronavirus outbreaks around the world are driven by person-to-person transmission
column2: experts say.

column1: There have been a handful of reports outside the US of pet dogs or cats becoming infected after close contact with contagious people
column2: including a Hong Kong dog that tested positive for a low level of the pathogen in February and early March. Hong Kong agriculture authorities concluded that pet dogs and cats couldn’t pass the virus to human beings but could test positive if exposed by their owners.

column1: Some researchers have been trying to understand the susceptibility of different animal species to the virus and to determine how it spreads among animals
column2: according to the Paris-based World Organisation for Animal Health. The American Veterinary Medical Association and the federal Centres for Disease Control and Prevention have been recommending that out of an abundance of caution
column3: people ill with the coronavirus should limit contact with animals – advice that the veterinary group reiterated after learning of the tiger’s test result.

column1: In general
column2: the CDC also advises people to wash their hands after handling animals and do other things to keep pets and their homes clean. At the Bronx Zoo
column3: Nadia
column4: her sister Azul
column5: two Amur tigers and three African lions developed dry coughs
column6: and some of the cats exhibited some wheezing and loss of appetite
column7: said Dr Paul Calle
column8: the zoo’s chief veterinarian.

column1: Only Nadia was tested because it takes anaesthesia to get a sample from a big cat. Her temperature was taken at the same time
column2: and it was normal
column3: Dr Calle said. The seven sickened cats live in two areas at the zoo
column4: and the animals had contact with the same worker
column5: who is doing OK
column6: zoo officials said. They said they are taking “appropriate preventive measures” for the staffers who care for the ailing animals
column7: and there are no signs of illness in other big cats on the property.

column1: For most people
column2: the coronavirus causes mild or moderate symptoms
column3: such as a fever and cough that clear up in two to three weeks. For some
column4: especially older adults
column5: it can cause more severe illness
column6: including pneumonia
column7: and can be fatal."

column2: clinicians and manufacturers has been working tirelessly to develop suitable products and to co-ordinate the supply and demand of these essential items
column3: and it has begun to network with other similar groups across Australia and internationally.

column1: They have reached out to philanthropical organisations and local engineers and manufacturers to open up supply lines and found them keen to help.
The PPE items they are working to create in order to reduce the risk to staff and secure their safety include:
On top of the doctors' efforts
column2: a Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) task force has been established to assess this dynamic supply and demand situation
column3: while the Federal Department of Industry
column4: Science
column5: Energy and Resources has set up a ventilator task force.

column1: All DHHS-supplied equipment needs to be approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA).
The TGA has created a rapid approval process to speed this up for COVID-related equipment.
Con Kolivas
column2: a retired anaesthetist and software engineer who is helping to coordinate one of the groups
column3: said it started as a casual chat between a few people about the lack of ventilators in Italy at the time.

column1: They wondered whether it would be possible for Australia to build some kind of simple ventilator in case of a shortage locally.
The rate of infection of medical staff in the worst-affected areas overseas is now very high and
column2: to make matters worse
column3: doctors who've been infected at the front line appear to have a higher death rate than people who've caught it in the community
column4: he said.

column1: I and others approached people from different disciplines in industry
column2: medicine
column3: engineering
column4: software and so on about what we could do and found a cohort of people willing to help out.

column1: After the initial discussion about ventilators
column2: talks turned to things we could manufacture locally and personal protective equipment (PPE) was top of the list.

column1: Government and health suppliers don't actually give us any of this sort of equipment
column2: so we needed to innovate because there isn't an easy path to find these novel pieces of equipment.""

column1: Emergency physician and intensive care fellow Arun Ilancheran said a severe shortage of equipment was looming.
Our group feels is it imperative that we source local engineers and manufacturers to continue to have the supply chain of the essential equipment that we need to save lives during this pandemic.
We are aware that as the lockdown phase gets stricter
column2: we will have further supply chain issues.""

column1: Dr Kolivas said the Victorian Government was keen to support any firm designs the group could come up with
column2: but for any complex designs
column3: the regular government channels of approval and funding could slow things down.

column1: Fortunately
column2: various philanthropical organisations were also very willing to assist
column3: he said.

column1: With the help of 3D printing it makes it possible to tackle any kind of design we want
column2: Dr Kolivas said.

column1: The problem with 3D printing is it's slow
column2: so it's great for producing the prototypes
column3: but you can't mass produce them if each one takes two hours to print.""

column1: That is where support from local manufacturers comes in.
Dr Kolivas said that
column2: again
column3: there was a desire to help.

column1: Toyota is one example of a company which has offered its design and engineering capabilities to produce equipment on a large scale.
Crucially
column2: Dr Kolivas said
column3: ventilator manufacturer Medtronic had opened up one of its designs for free use during the pandemic
column4: without intellectual property restrictions
column5: meaning there was potential for manufacturers to produce the vital piece of equipment in Australia.

column1: A website
column2: COVID SOS
column3: has been set up as a central hub for the various groups out there working on novel solutions.

column1: It is also trying to address frontline medical equipment shortages through community-sourced methods of design and manufacture.
Here are some examples of the equipment the group is working on:

The ""intubation box"" is an example of an alternative novel PPE to deal with the unique threat of coronavirus. When a patient is so severely affected by the respiratory complications that they need to be put on a ventilator
column2: they need to have a tube put into their trachea to connect them up to the ventilator. That particular procedure puts the doctor (usually an anaesthetist
column3: intensive care specialist
column4: or emergency physician) and assisting staff in very close proximity with the patient's respiratory tract — they're literally staring down the patient's throat. The potential for aerosol exposure there is extreme
column5: and our clinicians had seen perspex shells used overseas for that scenario to limit that exposure. We developed our own solution
column6: as you can see in the diagram
column7: where the patient is under perspex with rubber-like seals to drop around the patient
column8: and it has self-sealing hand holes for the clinicians to do their intubation. The design was revised and simplified a few times and is made from laser-cut perspex
column9: so is ultimately not that complex to build
column10: which is important. It has been tested clinically with success already and we're looking to produce a number of these for multiple hospitals.""

column1: The facial shield is a very simple guard to/from the staff member which provides an impermeable barrier to any aerosols being sprayed in either direction. It obviously doesn't provide a perfect airtight seal but it affords a great deal of confidence when performing procedures on infected patients. We were able to prototype these from an open-source design on the internet and 3D print them. 3D printing has allowed us to rapidly get a design built
column2: so it allows for rapid prototyping
column3: but is very slow in production. A local manufacturer has taken up the need for facial shield designs and has said they'll be able to produce them in the thousands. We have been connecting hospital networks with this manufacturer to allow them to test out their prototypes and they should be able to order them immediately."""

Trump's criticism of Pritzker came hours after the Illinois governor called out the president on CNN's State of the Union for suggesting that states should have prepared their own stockpiles of medical equipment.
The president does not understand the word federal. Federal Emergency Management Agency. We have a state Emergency Management Agency
column2: but if he were right
column3: why would we ever need a Federal Emergency Management Agency?"" Pritzker said. ""It's because individual states can't possibly do what the federal government can do.""

column1: Trump said some U.S. states were ""totally unprepared"" for the coronavirus pandemic during the White House' COVID-19 press conference on Friday. ""We have a federal stockpile
column2: and they have state stockpiles
column3: and frankly they were
column4: many of the states
column5: they were totally unprepared for this
column6: the president said. ""So we had to go into the federal stockpile
column7: but we're not an ordering clerk. They have to have it for themselves.""

column1: In response
column2: Pritzner told CNN that individual states did not have the power to invoke the Defense Production Act that would have allowed them to prepare for such a pandemic
column3: but noted that the Trump administration did.

column1: There's no way that we can stockpile in anticipation of a pandemic that no one anticipated
column2: and yet the federal government is responsible for doing precisely that
column3: the Illinois governor said. ""And we now know that intelligence sources and all the best advice that was given
column4: was given in January and early February to the president and the White House

Bottom Line: Every pricing strategy is going through a hard reset from the pandemics’ economic fallout
column2: making data-driven decisions a must-have going forward
column3: starting with stabilizing pricing and margins.

column1: Data is the best antidote against fear and panic. It provides guardrails
column2: guidance
column3: and insights that lead to better decision-making and
column4: in the case of pricing
column5: preserving margins. Manufacturers surviving in the chaotic wake of COVID-19’s economic impact began modeling worst-case pricing and volume scenarios in early February. Every one of them began deconstructing their sales pipelines
column6: order backlogs
column7: and negotiating for new order delivery dates
column8: doing the best they can with the applications and tools they have. Of all the levers a company can use to stay profitable
column9: pricing is by far the most powerful. A recent McKinsey study found that a 1% price increase yields a 22% increase in Earnings before Interest  Taxes (EBITDA) margins for distribution-based businesses. The same study found it would take a 7.5% reduction in fixed costs to achieve the corresponding 22% increase in EBITDA that a 1% increase in pricing delivers. The more integrated accounting
column11: production
column12: sales
column14: the better the pipeline
column15: backlog
column17: margin
column18: and revenue decisions every business will be able to make. The more effective the commercial analytics
column21: the more they’re able to choose the best possible pricing strategy during chaotic times.

column1: Intelligent Pricing Protects Margins In A Downturn
Being data-driven through a crisis helps alleviate risk
column2: demystifies what the actual revenue and order forecasts are
column3: all leading to fewer pricing missteps in uncertain times. The better the data
column4: the more precise projections of downside risk. Using advanced predictive analytics and machine learning
column5: intelligent pricing can deliver commercial analytics
column6: deal price guidance
column7: and deal intelligence. Think of these three areas of commercial intelligence as part of an intelligence pricing engine continually and dynamically always testing and learning through the use of supervised machine learning algorithms. McKinsey’s recent article
column8: Dynamic pricing: Using digital and analytics to take value pricing in the chemical industry to the next level
column9: provides a framework that illustrates why intelligent pricing is needed today. And while the framework is in a chemical industry-oriented article
column10: its core concepts apply to manufacturing.

column1: McKinsey
column2: Dynamic pricing: Using digital and analytics to take value pricing in the chemical industry to the next level

column1: Preserving margins and enough profit to keep operating during the pandemic requires an entirely new approach to pricing. Knowing in real-time how supplier costs
column2: delays
column3: and unforeseen events impact revenue is a must-have now. Real-time data integration and the speed it delivers is a must-have feature of any pricing system to take on and overcome the many challenges this pandemic has created. Having an intelligent pricing strategy that can quickly interpret
column4: recommend
column5: and act on pricing and margin insights will save more companies in this pandemic than the severest price cuts ever will.

column1: The ideal intelligent pricing system would support real-time integration to ERP
column2: CRM
column3: pricing
column4: and service systems and be built on a solid price management
column5: dynamic pricing
column6: and discount and rebate management platform. Personalizing offers and quoting via machine learning would need to be available across every selling and service channel. Vendavo’s B2B Commercial Excellence platform
column7: coupled with their AI and machine learning expertise
column8: is proving valuable for manufacturers facing the many challenges of operating today:

column1: vendavo.com
What Matters Most When Pricing In A Pandemic
Realize everyone is dealing with a hard revenue reset right now
column2: and the need for demystifying sales pipelines
column3: orders
column4: and backlog is shared across nearly every business affected by the pandemic. After speaking with almost a dozen U.S.-based manufacturers over the last week to see how the pandemic is impacting their business
column5: I learned the following:

column1: Set hard price floors for customers
column2: segments
column3: by SKU (Stocking Unit)
column4: vendor
column5: product collection
column6: and segment. Weighing transaction speed or the time it takes to release a sales hold on a price quote versus margin leakage needs to be considered when hard price floors are set. It’s also a good idea to define eligibility flags which customer
column7: product
column8: vendor
column9: or segment prices are eligible for price exceptions that are sent to sales and senior management for approval.

column1: Price wars waste margins
column2: and do you want a customer who only buys on price anyway? It’s time to quit any deal where there’s a price war going on now and save the margin. Besides
column3: if you’re quoting to a customer who wants to drive your price to the floor or lower
column4: would you take their business in better times? No. Let them go to competitors who are willing to sacrifice margin.

column1: Support the five most-proven sales strategies emerging out of this pandemic with more flexible pricing to match how your customers want to buy. Cross-sell
column2: upsell
column3: renewals
column4: win back
column5: and new customers are the five most proven selling strategies during the pandemic based on last months’ manufacturing sales. When defining cross-sell and upsell sales strategies
column6: taking into account how offers and pricing can be personalized to the offer level is proving effective today. Bundling in services and transitioning win-backs to subscription-based models that may be more affordable today is also working. New customer wins are still happening
column7: driven by improved deal pricing guidance.

column1: Using Configure
column2: Price
column3: Quote (CPQ) as a single console for managing pricing while achieving greater enforcement and guidance is a must-do in these times. Achieving greater pricing enforcement and guidance across all sales channels starts with CPQ being the central hub or reference system for price execution. It’s easier to manage product mix decisions and personalize pricing offers by customer
column4: segment
column5: channel
column6: and product. It’s also an excellent way to get warnings or alerts of potential churn and risk detection by customer of low purchasing – all invaluable data to have during a pandemic."

column1: 466	News	1019019	Benedict Brook	We may never get a vaccine for COVID-19
column2: an infectious diseases expert has warned	"Governments around the world have pinned their hopes of a vaccine for COVID-19 as being the end game in putting the virus to bed.

column1: But an infectious diseases expert has said it’s very possible a vaccine will never be found.
Talking to Karl Stefanovic and Allison Langdon on Channel 9’s Today show this morning
column2: the University of Sydney’s David Isaacs said a vaccine wasn’t found for SARS or MERS – two previous coronavirus outbreaks.

column1: “I think we are all hoping for a vaccine
column2: ” he said.

column1: “People will certainly be developing vaccines
column2: but they have to be tried out as well and see if they work. They have to be effective and that's not an easy task.

column1: “We haven’t had a vaccine
column2: an effective one
column3: against a coronavirus before. The SARS outbreak in 2003
column4: people were developing a vaccine
column5: but it never got tried because SARS disappeared.

column1: “I'm not going to say that is going to happen quite the same with COVID
column2: but we may see COVID under control before we can really test out a vaccine
column3: ” he said.

column1: RELATED: Follow the latest coronavirus updates
RELATED: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson taken to hospital
Asked if that meant we would be in lockdown until a vaccine was found
column2: Dr Issacs said that we might face restrictions until COVID-19 was “under control” possibly in some other form including that the virus simply burned itself out.

column1: “Waiting for a vaccine is a hope but not a certainty. If we don't get a vaccine
column2: we have got other alternatives.

column1: “We found drugs for HIV; we never found a vaccine. We have controlled HIV pretty well in the world using antiviral drugs.
“At the moment we haven't got antiviral drugs (for COVID-19)
column2: they are being tested and we may get those
column3: but in the meanwhile it’s public health measures that are the major weapon in our armoury.”

column1: Hand washing
column2: social distancing and supporting one another were effective methods of getting a handle on coronavirus and he added that “we are doing very well in Australia” because of those measures.

column1: However
column2: Dr Isaacs warned that a vaccine may itself cause unhelpful side effects due to the way some people’s immune systems reacted to the virus.

column1: He cited UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s hospitalisation today (Australia time) after contracting coronavirus and yet still suffering from symptoms more than a week later.
“That may be because his immune response has kicked in and it is actually doing him some harm. His immune response to the vaccine is part of the problem almost
column2: and that's why some younger people are getting sick.”

column1: This is called a cytosine release where the immune system
column2: particularly in healthy people
column3: can go into overdrive and begin damaging the body rather than helping it recover.

column1: “So
column2: when you are developing a vaccine you might conceivably actually cause problems to some people. It is something that we will have to test very carefully.”

column1: It was for that reason
column2: Dr Issacs said
column3: that young people needed to be wary of coronavirus. Because while most will recover
column4: some could react extremely badly to the virus entering their system."

column1: 1478	Stuff	983530	Melanie Earley	Coronavirus: 'Virtual check-in' trialled at two Auckland supermarkets to help ease queues	"A ""virtual check-in"" system is being trialled at two Auckland supermarkets in a bid to help keep customers safe during the level four lockdown.
Foodstuffs has introduced the technology – which allows customers to wait in their cars until it's their turn to enter the store – at New World in Kumeu and Pak 'n Save in Royal Oak.
Our goal with the virtual 'check-in' solution is to improve the customer experience when New Zealanders arrive to our stores to do their essential shopping
column2: Simon Kennedy
column3: Chief Digital Officer of Foodstuffs North Island said.

column1: The physical distancing measures we need to maintain inspired the teams to innovate a solution which would simplify store arrival and give customers the flexibility to wait where they please.""
READ MORE:
* Coronavirus: Full coverage
* Staff member at Kaikohe New World tests positive for virus
* Man arrested after coughing on fellow shoppers
During the trial customers at the two supermarkets can check in either virtually or physically at entry.
Those who check in virtually with their phones will be sent a text when it's their turn to enter
column2: while those who check in physically will have their names added to a list which will be called out when it is their turn.

column1: The solution is easy
column2: free and all customers need is a mobile phone
column3: Kennedy said.

column1: The virtual check-in means customers will not have to queue outside the store and instead can wait somewhere more comfortable such as their car until it is their turn.
It's great for all customers
column2: but particularly for those who are vulnerable or elderly who can now wait somewhere more comfortable. By reserving a virtual spot in line
column3: they can now wait in their car or go for a walk around the block to get some fresh air
column4: Kennedy said.

column1: Store staff and signage will advise customers which number they should text and to answer any questions they might have.
The average virtual wait varies by how busy the store is and how many customers are allowed in the store based on the 2m physical distancing measure.
Further national roll out of the trial beyond New World Kumeu and Pak 'n Save Royal Oak will be decided at a later date."
1478	Stuff	1218772	Sue Williams	How to persuade elderly parents and grandparents to stay home: Away from coronavirus	"This generation is tremendously hardy
column2: often infuriatingly independent and just don't like being told what to do by their youngers. (File photo)

column1: It's fast emerging as one of the toughest challenges of the coronavirus crisis: how to persuade elderly parents and grandparents to stay home and out of infectious harm's way.
This generation is tremendously hardy
column2: often infuriatingly independent and just don't like being told what to do by their youngers.

column1: After all
column2: they fought in wars
column3: they remind us. They survived bombings
column4: sometimes in their earlier homelands. They've known bleak economic conditions and shortages before.

column1: And
column2: they say feistily
column3: they're a lot closer than most to the end of their lives
column4: so what the hell?

column1: READ MORE:
* Coronavirus: PM backs families battling to keep seniors in their lockdown bubble
* Rise of the introverts as coronavirus lockdown takes hold
* Coronavirus: Brothers stranded in China make it home to Taranaki
I called my own parents
column2: aged 82 and 89
column3: this morning. They were out.

column1: People have to sit their parents and grandparents down and explain to them in very
column2: very clear and simple terms why it's so important they stay at home
column3: said Cheryl Field
column4: the editor of The Senior newspaper.

column1: The main thing is to stress how urgent it is
column2: but not to scare the living daylights out of them so they spend their time in the house shivering with fear.

column1: Then we're finding them falling into two camps
column2: like any age group. There are some who'll obey and others who'll say
column3: 'I'm 80 and I'm going to go out and do what the hell I want'. There's a lot of information going out online
column4: but a lot of this group aren't online.""

column1: A just published Harris Poll in the US found that the population most at risk – the elderly with 80-year-olds and over having a 15 per cent fatality rate compared to the average rate of 2.3 per cent – are the least worried about catching the disease and dying
column2: and are the least informed.

column1: Aged Care Minister Richard Colbeck said we should all remind them of the importance of social distancing
column2: too.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the highest rate of fatalities is among older people
column3: particularly those with a weakened immune system
column4: he said.

column1: Many elderly people are doing the right thing
column2: believes comedian Jean Kittson
column3: who's just brought out a new book We Need To Talk About Mum & Dad. But there are others who
column4: for various reasons
column5: aren't doing the right thing.

column1: It's then important to talk to them about why they're insisting on going out. ""It might be that they think they're being less of a burden by doing their own shopping
column2: rather than sending someone else out into the virus zone
column3: she said. ""They might be doing out of some misplaced sense of self-sacrifice.

column1: But then you talk to them about how they would be much more useful to the family if they don't get sick or don't spread it to others. Sometimes they're not so concerned about getting it themselves because they're elderly and they feel they've lived their lives
column2: but they don't want to give it to others.""

column1: It's not just the stick of scary warnings that should work with older parents and grandparents
column2: however. There are also carrots to offer them to stay at home.

column1: Younger members of the family could do their shopping for them
column2: set them up for online deliveries and suggest they install Zoom or Skype or use Facebook's Messenger for fun contact.

column1: If they're not tech-savvy
column2: their family could use the remote connectivity platform TeamViewer to install apps for them. Playing Scrabble online against an unknown opponent can be a refreshing diversion.

column1: We can also talk them into streaming services
column2: particularly to watch some of the old shows they might be most fond of
column3: or pay for it ourselves. And there are long-lost hobbies to take up again
column4: photos to organise on their computers
column5: or older ones to sort through and finally stick into albums.

column1: Social isolation may be very difficult for them
column2: said Kittson. ""So it's important to help them through it. You might ring them twice a day and stay in touch
column3: and reassure them as they may have already experienced a lot of loss
column4: especially if they've lost a partner.

column1: That might sometimes work better than reading them the riot act.""
This article first appeared in Domain.com.au and has been republished with permission."

1551	The Sun - UK	1106745	Amanda Devlin	Dynamo reveals life-threatening Crohn's disease battle after getting COVID-19	"HE has performed to 750
column2: 000 people during a live tour
column3: sold out London’s O2 arena
column4: counts Brad Pitt and Justin Bieber among his fans and has wowed TV audiences with his brand of intimate close-up magic and mesmerising big-budget stunts.

column1: But all that came crashing down around Dynamo’s ears in the summer of 2017 when he suffered such a serious flare up of his Crohn’s disease that he feared for both his life and his livelihood.
After a two-year battle to regain his health
column2: Dynamo – real name Steven Frayne – makes a triumphant return to our screens this week in Beyond Belief
column3: his first all-magic TV show since Magician Impossible ended in 2014.

column1: Having suffered from Crohn’s since his teenage years – he had half of his stomach removed at the age of 17 – the 37 year old is used to managing pain and discomfort
column2: but as he sits down for an interview with TV Mag during our exclusive photo shoot
column3: Dynamo reveals that he’s never felt worse than when he got a bout of food poisoning three years ago.

column1: “The easiest way to sum up Crohn’s is to imagine an open wound on your hand
column2: but inside your tummy
column3: and every time you eat it’s like rubbing dirt into that wound
column4: ” he explains.

column1: “Obviously some food is dirtier than others and it can cause your tummy to bleed
column2: so it’s a wound that never quite heals up.

column1: I don’t want to sound too disgusting
column2: but with this food poisoning
column3: there was a lot of stuff coming out everywhere. You know like in Family Guy when they vomit? It was like that
column4: but blood.

column1: It was 4am and my wife rushed me to hospital. I could tell it was something to do with the Crohn’s
column2: but when I got to hospital the highest dosage of morphine wasn’t even touching the sides. It was the worst feeling I’ve ever had.”

column1: He ended up facing a five-week stretch in hospital
column2: much of it in isolation because doctors were unsure whether he was contagious or at risk from other people.

column1: “I’m very comfortable in my own company because I was always left alone when I was on my estate in Bradford growing up – my dad was in jail and my mum wasn’t always around
column2: ” shares Dynamo.

column1: “My imagination became my best friend then. So when I was in isolation in the hospital
column2: after getting over the burden of thinking: ‘Am I ever going to perform again?’ I started to create loads of crazy magic. I’m not going to lie
column3: I was definitely high on the medication the doctors were giving me!”

column1: That stay in hospital wasn’t the end of Dynamo’s suffering
column2: however. After he was discharged
column3: he developed reactive arthritis
column4: and was put on an extremely high dose of steroids to treat his swollen and painful joints. That resulted in his whole body puffing up
column5: creating what he describes as a “moonface”
column6: and pictures surfaced that shocked his fans.

column1: “My appearance was changing and it was getting harder to hide that I wasn’t the same old Steven that people knew
column2: ” he says. “I didn’t want to be defined by my illness and I didn’t want to burden people with my problems.

column1: But when some images came out I decided to make a video on Instagram explaining to people the real story behind them. The outpouring of support I got spurred me on.

But it was also quite funny because I never thought I would see in my Instagram comments people calling me fat – I thought it was hilarious because I have always been the skinny kid. I was sending the pig emoji to all of my friends!”
The 37-year-old magician revealed he has been battling ""severe"" coronavirus symptoms.
He is considered a high risk for the deadly illness because of Crohn's disease.
While Dynamo admits that he’s still only at 85 per cent fitness and is in hospital every other week for powerful infusions of medicine that helps keep his arthritis and Crohn’s at bay
column2: he’s determined to turn what he describes as his darkest days into something positive.

column1: “It’s very easy to wallow in the sickness
column2: especially when you feel like you’re losing everything that’s important around you
column3: ” he reflects. “Not being able to perform magic
column4: for me
column5: I didn’t see the point in being alive. It’s my identity. But it caused me to find myself in a different way. And I’ve definitely taken my disabilities and turned them into superpowers.

column1: “Beyond Belief has definitely been the hardest I’ve ever had to work to create something
column2: but it’s come from such a personal place. I genuinely think this is the best magic I have ever done. I want to show people I’m back. This is only the beginning of the return of Dynamo…”"

column1: 1925	Fortune	967756	Jenna Schnuer	Coronavirus gave cannabis companies a big bump in sales and it wasn't just for the wake-and-bake set	"As a wide range of American economy sectors ground to a halt in response to the coronavirus crisis
column2: one particular industry headed in the other direction. Across the United States during the week of March 16
column3: cannabis dispensaries saw their sales soar by double digits. One company dealt with hour-long lines at its Pennsylvania stores. On March 16th alone
column4: sales doubled in California.

column1: Roy Bingham
column2: CEO of cannabis market research firm BDS Analytics
column3: said he expects the industry to not only ride out the coming economic storm but continue to grow. His firm has yet to revise its prediction of a 30% jump to $17 billion in U.S. retail sales for 2020. “First
column4: you have this existing core demand; 65% of cannabis consumers consume on a daily basis
column5: ” said Bingham. “And now you have people who can’t go to the gym or the bar and are locked up at home
column6: where about half of all cannabis consumptions happens anyway.”

column1: Though sales flattened out after that initial bump in sales
column2: the demand for cannabis isn’t expected to dip anytime soon. Thus far
column3: none of the 22 states with legal marijuana dispensaries have ordered them closed (although Nevada moved to delivery only and some companies have decided their customers must order online before coming to the store). Most U.S. dispensaries remain open
column4: often classified as essential services
column5: though
column6: in Canada
column7: Ontario took pot shops off the essential list and ordered them closed by April 3.

column1: The fact that marijuana could remain one of the fastest growing sectors of the economy has much to do with the fact the product is hardly just for stoners anymore. In recent years
column2: cannabis companies have been busy opening new dispensaries in mainstream
column3: high traffic locations. Sleek
column4: spacious
column5: and uncluttered
column6: they often look more like Apple stores or places to buy upscale furniture than traditional headshops that appealed more to counterculture types. The goal is
column7: at many of the newer shops
column8: to educate consumers and entice people to think of marijuana as no different than a glass of wine or a few beers.

column1: “The stoner stereotype is not dead
column2: but it’s not the primary cannabis consumer these days
column3: ” said Jessica Lukas
column4: vice president of consumer insights at BDS Analytics.

column1: Cannabis 2.0 consumers are older and more female than cannabis enthusiasts of years past
column2: and they’re showing up at dispensaries not just to get high but for health and wellness needs. “A good night’s sleep and pain relief are the biggest drivers for people coming into our stores
column3: ” said Jennifer Dooley
column4: chief strategy officer at Green Thumb Industries
column5: which operates Rise dispensaries in seven states.

column1: Even High Times
column2: the longtime chronicler of the stoner lifestyle and a “magazine of high society” tagline
column3: is going mainstream. Stormy Simon
column4: High Times CEO
column5: said the company will open two “clean and inviting” dispensaries in Las Vegas and Los Angeles later this year. They will feature legacy High Times memorabilia but also welcome people who have little-to-nothing in common with old-school stoners “with open arms.”

column1: Much like other dispensary companies
column2: High Times will bring in new consumers with the help of new kinds of cannabis products. While straight marijuana
column3: or flower
column4: remains a core product
column5: the fastest growing categories are edibles and other smokeless options—from gummies and chocolates to tinctures
column6: breath sprays
column7: and bath salts. Instead of touting THC levels or “terpene profiles
column8: ” these products are packaged to appeal to specific consumer segments or address a particular need. Green Thumb’s Feel Collection tinctures
column9: for instance
column10: loos like something you might buy in a beauty store. Packaged in elegant purple
column11: blue
column12: and green glass bottles
column13: the products target middle-aged women (“blends cannabis extracts with natural ingredients to make every day a little more heck yeah”). Each product promises a desired effect
column14: including comfort
column15: dreamy
column17: relaxed
column18: or healed.

column1: There is even cannabis in capsule form that’s packaged in the well-known look of a prescription drug bottle. “We’re not going to ask grandma to roll a joint
column2: so we focus on forms that are familiar and comfortable to people
column3: ” says Greg Butler
column4: chief commercial officer at Cresco
column5: which sells Remedi cannabis capsules. Brands also focus on appealing to people who worry their weed will leave them unable to get off the couch and function normally (aka “couch lock”)
column6: though that may be less of an issue during the coronavirus lockdown. “Our Beebo brand has much more subtle
column7: lower THC levels. We call it a social dose. You can enjoy it but still go on with your day
column8: ” said Green Thumb’s Dooley.

column1: But perhaps no consumer is as attractive to cannabis companies as seniors. Not only are they more likely to have medical conditions that cannabis could address
column2: they’re also the most free-spending of all users. According to Eaze
column3: a cannabis software platform and marketplace
column4: baby boomers spend
column5: on average
column6: close to 30% more at dispensaries than millennials. Yet reaching these consumers
column7: along with other segments of the population
column8: is a challenge because marijuana’s continued illegal status at the federal level renders TV and digital ads off limits. As a result
column9: many companies are taking their pitch directly into senior communities.

column1: Earlier this month
column2: Trulieve
column3: which operates 45 dispensaries in Florida
column4: hosted a “Silver Tour” at a large retirement community in Tamarac
column5: Fla. Featuring free Panera Bread and a doctor who spoke about marijuana and medical conditions
column6: it drew several hundred attentive audience members. “When I started doing this
column7: they said
column8: ‘We don’t want these shows; our people are not interested in marijuana
column9: ’” said Robert Platshorn
column10: a marijuana activist who runs and organizes these events for Trulieve. “Now it’s a matter of getting to all the senior communities who would like to have us.”
