—Which stores are open—and closed—during the coronavirus pandemic in the U.S.?—How re-commerce players like Poshmark and eBay are adapting to the coronavirus—How Nike is overcoming the coronavirus impact on its China business—It may be a while before many of America’s stores open again—Listen to Leadership Next
column2: a Fortune podcast examining the evolving role of CEO—WATCH: The greatest designs of modern timesFollow Fortune on Flipboard to stay up-to-date on the latest news and analysis."

column1: 692	The Hill	942105	Peter Sullivan	Feds send ventilators to coronavirus hot spots around country	"President Trump Donald John TrumpPelosi eyes end of April to bring a fourth coronavirus relief bill to the floor NBA to contribute 1 million surgical masks to NY essential workers Private equity firm with ties to Kushner asks Trump administration to relax rules on loan program: report MORE announced Sunday that the federal government is sending several hundred additional ventilators to states hit hard by the coronavirus outbreak.
Trump told a White House briefing that over the last 24 hours the federal government has delivered an additional 500 ventilators to New Jersey

column3: he said

column1: The ventilator disbursements come as governors have clamored for weeks for the Trump administration to do more to confront the shortage of the crucially needed machines

Louisiana Gov. John Bel Edwards (D) said earlier Sunday on CNN that his state had received 200 ventilators from the federal government but still expected to run out on April 9.
The ventilator announcement comes as federal officials are warning that the coming week will be particularly bad

column1: Secretary of Veterans Affairs Robert Wilkie Robert Leon WilkieVA must improve access to high-quality care for transgender veterans VA secretary confirms first veteran death due to coronavirus Hillicon Valley: Harris presses Facebook over census misinformation | Austin cancels SXSW over coronavirus fears | Surveillance deal elusive as deadline nears | FTC sends warnings to Cardi B

column1: Still

Pritzker (D) kept up his criticism of the Trump administration earlier Sunday for not fully using the Defense Production Act to direct businesses to ramp up production of needed supplies and coordinate where they will go. column1: 323	BBC UK	2432059	Claire Press	Why some NHS workers are wearing bin bags	"As the death toll from coronavirus continues to climb
column2: hospitals across the UK are working flat out to create more intensive care beds for those who are critically ill. Speaking to the BBC
column3: one intensive care doctor describes the crippling reality of a lack of support and equipment faced by some health-care workers in England.

column1: Several healthcare workers in England have told the BBC of a lack of equipment in their hospitals. Warned against speaking to the media
column2: they were unwilling to talk publicly. However
column3: one intensive care doctor from the Midlands wanted to go on record. The BBC agreed to change her name in order to protect her identity.

column1: Dr Roberts describes a hospital on the brink. Intensive care is already full of coronavirus (Covid-19) patients. All operations deemed non-urgent
column2: even the cancer clinics
column3: have been cancelled. There is a lack of staff
column4: a lack of critical care beds
column5: a shortage of basic antibiotics and ventilators.

column1: All this
column2: combined with the looming uncertainty of what will be the expected peak
column3: estimated to hit the UK around 14-15 April
column4: means hospital staff are already feeling the strain.

column1: However
column2: nothing Dr Roberts describes is quite as alarming as the fact that these medical professionals
column3: who continue to care for critically ill patients for 13 hours every day
column4: are having to resort to fashioning personal protective equipment (PPE) out of clinical waste bags
column5: plastic aprons and borrowed skiing goggles.

column1: Image caption
Dr Roberts shown in the left picture
column2: tying a bin bag covering the sides and back of her colleague's head

column1: While the public attempts to keep to a social distance of two metres
column2: many NHS staff are being asked to examine patients suspected of coronavirus at a distance of 20cm - without the proper protection.

column1: With potentially fatal implications
column2: Dr Roberts says several departments within her hospital are now so fearful of what's coming next
column3: they have begun to hoard PPE for themselves.

column1: It's about being pragmatic. The nurses on ITU (Intensive Treatment Unit) need it now. They are doing procedures which risk aerosol spread of the virus. But they've been told to wear normal theatre hats
column2: which have holes in them and don't provide any protection.

column1: It's wrong. And that's why we're having to put bin bags and aprons on our heads.""
The government has acknowledged distribution problems
column2: but says a national supply team
column3: supported by the armed forces
column4: is now ""working around the clock"" to deliver equipment.

column1: NHS England also said more than one million respiratory face masks were delivered on 1 April
column2: but with no mention of much-needed head protection and long-sleeved gowns.

column1: Dr Roberts says her hospital has not received anything from the government
column2: and what they do have is causing concern.

column1: The respiratory protection face masks we're using at the moment
column2: they've all been relabelled with new best-before end dates. Yesterday I found one with three stickers on. The first said
column3: expiry 2009. The second sticker
column4: expiry 2013. And the third sticker on the very top said 2021.""

column1: Public Health England has said all stockpiled pieces of PPE [personal protective equipment] labelled with new expiry dates have ""passed stringent tests"" and are ""safe for use by NHS staff"". But Dr Roberts says she is not convinced.
Image caption
Dr Roberts pulls expiry date stickers from the packaging on a face mask
The Department of Health and Social Care also said it was ""working closely with industry
column2: the NHS
column3: social care providers and the Army… If staff need to order more PPE there is a hotline in place"".

column1: It said its new guidance on PPE was in line with World Health Organization advice to ""make sure all clinicians are aware of what they should be wearing"".
Currently ventilated and under Dr Roberts' care are three of her colleagues
column2: all of whom have tested positive for coronavirus. One is an intensive care doctor working on a Covid ward
column3: who
column4: like Dr Roberts
column5: only had access to inadequate protection.

column1: The other two were both working on non-Covid wards and therefore were wearing no PPE. However
column2: given their symptoms
column3: Dr Roberts believes both of them contracted the virus while at work.

column1: Although colleagues continue to visit
column2: as with all other patients
column3: no relatives are allowed anywhere within the hospital.

column1: The hardest thing at the moment is having to tell families you are withdrawing care
column2: over the phone. Telling them their relatives are dying or have died but we can't let you come and see them
column3: says Dr Roberts.

column1: ""Normally you can say to their relative who's at the bedside
column2: 'We're going to do everything we can'
column3: but I haven't felt able to say that
column4: because at the moment
column5: I can't.

column1: I can't necessarily give them the best care on a ventilator
column2: I can't guarantee the best nursing care
column3: because the best nurses are being stretched four ways. We're running out of antibiotics
column4: and I can't guarantee all the treatments that I know would help them.""

column1: NHS England says it has no record of how many medical professionals have been admitted to hospital after contracting coronavirus at work.
However
column2: the two hardest-hit countries in Europe are counting. Spain's emergency health minister announced on 27 March that more than 9
column3: 400 health-care workers had tested positive
column4: and in Italy
column5: as of 30 March
column6: more than 6
column7: 414 medical professionals were reported to have been infected.

column1: In the UK
column2: several health workers are known to have died from coronavirus
column3: including Areema Nasreen
column4: a staff nurse in the West Midlands
column5: Thomas Harvey
column6: a health-care assistant in east London
column7: Prof Mohamed Sami Shousha in central London
column8: Dr Alfa Saadu in north London
column9: Dr Habib Zaidi in Southend
column10: Dr Adil El Tayar in west London and Dr Amged El-Hawrani in Leicester.

column1: Breaking point
Based on projections from Italy and Spain
column2: Dr Roberts says health-care workers are bracing for the peak to hit in less than two weeks.

column1: If cases rise as quickly as they did in Spain and Italy
column2: then quite frankly
column3: we are screwed. All of our overspill areas will soon be full.

column1: The anaesthetic machines we have
column2: which are designed to work for two to three hours at most
column3: have been running for four to five days straight. We're already getting leaks and failures.""

column1: Image copyright
Getty Images
Image caption
Also short of PPE
column2: an intensive care nurse in Spain wears a bin bag and a protective plastic mask
column3: donated by a local company

column1: Extra intensive care beds
column2: set up in several operating theatres and wards
column3: have nearly doubled the hospital's capacity to support critically ill patients
column4: particularly those who can't breathe for themselves and need to be put on a ventilator.

column1: However
column2: by expanding intensive care
column3: Dr Roberts says it's the nursing staff who are disproportionately affected.

column1: Intensive care nurses are highly trained and normally deliver care one-to-one to those critically ill. Their patients may be asleep
column2: but they have such a close relationship
column3: they can describe every hair on a patient's head.

column1: But now
column2: with these extra beds
column3: nurses are under pressure to look after up to four patients
column4: while delivering the same level of critical care. They are in tears and really struggling. They are the most important part of the system
column5: but that's where it's going to fall down"".

column1: Stay at home
Outside in the hospital car park
column2: Dr Roberts describes how a new temporary building has appeared in the ambulance bay with just one purpose - to vet all patients for symptoms of coronavirus before they are admitted.

column1: It is run by a clinician
column2: who
column3: Dr Roberts points out
column4: could otherwise be looking after patients. She describes the unit as a ""lie detector"".

column1: Image copyright
Getty Images
""It's really common for people to lie about their symptoms just to get seen. People who should have stayed at home
column2: but they come to AE.

column1: So now every single patient gets vetted in the car park
column2: to make sure those with Covid symptoms go to the right part of the hospital and don't infect everyone else
column3: like those who've come in with a broken arm.""

column1: But for Dr Roberts
column2: it's not just about those turning up at AE
column3: it's everyone.

column1: Most hospital staff
column2: we are isolating ourselves when we are not at work
column3: so as not to put other people at risk.

column1: But the most frustrating thing for us is to see the parks full
column2: or Tescos even busier than usual. Please stay at home.""

16407	Vietnam Express	673534	Le Nga	Vietnam goes second morning with no new Covid-19 case - VnExpress International	"Vietnam goes second morning with no new Covid-19 case
By
Le Nga  nbspApril 6
A doctor in protective clothes is about to step in an ambulance car at the National Hospital of Tropical Diseases in Hanoi's Dong Anh District
column2: March 30
column3: 2020. Photo by VnExpress/Ngoc Thanh.

column1: Vietnam has not recorded any new coronavirus infections Monday morning and in the past 24 hours
column2: only one more case has been added.

column1: The national tally
column2: as such
column3: is kept at 241 since the evening of Sunday
column4: according to the Ministry of Health.

column1: Monday morning marks the second morning in a row that the nation has had no new cases of Covid-19
column2: after several were reported every morning for almost a month.

column1: On Sunday evening
column2: a 20-year-old Vietnamese student returning from the U.K. took the country’s total count to 241.

column1: Of the 241 Covid-19 patients in Vietnam
column2: 91 have been discharged.

column1: Many of the 150 active cases are Vietnamese nationals returning from abroad
column2: mostly from Europe and the U.S.
column3: and more than 60 people are related to the two major Covid-19 hotspots in the country – the Bach Mai Hospital in Hanoi with at least 43 cases and Buddha Bar  Grill in Ho Chi Minh City 18 cases.

column1: The country entered a 15-day nationwide social distancing campaign on April 1
column2: not allowing gatherings of more than two people and asking people not to leave their homes to contain the spread of the pandemic. The step was taken citing a crucial two-week period in the nation’s Covid-19 fight.

column1: The government also suspended all inbound international flights and halted road transport services until April 15 to limit travel in the country of 94 million people.
The global death toll caused by the Covid-19 pandemic has reached more than 69
column2: 300 people as it spread to 208 countries and territories."

1476	Straits Times	941192		Morning Briefing: Top stories from on April 6	"Good morning! Here are our top stories to kick-start your Monday
column2: April 6.

The constitution — an unwieldy collection of sometimes ancient and contradictory precedents — offers no clear

column1: Whereas in the United States the vice president steps up if the president dies or becomes incapacitated

Downing Street has already said
column2: however

column1: [ Sign up for our Health IQ newsletter for the latest coronavirus updates ]

column2: and there is little precedence.

column1: When asked about who would stand in for the prime minister

column3: but for now it is the prime minister and then the foreign secretary.”

column1: Churchill’s stroke
In June 1953
column2: then-Prime Minister Winston Churchill suffered a stroke while in office. His illness was kept so secret that some senior ministers were unaware.

column1: Story continues below advertisement
Churchill surprised doctors by recovering to carry on his duties

column1: More recently

column3: each time briefly cutting back on his workload for a couple of days.

column1: Officials said that if Blair were to have been incapacitated
column2: his then-deputy John Prescott would have taken over until a new leader was elected.

column2: speaking to Sky News last month after Johnson tested positive

column1: Story continues below advertisement
Haddon from the Institute for Government said some powers were specifically vested in cabinet ministers
column2: so there was an issue of what happened if they were unavailable.

2068	New York Post	994995	Mike Vaccaro	Lesson of Maurice Stokes-Jack Twyman bond resonates in these coronavirus times	"The celebration was going to culminate in the 700-seat auditorium at the John F. Kennedy Student Center
column2: tucked into the northern segment of the campus of St. Francis University in Loretto
column3: Pa. There
column4: Monday night
column5: the 2
column6: 100-student school would celebrate the life of Maurice Stokes
column7: the school’s most famous alumnus
column8: on the 50th anniversary of his death.

column1: “But God has his own plan
column2: ” says Rev. Malachi Van Tassell
column3: the university’s president.

column1: So much about the extraordinary life of Maurice Stokes must be explained
column2: if it is to be explained at all
column3: by those six simple words. He was a brilliant college player at St. Francis
column4: the first player to win the MVP at the NIT from a team that didn’t win the tournament (in 1955)
column5: culminating a year in which he averaged 27.1 points and 26.2 rebounds.

column1: He was the NBA’s rookie of the year in 1956 for the Rochester Royals
column2: became an All-Star when that franchise moved to Cincinnati
column3: averaged 16.4 points and 17.3 rebounds and was well on his way
column4: at age 24
column5: to becoming one of the greatest players in the league’s history.

column1: But on March 12
column3: Stokes fell and banged his head in the Royals’ regular-season finale. A few days later
column4: on a small plane ride home from Detroit for a playoff game
column5: he took ill. By the time he reached the hospital he was fully paralyzed
column6: diagnosed with post-traumatic encephalopathy.

column1: He would regain some motor skills over the years through intense physical therapy but suffered a heart attack and died on April 6
column3: two months shy of his 37th birthday. His funeral was held at St. Francis and he is buried on campus
column4: in the Franciscan Friar Cemetery
column5: one of only a few lay people given their eternal rest there.

column1: It is one of the heartbreaking stories in the history of American sports
column2: but also one of the most redeeming
column3: too
column4: thanks to Stokes’ friendship with Jack Twyman. Twyman was a fellow all-star on the Royals and though the two men weren’t especially close
column5: Stokes’ accident changed that. Twyman lived year-round in Cincinnati. Stokes’ family was in Pittsburgh. Soon after Stokes’ diagnosis
column6: Twyman agreed to become Stokes’ legal guardian.

column1: What followed was one of the extraordinary friendships ever formed.
One day
column2: Jack was asked why he’d decided to make such a remarkable commitment to Maurice
column3: and again he shrugged his shoulders and said
column4: “Maurice needed someone. I became that someone.”

column1: That phrase — “Become That Someone” — all these years later
column2: has become St. Francis’ motto. And though St. Francis had to postpone its celebration of Stokes’ life
column3: it is a message that has never seemed more relevant than it does in these turbulent
column4: uncertain days.

column1: “During this pandemic it’s a call for each person to become their best self
column2: ” Father Van Tassell says. “We can become that someone in any number of scenarios.”

column1: Tim Frank was hoping to be a part of the celebration. Frank is the NBA’s senior vice president for basketball communications and he is from Altoona
column2: Pa.
column3: less than a half-hour from St. Francis. He grew up believing Stokes was larger than life
column4: watched Red Flash basketball games in the fieldhouse named for Stokes
column5: looked at his retired No. 26 in the rafters there.

column1: One of the saddest elements of Stokes’ story is that he played in the league so briefly
column2: and even among many basketball fans his is a name that often draws blank stares. The NBA did its part to rectify that eight years ago when it created the Twyman-Stokes Award to recognize the league’s teammate of the year.

column1: It is a poignant trophy — one figurine helping another to its feet — and the winners
column2: who have included Chauncey Billups
column3: Tim Duncan and Vince Carter
column4: are invariably honored at first and then completely humbled once they read up on the award’s namesakes.

column1: “It’s so gratifying to see that
column2: ” Frank says. “More people should know about Maurice
column3: and more people should know about the amazing friendship he had with Jack. Especially now. This is a story that resonates.”

column1: It does. It should. We lean on friends now as much as we ever have
column2: more even
column3: as much as Maurice and Jack leaned on each other. Once
column4: late in his life
column5: Maurice’s intense rehab yielded a small victory: he was able to regain a little flexibility in his fingers. It took him a few hours
column6: but he finally completed his first sentence. He showed it to his friend:

column1: “Dear Jack
column2: how can I ever thank you?”

column1: To which Jack immediately
column2: and quintessentially
column3: replied: “You may think I come here to cheer you up. But
column4: really
column5: it’s the other way around.”"

column1: 2068	New York Post	1034484	Joel Sherman	Mets might be MLB’s biggest loser in the coronavirus era	"There are 30 losers. Some lose less
column2: some lose a lot more when it comes to major league teams during the coronavirus pandemic.

column1: The Orioles lose less. They were going to have trouble drawing spectators this year. They get to run time off the horrible contracts of Alex Cobb and
column2: especially
column3: Chris Davis without paying them. No one of too much significance is accruing service time toward arbitration or free agency while games are not played.

column1: The Tigers are in a similar situation
column2: just substitute Jordan Zimmermann and Miguel Cabrera for Cobb and Davis while acknowledging that service time accruing for Matt Boyd is somewhat hurtful.

column1: On the other side
column2: the Dodgers are oft mentioned for being particularly hurt by games being missed and perhaps a season lost to the virus. That revolves mainly around one player — Mookie Betts. He is due to be a free agent following the 2020 season regardless and now may never play a game for the Dodgers after they traded three prospects to Boston for him
column3: plus redirected Kenta Maeda to Minnesota.

column1: But the Dodgers have the young talent and resources to remain a powerhouse even without the prospects or Betts. The lost revenue in the sport likely will drive down free-agent prices at least for the near future
column2: and just a few teams
column3: such as the Dodgers and Yankees
column4: might have the finances to capitalize.

column1: For the Yankees
column2: though
column3: part of the tolerance to stretch to nine years at $324 million for Gerrit Cole was knowing
column4: yeah
column5: they likely would be overpaying over the last few seasons of the contract
column6: but they also would be getting prime years early. Now
column7: Cole’s final season in his 20s is tick
column8: tick
column9: ticking away without games.

column1: Still
column2: the Yankees have talent and resources and — like the Dodgers — a baseball operations department that knows how to assemble a winning team.

column1: The biggest losers are clubs that have pushed so much into the pot for this year or next and do not have strong feeder systems or the financial wherewithal to best withstand things if most or
column2: especially all
column3: of the 2020 major league season is lost. The three that stand out are the Cubs
column4: Reds and Mets.

column1: Mets GM Brodie Van WagenenCharles Wenzelberg/New York Post
The Cubs marketed their best players
column2: such as Kris Bryant and Willson Contreras
column3: in the offseason recognizing they needed to spread payroll around more and deepen their stock of controllable talent. But the Cubs never traded those players
column4: who had two years of service time until free agency. So now
column5: as their control is dwindling even as no games are being played
column6: their value is lower
column7: especially because more teams will lack the revenue to want to take on expensive players.

column1: Cubs president of baseball operations Theo Epstein told me last month the team would decide by the trade deadline if it could win a title and
column2: if not
column3: would be realistic about moving players. Will there even be a trade deadline now with the Cubs facing the core of a champion — Bryant
column4: Contreras
column5: Javy Baez
column6: Jon Lester
column7: Anthony Rizzo and Kyle Schwarber — with expiring contracts after this season or next?

column1: The Reds already gave away two of their better prospects (Jeter Downs and Josiah Gray) to get out of Homer Bailey’s pact last year
column2: and the Dodgers already used Downs as a key to get Betts. The Reds also used touted prospect Taylor Trammell last July to get Trevor Bauer when they weren’t really contenders just so they would have him in his walk year this season. Now
column3: what walk season?

column1: Cincinnati gave matching four-year
column2: $64 million free-agent pacts to Nick Castellanos and Mike Moustakas to try to win now. Would you bet on either aging well? Part of the calculus was at least they had 2020 with those guys to try to end a postseason drought that extends to 2013.

column1: But the Mets might be the big losers. Let us count the ways:
They traded key prospects Jarred Kelenic
column2: Justin Dunn
column3: Anthony Kay and Simeon Woods Richardson for Robinson Cano
column4: Edwin Diaz and Marcus Stroman
column5: and they did not make the playoffs last year. Stroman
column6: like Bauer
column7: was obtained with his 2020 walk year in mind. So either he will pitch less in his walk year or become a free agent without pitching at all.

column1: The trade with the Mariners
column2: already looking disastrous with Kelenic growing into a top prospect while Cano and Diaz faltered last year
column3: can only be revived if the Mets receive a lot out of Cano and Diaz. As one NL executive said of what missing games does to that Mets’ trade: “It takes an egregious screwup and makes it worse.”

column1: Like Bryant and Contreras
column2: Michael Conforto
column3: Steven Matz and Noah Syndergaard all will be free agents after next season
column4: and the Mets are now losing shrinking time with them. Syndergaard was going to miss this season one way or another after needing Tommy John surgery. But
column5: again
column6: like the Cubs with Bryant and Contreras
column7: the Mets have missed their best window to trade Syndergaard and recoup some of the controllable inventory lost in the Cano
column8: Diaz and Stroman deals.

column1: Also
column2: with no Syndergaard and with Stroman
column3: Rick Porcello and Michael Wacha free agents
column4: the Mets’ rotation to begin 2021 is Jacob deGrom and Matz — and Matz can leave the following offseason. The strength of the team is about to not be that.

column1: DeGrom turns 32 in June. Like Cole with the Yankees
column2: the Mets just don’t want to lose out on any of deGrom’s peak.

column1: One reason the Mets could tolerate some expense and bad contracts is players such as Pete Alonso
column2: Jeff McNeil and J.D. Davis were not yet arbitration eligible. The Mets wasted a cheap season of that trio last year and another could be flitting away now.

column1: If there is a season
column2: the good-faith understanding between the union and MLB is that an attempt will be made to play as many games as possible. That likely will necessitate adding doubleheaders and perhaps removing off days. I would argue that the Mets’ best 1-through-15 are as good as or better than that of any NL team except the Dodgers. And Brodie Van Wagenen has made the Mets a bit deeper than in recent seasons — especially in the bullpen if Dellin Betances is healthy
column3: and Diaz and Jeurys Familia rebound (which was going to be key even in a 162-game campaign).

column1: Submit questions on your favorite New York teams to be answered in an upcoming mailbag
But depth is still an issue made worse already by the loss of Syndergaard. If teams are going to need to play more games in an abbreviated period
column2: depth is going to be more vital than ever
column3: and depth is not a Mets stength.

column1: One way to create depth if there is a partial 2020 season is to capitalize on an unfortunate situation — that many teams bereft of revenue might have to move contracts even for middling return. But does anyone see the Mets adding to their payroll? Whenever I ask officials around the sport which teams are in the worst financial situation
column2: the Mets routinely come up because they have so much debt and already were going to lose a lot trying to win in 2020. Now
column3: also the value of a franchise the Wilpons are trying to sell may be plummeting.

column1: Might the Wilpons feel with Steve Cohen
column2: like the Cubs with Bryant and Contreras
column3: that their best chance to receive the most for assets — in this case a franchise — came and went in the offseason?

column1: What could financial distress mean for the near future? The Mets can get out of walk-year players such as Stroman
column2: Yoenis Cespedes
column3: Jed Lowrie
column4: Wilson Ramos
column5: Justin Wilson and even any non-insurance payments to David Wright after 2020. But will the lack of revenues this year (even with a partial season
column6: and especially with none) force the Mets to take their 2021 payroll down toward $100 million (or less)?

column1: As one personnel head said
column2: “Their track record is not wanting to spend even in good times.” In which case
column3: can they even make a qualifying offer (roughly $18 million) to Stroman? Would they even tender a contract to Syndergaard (about $10 million) if they thought they were only going to get
column4: say
column5: 15-18 starts from him next year and could not trade him for much more than 25 cents on the dollar?"

column1: Johnson

2068	New York Post	1117948	Virginia Backaitis	Four important lessons for working from home	"Welcome to the new world of working from home. Sure
column2: there’s no commute
column3: but there’s also no barista
column4: no going out for lunch
column5: no reason to get dressed up. What we’re discovering is that it can be awkward
column6: but also full of heart and
column7: sometimes
column8: even funny.

column1: Lesson 1: Juggling kids and work has never been trickier
Consider what “shelter in place” looks like for 35-year-old Erin Butler and her family in Ho-Ho-Kus
column2: NJ. Butler has climbed the rungs of Citrix’s corporate ladder for the past 14 years
column3: so handling her responsibilities shouldn’t be a problem
column4: even if it’s really busy. (Citrix provides remote digital workspaces
column5: among other things.)

column1: But add a 2- and a 5-year-old
column2: minus the grandparents
column3: who usually help out but are isolating
column4: and you find Butler and her husband waking up to discuss coordinating conference- call schedules as well as creating timetables for feeding
column5: nurturing and entertaining their kids.

column1: When neither is available
column2: they pull out the Little Tikes bounce house. “It can keep them busy for quite a while
column3: ” Butler says. Desperate times call for desperate measures.”

column1: With both of them home 24/7
column2: Butler also decided now was a good time to potty train their almost 3-year-old son. His desire to make a big-boy poop came while Dad was on an important call and Mom was in a virtual conference. “What could I do? I hit mute and took him to the bathroom. Thank God I didn’t have the video on
column3: ” she says.

column1: Lesson 2: The video conference call is a minefield

One enterprising software salesman would tell us his work-from-home story only if we agreed not to use his real name. The 41-year-old was on a Zoom video call when his partner ran buck naked from the shower to the bedroom. “I was the one speaking. All eyes were on me. There’s no way that my boss and team didn’t notice the nudity
column2: ” he says.

column1: But “Jones” went on with the call as if nothing had happened
column2: which is exactly the right thing to do
column3: says etiquette coach Maggie Adams.

column1: “There’s no need to put others in an awkward situation
column2: ” she says.

column1: Life coach Marie Singer
column2: from Florham Park
column3: NJ
column4: says there’s no need to get too upset about something like this. “Everyone is working from home and staying in place; it is an unnatural situation
column5: ” she says. “All kinds of unusual and unpredictable things are going to happen.”

column1: Suzy Shugg
column2: CEO of Teleplus Healthcare and clinical lipid specialist at NJ Cardiology Associates
column3: discovered this to be true while working from home and caring for her husband
column4: who had COVID-19.

column1: Shugg had taken one of the few gaps in her schedule to jump into the shower before a conference call that she believed was audio-only. When she joined it half-dressed and looked at her computer screen
column2: she was shocked — the camera was on and pointed at her crotch.

column1: “There was the lower half of my body covered only by bright pink underwear
column2: ” she says. She grabbed a blanket
column3: adjusted the camera and rejoined the conversation as if nothing had happened. Although at first she was alarmed
column4: “I now think it’s funny
column5: ” says Shugg. “There’s other stuff going on if you want to get upset.”

column1: And no
column2: the answer isn’t to turn off the camera for group calls — it implies that you’re doing something else and don’t think the others on the call are worth your undivided attention
column3: says Adams.

column1: Lesson 3: Finding your own space is key
Lynn Smith
column2: anchor of CNN’s 10 a.m. program “On the Story
column3: ” always thought that working from home in her profession was impossible. The pandemic has proven her wrong. Now she is doing her show from her home’s “basement bureau” via her phone and some bright lights.

column1: On weekday mornings
column2: just before 8:50 a.m.
column3: Smith tells her 4-year-old son that it’s time to go outside for recess (or to the garage if it’s inclement weather) before she starts work. Her husband or their au pair watches him and their other 1-year-old son while they play.

column1: “Sometimes they send me texts while I’m doing the show
column2: asking if they can come in the house yet
column3: ” says Smith.

column1: She spends time with the boys after the show
column2: but before retreating to her closet to make phone calls
column3: interview and write scripts for the next day. “It’s the only place in the house that is quiet
column4: ” she says.

column1: There is an upside
column2: though. “Usually
column3: I leave the house around 4 a.m.
column4: ” she says. “Now I’m here when everyone wakes up. It’s nice.”

column1: Charly Rok
column2: a vice president at Edelman
column3: takes it all in stride. She’s been answering phone calls while sitting on the bathroom floor or in her building’s stairwell. “My husband and I both have loud voices
column4: and we live in a loft
column5: ” she says.

column1: Lesson 4: You need to have a bit of give and take
Some space-sharers have created an imaginary co-worker to blame things on. Why fight with your roommate or significant other about empty coffee pots
column2: dirty mugs left in the sink or the printer being out of ink when you can blame Jim
column3: that lazy old slug?

column1: And sometimes
column2: the rest of the household needs some downtime regardless of your schedule. Jennifer Barish
column3: an office manager at Woodbury
column4: NY-based small business loan provider Lendio
column5: now works from her aunt and uncle’s kitchen table in Lindenhurst
column6: NY.

column1: On March 26
column2: her uncle and cousin spent the afternoon in the living room celebrating baseball’s opening day — taped from a previous year
column3: that is — complete with Mets jerseys
column4: hot dogs and general ballpark revelry.

column1: “I love baseball
column2: ” she says
column3: reckoning her employer would understand even if her full attention wasn’t on her work.

column1: Says Singer: “For now
column2: we all have to be flexible.”"

Late last year — long before most people had heard of the new coronavirus now sweeping the globe — scientists in Germany jumped into action to develop a test for the virus that originated in China.
They had one by mid-January — and labs around the country were ready to start using it just weeks later
column2: around the same time that Europe’s most populous country registered its first case.

column1: “It was clear that if the epidemic swept over here from China

column3: ” said Hendrik Borucki

column1: That quick work stood in stark contrast to delays and missteps in some other countries. “The reason why we in Germany have so few deaths at the moment compared to the number of infected can be largely explained by the fact that we are doing an extremely large number of lab diagnoses
column2: ” said virologist Dr. Christian Drosten
column3: whose team developed the first test for the new virus at Berlin’s Charité hospital — established over 300 years ago to treat plague victims.

column4: which is about $2.8b in revenue
column5: where it has a strong upstream portfolio with its cell culture media and single-use bioreactor offering. It also has a leadership position in downstream bioprocessing
column6: driven by its chromatography resins and hardware portfolio. Its protein A resin is widely adopted in almost all the leading monoclonal antibodies globally. Cytiva’s product was used in more than 75% of all biopharmaceuticals approved by the FDA in2019.

column1: The business also provides end-to-end bioprocess solutions via its Enterprise Solution where its KUBio prefabricated manufacturing facility and configurable FlexFactory bioprocessing platform to reduce the time taken for companies to build a new facility from scratch. This has allowed them to penetrate the increasingly lucrative Chinese market
column2: which is growing at an unprecedented pace. Notable clients include Lonza
column3: BeiGene (BGNE) and Pfizer (PFE). While being strong in both upstream and downstream bioprocessing
column4: Cytiva has almost no presence in the filtration space. Danaher has traditionally been operating in the filtration space with the acquisition of Pall which should complement Cytiva’s portfolio in the bioprocess space very nicely.

column1: The cell and gene therapy space has grown exponentially with the landmark approvals of several innovative therapies to cure previously incurable diseases. Cytiva have also managed to capitalize on the growth
column2: particularly in cell therapies where the business offer end-to-end solution to automate the manufacturing of cell therapies
column3: which is a critical part of successful cell therapies. Both Novartis (NVS) and Gilead Sciences (GILD) have adopted Cytiva’s solution to manufacture their approved CAR-Ts. Cytiva has also expanded its Enterprise Solution to the cell therapy space as well. Similarly
column4: Danaher’s Pall complements nicely in the gene therapy space
column5: where Cytiva’s offering is less complete.

column1: Lastly
column2: Cytiva’s genomics and cellular research should be complementary to the rest of Danaher’s life sciences platform where they serve biology researches. An example is how it is enabling the rapid diagnostics of the COVID-19.

column1: At the time of announcement of the deal
column2: GE Biopharma was expected to deliver 6-7% core revenue growth. In its Q4 earnings call
column3: Danaher acknowledged that the business had actually outperformed expectations in 2019. While the company still does not have enough visibility to raise 2020’s guidance
column4: the strong performance clearly outlined the underlying strength of the business.

column1: Furthermore
column2: the biopharmaceuticals and cell and gene therapy markets
column3: which are key markets that Cytiva sells to
column4: are both expected to grow in the coming years. As mentioned earlier
column5: Cytiva complements Danaher’s existing life sciences segment very nicely and the acquisition should help create more synergy to the end markets.

column1: Cytiva’s key competitors including Thermo Fisher (TMO)
column2: Sartorius
column3: MilliporeSigma and Danaher’s Pall all reported very strong results and outlook recently. This clearly shows that the end market is strong with a favorable tailwind.

column1: Lastly
column2: the deal was completed at approximately 17x of EBITDA
column3: which compares favorably to other deals conducted by competitors. For instance
column4: Danaher’s acquisition of Pall was completed at 22x of EBITDA and Thermo Fisher’s acquisition of Qiagen is expected to be at around 19x of EBITDA.

column1: Danaher has always been a well-run company that has consistently delivered outstanding long-term shareholders returns. With the Danaher Business System as their playbook
column2: the company has an excellent track record in improving the operations and performance of companies they acquired. Cytiva offers an avenue for Danaher to double down on life sciences
column3: with its high recurring revenue and margin meaning that it is already outperforming the other operating companies within Danaher.

column1: Cytiva also adds a complementary portfolio which adds synergy and gives Danaher access to key markets. On a macro level
column2: the biopharmaceuticals and cell and gene therapy are expected to grow
column3: and its key competitors have also reported strong results and outlook recently. While the COVID-19 pandemic has caused supply chain disruptions globally
column4: there should not be a demand issue moving forward given that Danaher’s offerings are used to make innovative and life-saving therapies across several modalities. In summary
column5: I believe that the acquisition of Cytiva is a big positive for Danaher. Coupled with the company’s track record in outperforming the market
column6: I would rate Danaher a buy.

column2: investors should conduct their own due diligence and consider their risk appetites and time horizon before taking up any position. This is especially so
column3: given the recent market turmoil resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Gig companies have started offering benefits like paid sick leave now that workers are on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic
column2: and some are getting sick.

column1: Gene J. Puskar/AP
April McGhee and her teenage daughter started feeling sick last month. They had coughs
column2: sore throats and fevers. Her daughter's condition became so bad that they went to the emergency room.

column1: ""She had it worse than I did

column3: nonproductive
column4: hacking cough.""

column1: McGhee
column2: who lives in Sacramento

column4: they went home and into isolation.

column1: A single mom
column2: McGhee makes ends meet by delivering groceries for Instacart and meals for Postmates. She contacted Instacart to apply for sick pay under a policy the company recently put in place because of the pandemic.

column1: ""They basically laughed me off
column2: McGhee said. ""They said
column3: 'Unless you have the health department or [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention] making you stay home on quarantine
column4: or a note from the doctor saying that you've been diagnosed with COVID-19
column5: you're out of luck.'""

column1: Gig companies like Instacart
column2: Uber and Lyft connect people who need tasks done with workers willing to do them. But the companies consider these workers independent contractors
column3: not employees. The firms generally do not provide paid sick leave or other employee benefits.

column1: Now
column2: however
column3: that's changing. The nature of the work that Instacart shoppers
column4: Uber and Lyft drivers and other gig workers do puts them in close contact with strangers. They are
column5: in essence
column6: on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic
column7: and some of them are getting sick.

column1: McGhee joined other Instacart workers who walked off the job Monday to demand better safety measures. She says the company's policy not only puts her at risk

column3: potentially
column4: spread the disease.

column1: She said the company should keep its workers healthy ""as a buffer zone instead of as a Typhoid Mary.""

column2: including masks
column3: hand sanitizer and thermometers
column4: to workers beginning this week.

column1: Workers for other gig companies are also running into hurdles getting the help they've been promised.

column1: He showed the letter to both companies to receive sick pay. He hoped it would cover the loss of the roughly $1
column3: 500 he says he typically makes per week. He got $250 from Lyft.

column1: Uber initially rejected his claim

column3: 400 claims to U.S. drivers in less than three weeks.

column3: 700 from Uber to cover the two weeks of work he's missed.

column1: That's money he sorely needs.
""To be honest
column2: right now
column3: I'm very broke
column4: Diop said.

column1: Uber does not require drivers to get tested for the coronavirus to get paid leave. They can show a doctor's note telling them to isolate themselves to prevent the virus from spreading.
But Uber's policy does not cover drivers who choose not to work because they're afraid of getting sick.
""I have bad lungs already. I'm borderline diabetic. I have high blood pressure
column2: said Steve Gregg
column3: an Uber driver in the Bay Area who stopped driving about three weeks ago. ""Getting in that car felt like Russian roulette.""

column1: Gregg got a note from his doctor explaining his preexisting conditions
column2: but Uber denied his claim.

column1: Editor's note: Lyft and Uber are among NPR's sponsors."

column1: Anti-money laundering laws are designed to make it difficult for terrorists and criminals to move money around.
The FMA is responsible for monitoring around 800 businesses for anti-money laundering processes under the Anti-Money Laundering and Countering Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT) Act.
The FMA said Tiger Brokers had failed to properly identify clients
column2: including checking relevant customer identification documents.

column1: It had also failed to check where clients' wealth came from
column2: or as it put it failed to ""obtain adequate source of fund or wealth information relating to high risk customers
column3: and take reasonable steps to verify that information"".

column1: And
column2: it had failed to take reasonable steps to determine whether a customer or any beneficial owner
column3: was a ""politically exposed person"".

column1: Tiger Brokers had also failed to report suspicious activity to the relevant authorities within three working days after forming a suspicion.
The FMA concluded there were reasonable grounds to believe Tiger Brokers had contravened the Anti-Money Laundering and Countering Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT) Act.
Tiger Brokers has been ordered to prepare and submit a plan to the FMA before April 17 describing how and when it would address the issues.
It must then complete these actions by 30 September 2020 or it will face enforcement action
column2: said James Greig
column3: head of supervision at the FMA.

column1: Warnings are an important regulatory tool for the FMA because they can force faster change than court proceedings. In these cases
column2: formal warnings were the most proportionate response to the conduct by the firms in question.

column1: A public warning is designed to send a signal that we have issues with a company
column2: and they need to address the concerns we have raised
column3: he said.

column1: The severity of Tiger Brokers' likely breaches meant that a public warning was necessary
column2: especially because it is a large business that is growing fast in New Zealand.

column1: The issues were wide ranging and weren't minor or technical
column2: meaning there was potential for immediate and ongoing damage to the integrity of our financial markets.""

column1: The anti-money laundering legislation has been in effect for some time now
column2: so we expect businesses to be aware of their obligations and why it is important to the integrity of New Zealand's financial system.""

column1: While the industry is grappling with the impacts of Covid-19
column2: anti-money laundering is a high-risk issue so we are continuing to actively monitor for non-compliance and take enforcement action.

column1: Greig said: ""We decided not to name the other six businesses after considering the proportionate regulatory response. All of these firms in breach were either small businesses or individuals
column2: and they are cooperating with the FMA and taking steps to become compliant.""

column1: Many of the private warnings relate to independent audits of anti-money laundering systems. These audits are essential because they help to ensure businesses have robust systems and processes to detect and deter money laundering. A guidance document on the auditing of risk assessments was issued last year so there is now no excuse for non-compliance.""
The FMA conducts cyclical reviews of the roughly 800 entities it supervises for anti-money laundering. In 2019
column2: the FMA analysed the AML audit reports of 49 businesses. The regulator also performs on-site monitoring visits.

column1: He said the warnings
column2: issued under section 80 of the AML/CFT Act
column3: did not suggest the businesses had allowed or enabled illegal activity to take place."

column1: 1099	Irish Times	1032255	Paul Cullen	Ireland has struggled to protect nursing homes from Covid-19	"Ireland has got many things rights in tackling the coronavirus pandemic but the handling of nursing homes is not one of them.
In less than 10 days
column2: the number of outbreaks in public and private nursing homes has gone from four to 50. That number jumped by 10 in a single day over the weekend
column3: indicating we have some way to go before the disease is brought under control in this kind of residential setting.

column1: This was not without warning. Concerns about the potentially devastating impact of a Covid-19 outbreak in a nursing home were already being flagged at the start of March
column2: when just that had happened in Seattle in the US
column3: leading to multiple deaths.

column1: One of the first cases of the disease
column2: again at the start of March
column3: involved a GP in the west who had worked in a nursing home as well as other healthcare settings before he was diagnosed. It appears this case did not lead to an outbreak in the nursing home in question
column4: but here was a pattern – of key workers moving around different healthcare settings – that perhaps should have been noted more.

column1: Nursing Homes Ireland (NHI) responded to the growing crisis on March 4th by imposing nationwide visiting restrictions on private facilities.
On March 10th
column2: chief medical officer Dr Tony Holohan said the blanket restrictions should be lifted because they were premature and impacted on residents’ social interactions.

column1: That stance seems extraordinary now
column2: with the benefit of hindsight
column3: but the National Public Health Emergency Team (NPHET) was anxious not to impose restrictions too soon. Perhaps it
column4: along with the rest of us back then
column5: may not have seen things getting so bad so quickly.

column1: Three days later
column2: on March 13th
column3: the visiting ban was imposed
column4: or re-imposed
column5: as part of a package of restrictive measures recommended by NPHET to Government.

column1: It has been clear from the start of the year that Covid-19 affects the old
column2: and the frail
column3: disproportionately. Residents of nursing homes
column4: and of other care centres
column5: were always liable to be at greater risk of dying.

column1: Yet despite a plethora of new guidelines being developed for the emerging situation
column2: none was specific to the nursing home sector.

column1: On March 25th
column2: when there were only a handful of clusters of Covid-19 in homes
column3: NHI complained that it had made numerous representations to Minister for Health Simon Harris and his officials
column4: but no offer of a meeting had been forthcoming.

column1: NHI appealed for “specific guidance” for what nursing homes should do in the crisis and predicted homes would experience severe staff shortages when staff were most needed.
Asked about the issue of guidance last Friday
column2: Dr Holohan said there were “extensive arrangements” in place across the sector and infection control guidelines for healthcare settings “that should have been applied” in nursing homes.

column1: But
column2: he acknowledged
column3: there is a “wide variation” in standards in nursing homes
column4: which are monitored by the Health Information and Quality Authority. “Some have very high standards and continue to be very safe [while] other places are not quite of that standard. We have to raise the standard of the entire sector.”

column1: It is understandable much of the focus in this epidemic has been on the potential devastation a surge of cases might wreak on hospitals and
column2: in particular
column3: intensive care units.

column1: However
column2: the problem with the one-size-fits-all approach
column3: including the lack of specific guidance for nursing homes (and other care centres
column4: and home care providers) is that it ignores the different environment and culture applying in these sectors.

column1: Typically
column2: staff are paid less and receive less training than their equivalents in hospitals. Staff in these Cinderella sectors are hard to come by and many supplied by locum agencies work across different locations. They may be renting accommodation
column3: sometimes cramped
column4: with other care staff working in other locations; more factors that help the virus spread.

column1: The Government is now recommending the cocooning of all over-70s
column2: who are being advised to remain at home. It is ironic
column3: therefore
column4: that a safe environment is not being offered to the most vulnerable of this age group who are residing in nursing homes where outbreaks have occurred.

column1: It is welcome the problem has been recognised
column2: even if belatedly. The package of measures agreed at the weekend should ensure the chains of transmission in nursing homes are broken. Key to this will be the implementation of proper infection control among staff; after all the residents themselves
column3: who are unlikely to be hospitalised even if they fall ill
column4: have few choices."

column1: 1099	Irish Times	1046443	Pat Leahy	Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael to put pressure back on smaller parties	"Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael will seek to put the focus back on the smaller parties this week

column1: The question of membership approval – necessary under Fianna Fail’s rules for any participation in government – also raises the issue of how such approval might be obtained.

column4: as one admitted this weekend: “Nobody has any idea how it might work.”

column1: The final results of the Seanad election confirmed that the two parties will have a majority in the upper house if they form a government.

column3: down from 14 in the last Seanad. A Government requires a minimum of 31 for a majority in the 60-seat Upper House

column5: giving the two parties a comfortable majority."

323	BBC UK	941341	Bbc News	The most famous letter in Scottish history?	"Image caption
The only surviving copy is carefully preserved by the National Records of Scotland
The Declaration of Arbroath is seen by many as one of the most famous documents in Scottish history.
It was written on 6 April 1320 but its words continue to inspire some in the Scottish independence movement
column2: 700 years later.

column1: Its broader message is a call for the right of Scots to rule themselves - but some claim its significance has been overstated and its purpose was simply to shore up the reign of King Robert the Bruce.
What was the Declaration of Arbroath?
Image caption
It is thought the letter was written at Arbroath Abbey
First of all it was not really a declaration and did not get that name until much later.
It was a private missive to Pope John
column2: which was endorsed by 39 of the most-powerful Scottish barons and earls
column3: who supported Bruce as king.

column1: They were appealing for help to end the wars of independence with England which had been going on for decades.
Bruce had struck a blow to settle Scotland's independence in 1314 at the Battle of Bannockburn but there was no truce between the two nations and the disputes raged.
What does it say?
BBC
It is in truth not for glory
column2: nor riches
column3: nor honours that we are fighting
column4: but for freedom
column5: for that alone
column6: which no honest man gives up but with life itself.

column1: The most often quoted line from the declaration
column2: which was originally written in Latin
column3: is a statement of Scottish independence.

column1: For
column2: as long as 100 of us remain alive
column3: never will we on any conditions be subjected to the lordship of the English
column4: it says.

column1: It is in truth not for glory
column2: nor riches
column3: nor honours that we are fighting
column4: but for freedom
column5: for that alone
column6: which no honest man gives up but with life itself.""

column1: The only surviving copy is a fragile sheepskin parchment
column2: carefully preserved by the National Records of Scotland.

column1: Dr Alice Blackwell
column2: senior curator of medieval archaeology and history at the National Museums Scotland
column3: says the letter starts out with the names of all the barons who support it.

column1: The main text
column2: which is only about 800 words
column3: opens by asserting Scotland's long history as an independent kingdom and talks about the ""countless evils"" perpetrated by English kings and the heroics of Robert the Bruce.

column1: It ends really powerfully with a plea to the Pope
column2: Dr Blackwell says. ""It essentially threatens the Pope and says that if he doesn't help intervene
column3: blood will be on his hands.""

column1: Why write to the Pope?
Image caption
Robert the Bruce was king of Scotland until his death in 1329
The barons hoped the Pope
column2: as the head of Western Christendom
column3: could put pressure of King Edward II of England to achieve peace.

column1: It was also a subtle diplomatic attempt to get the Pope
column2: who had clashed with Robert Bruce on a number of issues
column3: to recognise him as the legitimate king of Scotland.

column1: Pope John was no friend of King Robert
column2: a man who had murdered a rival claimant to the throne in a church and had ignored Papal decrees. In fact the Pope was seeking to enforce his excommunication.

column1: The letter was an appeal from the nobles to lift the excommunication and recognise Robert I as the rightful king.
Was it forgotten for centuries?
Image caption
The declaration still contains many of the wax seals of the barons who signed it
The significance of the Declaration of Arbroath to Scottish history is much discussed and disputed.
Dr Alan Borthwick
column2: National Record of Scotland's head of medieval and early modern records
column3: says there is very little record of it in the sources from around the time it was written and the major historians of the 16th Century make no reference to it.

column1: It was only in the 1680s when the text was printed in Latin
column2: and then it was it was later translated into English thereafter
column3: that people began to think this was a really important document
column4: he says.

column1: Robert Crawford
column2: professor of Modern Scottish Literature
column3: at the University of St Andrews told BBC Radio's Freethinking that the declaration lay in Edinburgh Castle for several centuries.

column1: It was nibbled by rats. It was not translated into English until the late 17th Century. It is in one sense a very obscure piece of medieval letter-writing
column2: he says.

column1: In another sense
column2: like all the classiest pieces of medieval sheepskin it has its own Wikipedia page and in our day it has become internationally known.""

column1: Did it inspire the US Declaration of Independence?
Image copyright
Trent Lott
Image caption
Senator Trent Lott maintains that the Scottish document inspired the writers of the US Declaration of Independence

The Scottish document pre-dates the United States revolution by about 450 years but some - such as former Senate majority leader Trent Lott - are convinced it inspired the American Declaration of Independence
column2: despite a lack of historical evidence.

column1: The annual Tartan Day celebrations in America - founded by Senator Lott in 1998 - take place on 6 April because that is the anniversary of the Declaration of Arbroath.
Mr Lott told BBC Scotland: ""I have no doubt they had read the declaration
column2: some people say that there is no connection
column3: but I say 'just read them and then tell me there is not a connection'.

column1: There is too much of the same verbiage and the same passion and the same reasons for these declarations.""
Dr Borthwick says scholars still debate at great length whether there is any genuine connection between the Arbroath declaration and the American declaration.
He says the Arbroath document probably only began being called a declaration in the late 19th or early 20th Century
column2: and then probably because of the US Declaration of Independence.

column1: The right to topple kings
Image caption
Tartan Day in New York mark the anniversary of the Declaration of Arbroath
The Arbroath letter praises King Robert for setting the Scots free and accepts that he has the right to be king.
But it warns that if he should change course and seek to make Scotland subject to England then they would ""drive him out as our enemy"".
Dr Borthwick says the current thinking among scholars is that this does not necessarily refer to the overthrowing Robert Bruce but to any successor such as Edward Balliol
column2: who was supported by Edward II.

column1: He says: ""There are many documents from the medieval period which attempt to impose some form of restriction on monarchical powers but this is very unusual
column2: if not unique
column3: in saying the king could be deposed.

column1: There is quite a difference there and they have taken it quite a step further.""
Was the declaration successful?
Dr Borthwick says the declaration had a small degree of success at the time but did not achieve its full aim.

He says the response from the Pope still did not describe Bruce as king of Scotland but he did write to Edward II of England and there was a clear steer from the Pope that he wanted a truce to be made.
However
column2: it was eight years before a peace treaty was agreed
column3: just months before Bruce died.

column1: How is the anniversary being celebrated?

There had been plans for an Arbroath 2020 festival and the document was to be put on public display for the first time in 15 years at National Museum of Scotland but both events have been shelved due to coronavirus.
Many celebrations have been rescheduled for next year so that the Declaration's 701st birthday is likely to be the big one."

The program authorizes up to $349 billion in loans through the Small Business Administration as part of the Coronavirus Aid
column2: Relief
column3: and Economic Security Act — or CARES Act — signed into law a week ago. It's designed to give small businesses quick funding to mostly cover payroll

column5: for eight weeks after a loan is made. The loan will be forgiven if businesses maintain employee pay
column6: according to a PPP fact sheet. Loan payments will be deferred for six months.

column1: But the SBA and U.S. Treasury didn't release final guidelines until Thursday evening – hours before the program was scheduled to go live.

NewDominion Bank CEO Blaine Jackson was one of many bankers who stayed up late studying the guidelines as soon as they were released. Phone calls and emails started early Friday morning. Most his of schedule on Friday was booked with conference calls.
Charlotte-based NewDominion is a subsidiary of Ohio-based Park National Corp. Jackson said the bank won't start processing the PPP loans until Monday at the earliest. It is
column2: however
column3: accepting applications in advance.

column3: CEO of the N.C. Bankers Association. The last-minute guidelines leave much unanswered as banks rush to set up internal processes. Some banks are still waiting on SBA credentials. That has to happen before lenders have access to the online program to process applications
column4: he said.

column1: Bankers spent all night reading
column2: working on their systems
column3: preparing their people for the unprecedented demand for this

column1: The federal government designed the program to roll out first through the SBA's preferred lenders

column3: 700 preferred lenders

column5: 100 total in the U.S.
column6: he noted. More banks

column1: Stan Lamb
column2: financial adviser at Pinnacle Financial Partners Inc. (NASDAQ: PNFP)
column3: said he hasn't seen anything like this in his 20-plus years in the business.

column1: Setting up for the PPP process has been a top-down approach at Pinnacle. The director of Pinnacle's SBA group is working directly with the chief operating officer

column3: he said
column4: but officials have alleviated some of the red tape to get the PPP loans out as quickly as possible.

column1: You're trying to roll out a program at lightning speed
column2: Lamb said. ""Everybody wants to get their piece of the pie ... of what's available for their business to help them through this because everybody's struggling. Everybody's hurting right now
column3: and they want to get in as soon as it's available.""

column1: Pinnacle was ready to accept applications on Friday morning. Spokesperson Joe Bass said the bank has seen a steady stream of applications coming in since Thursday night.
The SBA approved Gov. Roy Cooper's disaster declaration request earlier this month
column2: allowing North Carolina's small businesses to apply for low-interest economic injury disaster loans. Lamb believes the SBA created the PPP because its disaster loans are not necessarily built for nationwide crises.

column1: Jim Engel
column2: CEO of Aquesta Financial Holdings Inc.
column3: based in Cornelius north of Charlotte
column4: said the bank's loan volume is ""massive"" compared to a normal time. Aquesta had about 120 PPP loans in progress as of Friday afternoon.

column2: including medical offices
column3: he said.

column1: On Thursday
column2: Engel expressed his concern about the PPP's chosen 0.5 percent interest rate. He was hoping to break even on borrowing costs – saying it was ""not going to be a big moneymaker."" The federal government has since hiked the interest rate to 1 percent. That decision came after many banks raised questions on the previous rate.

column1: Jackson declined to share details on NewDominion clients' interest thus far

column1: For him
column2: important questions remain: How will the loan be forgiven? How does the bank ensure the money is used for eligible purposes? Does the six-month deferral apply to principal and interest?

column1: Questions may not be answered for days or weeks

column3: mostly from community banks
column4: according to a tweet from Secretary of the Treasury Steven Mnuchin. Some of the large banks had not yet submitted numbers
column5: he wrote.

column1: Charlotte's Bank of America Corp. (NYSE: BAC) was the first big bank to launch its PPP loan portal on Friday morning. The system prioritizes BofA's 1 million borrowing customers

column1: Wells Fargo  Co. (NYSE: WFC) is still working to launch its PPP portal. On Friday
