column1: 29	BBC	1038477	Sean Coughlan	Families in lockdown feel the psychological tension	"Image copyright
Getty Images
Image caption
Families are having to adjust to spending much more time together
We may never forget the coronavirus lockdown. But are we still going to be talking to each other at the end of it?
Because apart from worries about the virus
column2: there are likely to be rising tensions in some families having to live on top of one another at home.

column1: In ordinary times
column2: couples spend on average two-and-a-half hours together each day
column3: says researcher into relationships Prof Jacqui Gabb of the Open University.

column1: But that was in the BC era (before coronavirus)
column2: and now we can spend 15 or 16 of our waking hours together. And throw into that combustible mix
column3: children who are out of school.

column1: Image caption
Exercise is recommended as a way of reducing stress levels
Is it going to leave us seething with irritability or bring us serenely closer than ever before?
We've never lived through something like this
column2: says Prof Gabb.

column1: Most of the usual emotional pressure-cooker points - like being cooped up together at Christmas or going on a family holiday - have clearly defined exit points.
Image copyright
EPA
Image caption
Everyone seems to have found a dog to walk
But not with the coronavirus lockdown.
There are no certainties any more
column2: she says.

column1: But there are all the ingredients for stress on relationships
column2: she says.

column1: There are worries about jobs and money
column2: not enough personal space
column3: lack of childcare
column4: not being able to do the things you enjoy
column5: not seeing friends and the anxieties caused by the virus outbreak.

column1: The parent
I am a single parent who is a key worker. I can work from home but am finding it impossible with my six and 10-year-old at home. Work have said I can drop my hours
column2: but will lose the pay which I can't afford. My son has immune difficulties so cannot send him to school and we live with my 84-year-old mother. Feel really stuck!"" Shelley-Ann on workingmums.co.uk

column1: Lack of freedoms will be felt differently
column2: says Dr Caroline Schuster
column3: a psychologist who has worked with families in Dorset and Wiltshire.

column1: She says people might be feeling a ""lack of privacy
column2: boredom and isolation
column3: even in a family"".

column1: For all of us
column2: kids included
column3: there is a loss of the old way of life.""

column1: Both experts say they expect an increase in domestic violence from the lockdown.
We've also entered a strange new digital existence
column2: with many working and socialising online.

column1: But Prof Gabb warns that self-broadcasting on social media during the lockdown can put even more psychological pressure on families. Particularly if the smugness levels get too high.
Not everyone is at home in their giant kitchen. Other people are struggling to feed their kids and are going stir-crazy
column2: she says.

column1: The teenager
My parents are so annoying. I'll come downstairs and say
column2: 'Good morning'
column3: and they'll reply
column4: 'Good AFTERNOON'. It's like
column5: OK
column6: I'm a bum
column7: I get it."" From ""annoying parents"" on Twitter.

column1: The story of the lockdown is being seen through the eyes of the haves
column2: rather than the have-nots
column3: says Prof Gabb.

column1: It's not as easy as just put on an exercise video and bond with each other
column2: she says.

column1: Her concerns are echoed by research from Save the Children
column2: with the charity finding the biggest worries for parents in the lockdown are getting enough food
column3: helping children with schoolwork and concerns about money.

column1: Children are worried about someone in their family getting sick
column2: food shortages and not seeing friends.

column1: The loss of control over much of our everyday lives is stoking the domestic tensions. For adults used to being independent ""it's quite infantilising""
column2: says Prof Gabb.

column1: A sense of control is incredibly important for humans
column2: says Dr Punit Shah
column3: a psychologist at the University of Bath.

column1: Image copyright
Getty Images
Image caption
Family holidays might be tense but we know when they are going to end
When we feel we have no control we feel stressed - and he says there are all kinds of ""coping mechanisms"" appearing.
People might take a sudden interest in exercise
column2: or focus on cleaning their house or working on the garden
column3: giving them a sense of control over something.

column1: The head teacher
It is absolutely not possible to facilitate distance-learning with a primary-aged child and work from home at the same time. The very idea is nonsense. If you're trying to do that
column2: stop now. You can certainly have activities where your child learns
column3: but your focus is your job
column4: and survival. Stop trying to be superheroes."" Joseph Hellett to parents in Hastings.

column1: But Dr Shah says we should be more upbeat about what might emerge from this enforced confinement - and to ""give ourselves more credit"" for how we're adapting.
There could be an ""identity shift"" within families
column2: as parents and children get to know each other better
column3: says the psychologist.

column1: We shouldn't assume it will be negative and problematic
column2: he says.

column1: Image caption
How will generations brought together get on during a lockdown?
Dr Shah says we're still finding out during this experience what helps us feel better.
It might be a case of fear and clothing in the lockdown.
Because in his case
column2: Dr Shah says he feels more comfortable wearing smart working clothes when he is working from home
column3: even if it surprises everyone else on the video conference.

column1: One of the most visible tactics for stress-busting seems to be the family pet. When you go outside everyone who isn't jogging seems to be walking a dog.
There are really positive benefits
column2: says Prof Gabb. Pets are particularly important for people living on their own
column3: a group she thinks are not being adequately acknowledged during the lockdown.

column1: Image copyright
Getty Images
Image caption
All that energy is now in lockdown inside the home
Walking a dog might also make people feel more justified in being outside - and Dr Shah says our behaviour is being heavily influenced by ""social pressure"".
This includes parents feeling made to feel guilty about not having turned overnight into an accomplished teacher for their stay-at-home children.
But there are soothing words for anyone already suffering from laptop neck or Zoom ache.
A primary school head teacher in Hastings sent a message telling parents ""not to stress or feel guilty"" during these strange weeks.
Stop trying to be superheroes
column2: he told them."

column1: 645	New Zealand Herald	945097	Newsfeeds@nzherald.co.nz	Covid-19 coronavirus: Boris Johnson to stay in hospital 'for as long as needed'	"British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is expected to spend the night in hospital after being admitted for precautionary coronavirus tests.
He was taken in earlier in the evening local time
column2: but he is still leading the Government response on Covid-19.

column1: Johnson is understood to be in a National Health Service hospital in London where he will stay for ""as long as needed"".
Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab is likely to chair the daily Covid-19 meeting tonight NZT for ministers and officials
column2: which is usually led by the PM.

column1: Keir Starmer
column2: the newly elected leader of the Labour Party said: ""Wishing the Prime Minister well and a speedy recovery.""

column1: Nicola Sturgeon
column2: Scottish First Minister said: ""Wishing the PM all the best and a speedy recovery.""

column1: And Sadiq Khan
column2: Mayor of London
column3: said: ""Sending my very best to the Prime Minister and wishing him a swift recovery.""

column1: GP Dr Sarah Jarvis told the BBC it is likely the Prime Minister has ""moderate"" symptoms of coronavirus.
""The majority of people who develop coronavirus will have mild symptoms - that's probably 80 per cent or so
column2: she said. ""The older you become the more likely it is that you will become severely unwell with this.

column1: ""There is a severe stage
column2: a moderate stage and a critical stage.""

column1: Jarvis
column2: who is not Johnson's doctor
column3: added:

column1: ""Given he is staying in charge of the Government
column2: that suggests to me that he probably has moderate disease but that
column3: as a precaution
column4: he is being taken in to check the oxygen levels in his blood
column5: to do X-rays and probably scans of his chest.

column1: ""And to do blood tests to see for instance what his white cell counts look like and what his liver functions look like.""
Jarvis said of Boris Johnson's hospital admission: ""The main focus is going to be on his lungs.
""The majority of people are going to progress to have inflammation of the lungs and that inflammation can result in damage to lung tissue
column2: but also importantly can prevent oxygen being transferred into the blood stream.""

column1: She said the tests themselves are very rapid.
""You can clamp a monitor on to somebody's finger and that will give you a test very quickly
column2: in fact in general practice we have systems set up where people who have been discharged from hospital are having those tests delivered to them and they just pop the monitor on to their finger and literally within 30 seconds it will give a result.

column1: ""The X-ray will take a little longer and the scan will need to be assessed and looked at by a consultant - we are certainly talking a couple of hours I would say.""
Dr Rupert Beale
column2: Group Leader
column3: Cell Biology of Infection Laboratory
column4: Francis Crick Institute
column5: said:

column1: ""Doctors will be monitoring important vital signs such as oxygen saturations. They will also check blood tests to see what the immune response to the virus looks like
column2: and to assess liver and kidney function.

column1: ""They will perform an electrocardiogram (ECG) to check the heart. More sophisticated tests may include a CT scan of the chest to get an accurate picture of the lungs. They will consider the best way to deliver oxygen
column2: and will also consider other treatments depending on test results.

column1: ""We are in a struggle between humanity and a deadly virus. Whatever your politics
column2: we are all on the same side. I wish the Prime Minister a speedy recovery.""

column1: QA: BORIS JOHNSON IN HOSPITAL
Why has Johnson been taken to hospital?
The Prime Minister was transferred to hospital as a ""precautionary measure"" on the advice of his doctor
column2: according to Number 10. Ten days after his positive test for Covid-19
column3: Johnson is still suffering a high temperature.

column1: Who is leading the Government?
When the Prime Minister first announced that he was ill last week
column2: it was said that the Dominic Raab
column3: Foreign Secretary
column4: would take over if Johnson became too sick to work. A spokesman insisted tonight that Johnson remains ""in charge of the Government"" despite his hospital admission.

column1: Has Johnson been working since his diagnosis?

Johnson has led several meetings via video conferencing since his diagnosis including the Cabinet. He has shared several video updates from his Number 11 flat and stepped outside to join the nationwide clap for NHS staff on Friday NZT.
Has his pregnant fiancee been ill?
Carrie Symonds said she had been suffering Covid-19 symptoms
column2: but is ""on the mend"". Symonds
column4: who is expecting the couple's first baby in the early northern summer
column5: said she was not tested for the virus.

column1: Has anybody else in the Government been ill?
Matt Hancock
column2: Health Secretary
column3: is already back at work after having tested positive for the coronavirus. Scotland Secretary Alister Jack also developed telltale signs of the illness. Chief medical officer Professor Chris Whitty self-quarantined after he noticed symptoms
column4: and the Prime Minister's chief adviser
column5: Dominic Cummings
column6: also self isolating."

column1: 1081	Irish Independent	1307786	By Vicky Shaw
column2: Pa Personal Finance Correspondent	Consumer confidence has plunged at fastest rate in over 40 years
column3: says index	Consumer confidence fell of a cliff in the last two weeks of March
column4: tumbling at the fastest rate since records started more than 40 years ago
column5: according to an index. People were asked about changes to their personal finances
column6: the general economy and whether they feel now is the right time to make major purchases
column7: during interviews between March 16 and 27.The results produced an overall negative score in the consumer confidence barometer from GfK of minus 34
column8: indicating a sharp decline in confidence of 25 points from a score of minus nine in mid-March.Our Covid-19 flash report shows a dramatic result with consumer confidence falling off the cliff in the last two weeks of March.The 25-point tumble was the biggest fall in confidence since records started in January 1974.The overall score of minus 34 is approaching the depths of negativity recorded by the index during the 2008 economic downturn.Confidence decreased on all measures within the index.Joe Staton
column9: GfKs client strategy director
column10: said: Our Covid-19 flash report shows a dramatic result with consumer confidence falling off the cliff in the last two weeks of March.The last time we saw such a decline was during the 2008 economic downturn.Our falling confidence in our personal financial situation and the wider economy reflects the new concern for many across the UK.Despite record grocery sales
column11: and recent peaks for purchases of freezers
column12: TVs and home office equipment as people prepared for a long period in the home
column13: the major purchase index is down 50 points
column14: a stark picture for some parts of the retail industry in the short to medium term.More than 2
column15: 000 people aged 16 and over were surveyed.

column1: 1081	Irish Independent	1307786	By Vicky Shaw
column2: Pa Personal Finance Correspondent	New overdraft rules in force but lenders adjust plans due to coronavirus	New overdraft rules come into force from Monday
column3: which mean firms can only charge one single annual interest rate for both arranged and unarranged borrowing. The changes were announced by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) long before the coronavirus outbreak put many households finances under pressure.Many overdraft providers had pegged their new single overdraft rates at around 40% – which is around double the rate some borrowers had previously been paying to use their arranged overdraft.However
column4: as part stop-gap measures to help cushion the financial impact of coronavirus
column5: some providers are temporarily freezing rates at lower levels or rolling them back down to what they had been before they were increased.Many providers are also ramping up their zero-interest overdraft buffers
column6: so borrowers may not pay anything in the short-term.For example
column7: HSBC UK is temporarily halving its new 39.9% overdraft rate
column8: taking it back down to 19.9%.From April 9 for a three-month period
column9: HSBC UK will also automatically increase its temporary interest-free buffer for millions of Bank Account and Advance Account overdraft customers to £500.NatWest has frozen overdraft interest at current rates for personal customers for at least three months.The temporary relief available for overdraft customers affected by the coronavirus outbreak varies between providers.But the FCA proposed last week that a blanket zero-interest buffer of £500 should be introduced across providers
column11: on peoples main accounts.The proposal is being consulted on – but if agreed it could be in place by Thursday April 9.In the meantime
column12: the new industry rules coming into force from Monday aim to make overdraft pricing simpler and fairer
column13: reducing the burden on some people who have previously been paying high charges.Firms will need to charge a simple annual interest rate – without additional fees and charges for using an overdraft.The new rules will particularly help people who have paid high charges in the past for going into an unarranged overdraft.The FCA previously found that unarranged overdraft fees are often 10 times as high as charges for payday loans and fall disproportionately on vulnerable consumers.The regulators calculations suggested the cost of borrowing £100 through an unarranged overdraft would fall from a typical £5 per day to under 10p per day.It also said in January that it expects firms to help people who borrow large amounts within their arranged overdraft
column14: which could include reducing or waiving interest or agreeing a repayment programme.Gareth Shaw
column15: head of money at Which?
column16: said: These important changes will give consumers more clarity about their finances and should help them make informed spending decisions.It is right that banks are now working with the regulator to provide further help for customers who may need to use an overdraft facility to help manage their finances during the coronavirus outbreak.The FCA must keep a close eye on developments in this area
column17: including competitive pricing
column18: to ensure that its transformation of current account overdrafts delivers for customers.Here is a round-up of what major providers have already announced about their new overdraft rates and the measures put in place for giving temporary relief to borrowers affected by coronavirus:New rate: Nationwide introduced a 39.9% rate in November 2019.Overdraft relief: The Society will not charge overdraft interest from April 20 until July 1 for those financially impacted by coronavirus. Customers can request a fee-free overdraft interest holiday by completing an online form. Nationwide will email or text to acknowledge requests.New rate: The majority of customers will pay 39.9% (29.9% for Club Lloyds). As the group takes a risk-based approach to overdrafts
column19: some customers will pay 49.9%.Overdraft relief: All customers will be able to have a £300 interest-free buffer from April 6 to July 6. As a result of this
column20: Lloyds said all its overdraft customers would pay less from April 6. It said 90% of customers would have paid less for their overdraft even if the £300 buffer across its accounts was not introduced.New rate: A rate of 35% took effect on March 22.Overdraft relief: Barclays is waiving all overdraft interest from March 27 until the end of April 2020
column21: meaning no charges for customers to use their agreed overdraft. Interest will automatically be removed.Barclays is reviewing measures after this date and will be communicating with customers shortly.New rate: HSBC imposed a new rate of 39.9% on March 14. But it is now temporarily reducing the rate charged above its interest-free buffer to 19.9%.Overdraft relief: Alongside the rate reduction
column24: it will increase the temporary interest-free buffer for millions of Bank Account and Advance Account overdraft customers from £300 to £500.New rate: A rate of 39.49% would have been introduced on April 1 for NatWest customers
column25: and on March 30 for RBS and Ulster Bank customers. But customers will continue to pay their current rate of interest for at least three months
column26: meaning a maximum of 19.89% across arranged and unarranged borrowing.Overdraft relief: As well as the rate freeze
column27: the bank has also removed all other overdraft fees and charges
column28: so all customers who use their overdraft for the three months from March 30 will pay less.New rate: Santander previously announced it will be 39.9% from April 6
column29: however it plans to make a further statement in due course.Overdraft relief: Santander previously announced a £350 interest-free overdraft buffer for three months from April 6. This means it will automatically waive interest on up to £350 of any agreed overdraft limit.Santander said last week: We will be reviewing the FCA proposals as a matter of priority and will be announcing new measures to help our customers as soon as possible.New rate: A rate of 35.9% was due to come into force on April 4 – but this has been delayed until July 3.Overdraft relief: Customers with an existing arranged overdraft will have the interest waived on up to £500 of arranged overdraft use until July 3.New rate: TSB previously announced a rate of 39.9%.Overdraft relief: TSB has introduced measures including fees waivers or implementing an interest freeze on their overdraft.It is looking to make changes to align with FCAs guidance

column2: when you mention the pandemic of 2020 to an accountant who was working then

column1: Jovita Carranza
column2: administrator of the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA)
column3: left
column4: speaks as ... [+] Steven Mnuchin
column5: U.S. Treasury secretary

column1: © 2020 Bloomberg Finance LP
The Biggest Uncertainty

I see that Tony Nitti has addressed PPP this morning with Paycheck Protection Plan Loans: Three Things The SBA And Banks Need To Agree On Now. Good stuff there. Check it out. I am going to focus on one of the three and also take a step back and look at a larger picture.
The language in the legislation that is now driving accountants crazy is this exclusion from defined “payroll costs”:
(bb) taxes imposed or withheld under chapters 21
column3: or 24 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 during the covered period;

column1: Chapter 24 is the biggest concern - Collection of Income Tax At Source on Wages.
A really on-the-ball CPA Daniel Baratz of the Zenith Group wrote me on March 29 (two days after the act passed)
“Based on my read of this
column2: the Act excludes taxes assessed or withheld under Chapters 21
column3: 22 and 24 of the Code. From what I can tell
column4: this is FICA
column5: Railroad and Withholding at the source.

column1: To me
column2: this seems to indicate that the amount of “payroll costs” eligible to be the basis for calculating the loan amount is your gross payroll MINUS federal income tax withholding as well as both employee and employer shares of social security and Medicare. Maybe I am missing something but I am having a hard time not reading it this way and also a really hard time believing that this was congress’ intent.

column1: If I am reading it right
column2: this would mean
column3: in theory at least that if an employee has chosen to have 100% of their pay withheld for FIT
column4: the employer could borrow nothing to keep paying that employee during this period. Similarly
column5: their ability to have loan amounts forgiven would actually be partly determined by each employee’s W-4. I really hope I am reading this wrong or the regulatory interpretation can get around this – what do you think?”

column1: Here is my lame response.
“That is interesting. I don't read it that way. I'll look again. It will be clear pretty quickly when people start applying.”
That was last Sunday. It was around Wednesday or Thursday
column2: that most of the rest of the world was catching up with Daniel Baratz. The CPA I consult for who drops F-bombs like a B-17 drops 500-pounders was on me about it on Thursday.

column1: Why Accountants Think It Cannot Be So

I just don’t think of withholding as a tax that the employer is paying. I think of it as money that no longer belongs to the employer and is held in trust to be paid over rather quickly. And for many if not most employers
column2: it goes into the hands of a payroll company at the same time the net is paid. Given the nasty stuff that happens when you fail to pay withholding it is a reasonable view.

column1: But remember Reilly’s First Law of Tax Planning: It is what it is. Deal with it. In this case what it is remains unclear.
More From Daniel Baratz
At any rate
column2: yesterday I call Mr. Baratz to eat a little crow
column3: congratulate him for being ahead of the curve and ask for any further comments. He was very gracious. Here is some of what he wrote back to me:

column1: “The federal government has an existing definition for “payroll costs”. It is reported by every employer in America on quarterly payroll tax returns. Despite that

Section 1102 of the CARES act creates its own original and unique definition of “payroll costs” that does not exist anywhere else in the known universe and actually has no bearing on the actual amount of dollars (cost) employers must expend to pay their payroll!
The result in a practical sense is that based on the current definition
column2: even if an employer maintains 100% of their workforce and pays them 100% of their existing wages
column3: they will likely have only a portion of their loan forgiven even though they have complied with the stated intention of the program. What is even crazier is that the amount of the forgiveness will actually be driven by each individual employee’s withholding elections. So
column4: an employer that has several employees who request more tax to be withheld from their pay because maybe they like to get a big refund is penalized and will have less of their loan forgiven than someone whose employees choose to have less withheld. There is no economic basis for this approach. I do not know for sure what Congress’ intent was with excluding certain employee-paid taxes from the definition of Payroll Costs but I surely hope this was not it.”

column1: I still think you should probably still apply for the loan
column2: but please put it in a separate account and wait for some clarity before you count on not having to pay it back.

column1: Take A Step Back
Remember that the Paycheck Protection Plan is not the only tool that Congress has given us to help deal with the crisis.
There is the Employee Retention Credit Tony Nitti explained it further here.
There is the Economic Injury Disaster Loan.
There is Pandemic Unemployment Assistance.
That is not all
column2: but it’s a lot.

column1: And then there are tools that were already in the tool-box
column2: but kind of buried pretty deep. One of those is Code Section 139 - Disaster Relief Payments. John E. McGrady discusses that here.

column1: Some Probably Bad Ideas You Should Consider Anyway

It has occurred to me that an alternative or supplement to PPP might be laying some people off and then helping them out with some deductible disaster relief payments. Maybe you just use PPP money for people that can keep doing something during the crisis. Of course that sort of course assumes you have some resources.
On the other hand
column2: that $600 per week supplement to unemployment might be a better deal than you paying them money that you might have to pay back even if you don’t have something extra to throw in.

column1: I would not recommend taking up to $100
column2: 000 out of retirement accounts that you can put back during the next three years
column3: but perhaps when combined with the net operating loss carryback that might be what lets you pull through.

column1: Start With A Blank Slate
Now
column2: I just gave you two quite likely bad ideas
column3: but there might be the germ of a good idea buried in there. This reminds me a little bit of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 which made my career
column4: because I read a bit more than the average accountant in my firm who lived by oral tradition and following last year. All of a sudden everything they knew was wrong.

column1: As you look at these programs and how they interact and what your particular situation is
column2: try to clear your mind of preconceived notions. Don’t fixate on any one tool. PPP might be a great hammer
column3: but maybe your problem is not a nail."

column1: 27	Reuters	1149086	Reuters Editorial	Timeline: Johnson's activities before his hospitalisation with coronavirus	"LONDON (Reuters) - British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was admitted to hospital for tests on Sunday in what Downing Street said was a “precautionary step” because he was showing persistent symptoms of the coronavirus 10 days after testing positive for it.
A view of 10 Downing Street in London
column2: Britain April 5
column3: 2020 after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was admitted to hospital for tests on Sunday after suffering persistent coronavirus (COVID-19) symptoms after testing positive for the virus. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

column1: Below is a timeline with what we know about his activities over those 10 days
column2: when he was self-isolating but still leading Britain’s response to the coronavirus outbreak
column3: including chairing daily virtual emergency meetings.

column1: March 27
column2: Friday - Johnson said he had tested positive for the coronavirus and that he would self-isolate in Downing Street. Health Minister Matt Hancock also tested positive
column3: while England’s top medical officer began self-isolating after developing symptoms.

column1: “I’ve developed mild symptoms of the coronavirus. That’s to say - a temperature and a persistent cough
column2: ” Johnson said in a video posted on Twitter.

column1: “Be in no doubt that I can continue
column2: thanks to the wizardry of modern technology
column3: to communicate with all my top team to lead the national fightback against coronavirus.”

column1: Johnson spoke by phone to U.S. President Donald Trump
column2: who wished him a speedy recovery.

column1: Johnson chaired a government meeting on the coronavirus on Friday morning via teleconference. Johnson had meals delivered to the door of an apartment at 11 Downing Street while in self-isolation.
March 28
column2: Saturday - It is announced that Johnson will write to every UK household urging people to stay at home to help contain the coronavirus.

column1: March 29
column2: Sunday - Johnson posted a video of himself in a suit and tie
column3: thanking people for staying at home as well as health workers
column4: grocers and pharmacists.

column1: March 30
column2: Monday - Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said Johnson was “full of vigour” despite being self-isolated. Johnson’s spokesman said that Johnson was fully able to run Britain’s coronavirus response despite the positive test
column3: and he continued to chair daily meetings.

column1: Johnson tweeted a picture of himself attending a meeting via video link.
March 31
column2: Tuesday - Johnson chaired Cabinet - the first all-digital meeting of a British PM’s top team of ministers - on video platform Zoom.

column1: April 1
column2: Wednesday - Johnson posted a video message on Twitter
column3: lamenting a rise in the number of coronavirus-related deaths in Britain.

column1: April 2
column2: Thursday - In another video message
column3: Johnson vowed to ramp up testing for the coronavirus.

column1: He also came out by himself onto the doorstep in Downing Street to applaud frontline medical workers as part of the “Clap For Carers” initiative.
April 3
column2: Friday - A weary-looking Johnson said he would remain in isolation as he continued to have mild symptoms of COVID-19
column3: the respiratory disease caused by the novel coronavirus
column4: including a high temperature
column5: a week after he tested positive for the virus.

column1: “Although I’m feeling better and I’ve done my seven days of isolation
column2: alas I still have one of the symptoms
column3: a minor symptom
column4: I still have a temperature
column5: so in accordance with government advice I must continue my self-isolation until that symptom itself goes
column6: ” Johnson said in a video message
column7: wearing an open-necked shirt.

column1: April 4
column2: Saturday - Johnson said in a tweet that he spoke to newly elected opposition Labour leader Keir Starmer and invited him and other party leaders to a briefing the following week on how to work together during the national emergency.

column1: April 5
column2: Sunday - Downing Street announced in the evening that Johnson had been taken to hospital as a precautionary measure because of the persistent nature of his symptoms 10 days after he first tested positive.

column1: Reporting by Alistair Smout and Mark Bendeich; Editing by Peter Cooney"
202	The New York Times	1233496	Charles M	Opinion | Social Distancing Is a Privilege	"People like to say that the coronavirus is no respecter of race
column2: class or country
column3: that the disease Covid-19 is mindless and will infect anybody it can.

column1: In theory
column2: that is true. But
column3: in practice
column4: in the real world
column5: this virus behaves like others
column6: screeching like a heat-seeking missile toward the most vulnerable in society. And this happens not because it prefers them
column7: but because they are more exposed
column8: more fragile and more ill.

column1: What the vulnerable portion of society looks like varies from country to country
column2: but in America
column3: that vulnerability is highly intersected with race and poverty.

column1: Early evidence from cities and states already shows that black people are disproportionately affected by the virus in devastating ways. As ProPublica reported
column2: in Milwaukee County
column3: Wis.
column4: as of Friday morning
column5: 81 percent of the deaths were black people. Black people make up only 26 percent of that county.

column1: As for Chicago
column2: WBEZ reported Sunday that “70 percent of Covid-19 deaths are black
column3: ” and pointed out about surrounding Cook County
column4: “While black residents make up only 23 percent of the population in the county
column5: they account for 58 percent of the Covid-19 deaths.”

column1: The Detroit News reported last week
column2: “At least 40 percent of those killed by the novel coronavirus in Michigan so far are black
column3: a percentage that far exceeds the proportion of African-Americans in the Detroit region and state.”

column1: If this pattern holds true across other states and cities
column2: this virus could have a catastrophic impact on black people in this country.

column1: And yet
column2: we are still not seeing an abundance of news coverage or national governmental response that center on these racial disparities. Many states haven’t even released race-specific data on cases and deaths. The federal government hasn’t either.

column1: Partly for this reason
column2: we are left with deceptive and deadly misinformation. The perception that this is a jet-setters’ disease
column3: or a spring breakers’ disease
column4: or a “Chinese virus” as President Trump likes to say
column5: must be laid to rest. The idea that this virus is an equal-opportunity killer must itself be killed.

column1: And
column2: we must dispense with the callous message that the best defense we have against the disease is something that each of us can control: We can all just stay home and keep social distance.

column1: As a report last month by the Economic Policy Institute pointed out
column2: “less than one in five black workers and roughly one in six Hispanic workers are able to work from home.”

column1: As the report pointed out
column2: “Only 9.2 percent of workers in the lowest quartile of the wage distribution can telework
column3: compared with 61.5 percent of workers in the highest quartile.”

column1: If you touch people for a living
column2: in elder care or child care
column3: if you cut or fix their hair
column4: if you clean their spaces or cook their food
column5: if you drive their cars or build their houses
column6: you can’t do that from home.

column1: Staying at home is a privilege. Social distancing is a privilege.
The people who can’t must make terrible choices: Stay home and risk starvation or go to work and risk contagion.
And
column2: this isn’t just happening here
column3: it is happening with poor people around the world
column4: from New Delhi to New Mexico.

column1: If they go to work
column2: they must often use crowded mass transportation
column3: because low-wage workers can’t necessarily afford to own a car or call a cab.

column1: Such is the life of the working poor
column2: or those slightly above poverty
column3: but still struggling. Our entire discussion around this virus is stained with economic elitism. In social media commentary about images of packed buses and crowds of delivery workers outside restaurants
column4: people chastise black and brown people for not always being inside
column5: but many of those doing the chastising do so from comfortable homes with sufficient money and food.

column1: People can’t empathize with what it truly means to be poor in this country
column2: to live in a too-small space with too many people
column3: to not have enough money to buy food for a long duration or anywhere to store it if they did. People don’t know what it’s like to live in a food desert where fresh fruit and vegetables are unavailable and nutrient-deficient junk food is cheap and exists in abundance.

column1: People are quick to criticize these people for crowding into local fast food restaurants to grab something to eat. Not everyone can afford to order GrubHub or FreshDirect.
Furthermore
column2: in a nation where too many black people have been made to feel that their lives are constantly under threat
column3: the existence of yet another produces less of a panic. The ability to panic becomes a privilege existing among those who rarely have to do it.

column1: I wholeheartedly encourage everyone who can to stay home
column2: but I’m also aware enough to know that not everyone can or will
column3: and that it is not simply a pathological disregard for the common good.

column1: If you are sheltering in place in an ivory tower
column2: or even a comfortable cul-de-sac or a smartly well-appointed apartment
column3: and your greatest concern is boredom and leftover food
column4: please stop scolding those scratching to survive.

column1: The Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some tips. And here’s our email: letters@nytimes.com.
Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter (@NYTopinion)
column2: and Instagram."

column1: 2068	New York Post	2432022	Carl Campanile	Thousands of NY COVID patients are being treated with anti-malarial drug	"As many as 4
column2: 000 seriously ill coronavirus patients in New York are being treated with the anti-malarial drug hydroxychloroquine
column3: state health officials say.

column1: President Trump has touted hydroxychloroquine as a potential life-saver
column2: although there is no widespread scientific evidence to date showing it helps battle COVID-19.

column1: But Gov. Andrew Cuomo last month said healthcare providers in the state would be using the drug in combination with the antibiotic Zithromax
column2: or azithromycin
column3: for some last-ditch cases
column4: based on potentially promising research.

column1: “Time is of the essence
column2: ’’ said Albany University Public Health Dean David Holtgrave
column3: who is on the state’s research team
column4: in a statement.

column1: A state Health Department official said the DOH has shipped doses of hydroxychloroquine to 56 hospitals across New York
column2: distributing enough “to treat 4
column3: 000 patients to date.”

column1: Patients have received doses as part of four- or 10-day regimens
column2: officials said.

column1: The University of Albany’s School of Public Health is observing the drug’s impact on the patients
column2: and its preliminary study could come back in weeks instead of the usual months
column3: officials said.

column1: There are also clinical trials being conducted to see whether the drug can help block transmission.
NYU Langone Medical School is conducting a random trial with a $9.5 million grant from the Bill  Melinda Gates Foundation.
“Currently
column2: there is no proven way to prevent COVID-19 after being exposed
column3: ” said Anna Bershteyn
column4: an assistant professor with the Department of Population Health at NYU Langone and the study’s co-principal investigator.

column1: “If hydroxychloroquine provides protection
column2: then it could be an essential tool for fighting this pandemic. If it doesn’t
column3: then people should avoid unnecessary risks from taking the drug.”

column1: The RX has long been used to treat malaria
column2: rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

column1: Its potential side effects include everything from fatal heart arrhythmia to vision loss
column2: ear-ringing
column3: vomiting
column4: mood changes
column5: skin rashes and hair loss.

column1: Health officials are treading cautiously
column2: saying they don’t anticipate hydroxychloroquine will be a “miracle drug” against the coronavirus — but the studies are worth the gamble.

column1: In terms of the NYU clinical trial regarding prevention
column2: researchers are enrolling 2
column3: 000 adult volunteers at six sites.

column1: They are recruiting people who lack any COVID-19 symptoms but have been in close contact with others who have a confirmed or pending diagnosis.
On a random basis
column2: the trial participants will receive either hydroxychloroquine or a placebo pill — vitamin C — every day for two weeks.

column1: Each day during the 14-day period and then again on Day 28
column2: the participants will swab their nasal passages and send the samples to researchers to detect potential COVID-19 infection.

column1: “If everything goes as planned
column2: the eight-week trial could provide answers by summer on whether a preventive dose of the drug is safe and effective
column3: ’’ NYU Langone said in a release.

column1: “If so
column2: the strategy could give health officials a much needed boost in slowing person-to-person transmission.”

column1: The federal Food and Drug Administration granted emergency-use authorization to use hydroxychloroquine to treat COVID-19 patients amid the pandemic.
There has been anecdotal evidence — including from China — that the drug help patients clear the virus sooner.
But Dr. Anthony Fauci of the National Institutes of Health
column2: asked recently whether the drug was considered a treatment for the novel coronavirus
column3: said
column4: “The answer is no … The evidence that you’re talking about … is anecdotal evidence.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Northwell Health facilities — including Lenox Hill
column3: Long Island Jewish and Staten Island University hospitals — and Maimonides Medical Center are giving moderately to seriously ill coronavirus patients certain antiviral drugs such as Sarilumab
column4: an IL-6 inhibitor
column5: and Remdesivir
column6: a drug that incorporates itself into the genome.

column1: Northwell has recruited 143 patients for a Sarilumab trial.

Mount Sinai’s-Icahn School of Medicine also is one of 34 institutions nationwide participating in the National COVID-19 Convalescent Plasma Project. The program seeks blood-plasma donations from recovered coronavirus patients that contain antibodies that can be used to fight the virus in seriously ill patients."

29	BBC	954024	Helen Briggs	How the pandemic is putting the spotlight on wildlife trade	"Image copyright
Getty Images
Image caption
Sun bear rescued from wildlife traffickers in Indonesia
Conservation experts say the coronavirus pandemic
column2: which likely originated at a market selling wild animals in China
column3: is a watershed moment for curbing the global wildlife trade
column4: which can drive extinction and spread disease.

column1: When Adam Peyman walked into a restaurant in Vietnam to order a meal he was shocked to find wild animals
column2: including threatened species
column3: on the menu
column4: alongside traditional rice
column5: noodles and seafood. Sting ray
column6: porcupine
column7: softshell turtle
column8: wild pig and wild goat were all on offer.

column1: It was a bit of a surprise to see these foods
column2: says the wildlife manager for the animal welfare organisation
column3: Humane Society International. ""But
column4: these kinds of wild foods are considered something of a luxury.""

column1: Feasting on exotic game has become a sign of status and wealth in some Asian countries. The desire for wildlife as food or medicine drives a trade in wild animals
column2: some procured illegally
column3: creating a breeding ground for disease and the chance for viruses to leap to humans.

column1: Image copyright
Getty Images
Image caption
US protest by the animal rights organisation
column2: Peta

column1: ""The consumption of wild animals
column2: especially wild mammals
column3: which can carry diseases that can cross the species barrier
column4: does pose a real threat to human health
column5: says Mr Peyman. ""It's hard to tell whether these animals are taken from the wild legally or not
column6: some of them could have been smuggled in and then sold on these wet markets
column7: as they're called.""

column1: Wet markets
Wet markets have become a familiar sight in many countries in Southeast Asia
column2: particularly mainland China. Selling live fish
column3: chickens and wildlife
column4: as well as fresh fruit and vegetables
column5: they get their name from the melting ice used to preserve goods
column6: as well as to wash the floors clean of blood from butchered animals.

column1: Image copyright
Getty Images
Image caption
Illegal wildlife trade in Myanmar
Wet markets can be ""timebombs"" for epidemics
column2: says Prof Andrew Cunningham
column3: deputy director of science at the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). ""This sort of way that we treat... animals as if they're just our commodities for us to plunder - it comes back to bite us and it's no surprise.""

column1: Leap to humans
The current coronavirus pandemic
column2: which has claimed tens of thousands of lives
column3: likely originated in the Wuhan seafood market. Despite its name
column4: the market was selling a lot more than fish
column5: including snakes
column6: porcupine and deer
column7: according to one report.

column1: After an initial cluster of cases connected to the market
column2: the virus began spreading dramatically inside China
column3: before reaching much of the world. The origins of the novel virus are unknown
column4: but it most likely emerged in a bat
column5: then made the leap to humans via another wild animal host.

column1: Scientists have for decades been drawing attention to outbreaks of human diseases that have originated in animals
column2: including Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (Sars)
column3: Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (Mers) and Ebola.

column1: The message from the New York-based Wildlife Conservation Society is clear: ban live animal markets that trade in wildlife
column2: stop illegal trafficking and poaching of wild animals.

column1: Not only will this help prevent the spread of disease
column2: it will address one of the major drivers of species extinction
column3: says the society.

column1: Image copyright
Wildlife Conservation Society
Image caption
The Wildlife Conservation Society is calling for a ban on wildlife consumption
In the wake of the initial outbreak in Wuhan
column2: China introduced a ban on all farming and consumption of live wildlife
column3: which is expected to become law later this year. Thousands of wildlife farms raising animals such as porcupines
column4: civets and turtles have been shut down. However
column5: loopholes remain
column6: such as the trade in wild animals for medicine
column7: pets and scientific research.

column1: Then there is the traditional Chinese medicines industry
column2: which also uses wildlife products. Only recently
column3: the Chinese government appears to have approved the use of an injection - ironically as a coronavirus treatment - that contains bear bile.

column1: Campaigners worry these exemptions could pave way for illegal trade on wildlife meat
column2: as it did in the past with
column3: for instance
column4: tiger and leopard body parts. So pangolin meat could still be available as the animal's scales can be used for medicine and its nails as ornaments.

column1: All eyes
column2: therefore
column3: are on the soon-to-be amended wildlife protection law - whether and how it would address those loopholes.

column1: In neighbouring Vietnam
column2: the government is rushing through legislation to clamp down on illegal wildlife trade at street markets and online.  But some say it won't be easy to change cultural attitudes or to enforce bans
column3: when wet markets are part of the local culture
column4: with the belief that the meat sold there is fresh and cheap.

column1: Supply and demand
Prof Dirk Pfeiffer of City University of Hong Kong says the real issue is demand. ""The people who are providing them
column2: whether that's farmed wild animals or animals from the wild
column3: that's an important source of income for them. Pushing it underground
column4: that's not the solution
column5: so it needs to be a phased process.""

column1: This isn't the first time a pandemic has put the spotlight on wildlife trade. The 2002 Sars outbreak
column2: which started in China and claimed more than 700 lives
column3: was linked to bats and mongoose-like civets
column4: although the source was never confirmed.

column1: Image copyright
Getty Images
Image caption
Asian civet in Banda Aceh; the mammals were linked to Sars
Prof Cunningham says if we're to stop another pandemic in the future
column2: we must focus on causes as well as effects. At the root of the problem is the destruction of nature
column3: bringing animals and humans into conflict.

column1: Even in protected forests
column2: the forests are still there
column3: but the wildlife's gone from within them because they have ended up in markets
column4: he says. "".And it's easy to finger point
column5: but it's not just happening in China
column6: it's happening in many other countries and even in the western world. We like to have exotic pets and many of those are wild caught and we ought to be putting our own house in order too.""

column1: Additional reporting Navin Singh Khadka
Follow Helen on Twitter."

column1: 55	Daily Mail UK	1807995	Jayne Fryer	Britain's tallest folly could be yours for a knockdown price of £1.6m	"Do you have lofty aspirations? Or perhaps you're nurturing a Rapunzel complex — perfect for these self-isolating times.
Or maybe just the thought of owning your very own Grade I-listed
column2: 175ft
column3: eight-storey tower
column4: complete with 400 stairs
column5: a basement media room that once doubled as a sex dungeon
column6: communal ornamental pond
column7: metre-thick walls
column8: a crenellated coffee terrace and sweeping views over pretty much the whole of Kent are enough to put a spring in your step.

column1: If so
column2: read on.

column1: Because there is a silver lining to the upheavals of recent times — for buyers
column2: if not sellers. Property prices are being slashed and
column3: suddenly
column4: properties that most of us could only dream about are now far more affordable.

column1: (If only we were able to move.) One of these — after a huge £400
column2: 000 price drop — is Hadlow Tower
column3: the tallest folly in the country (soaring even higher than Nelson's Column in Trafalgar Square)
column4: which dominates the village of Hadlow near Tonbridge
column5: Kent
column6: and could now be yours for £1.6 million.

column1: For the price of a bog-standard terrace house in Fulham
column2: London
column3: you could live an entirely new life.

column1: Each morning you'd wake in your four-poster bed to the sound of nesting peregrines
column2: take your morning cuppa to the viewing platform on the eighth floor
column3: run up and down the two staircases for exercise — or take the lift
column4: if you're feeling lazy — gaze down on the peasants of Hadlow from your mullioned windows and
column5: well
column6: generally
column7: behave as if to the manor born.

column1: As current owner Christian Tym puts it: 'You can see it from about two miles away and whenever you even approach it
column2: it puts a smile on your face. I don't think I've ever looked at it and not felt lucky to own it.'

column1: Perhaps
column2: like Christian and his wife Rebecca
column3: both 43
column4: you'll host endless murder mystery parties
column5: snap up your very own suit of armour online and dream of designing your own crest — 'I would like one
column6: but my wife said it was pretentious!'

column1: Next you could pin up some family portraits and study your brand-new 'ancestral' home's history to wow your friends.
Hadlow Tower has certainly had its fair share of excitement.
Built in 1838 and originally attached to Hadlow Castle
column2: it was the brainchild of Walter Barton May
column3: a wealthy merchant who
column4: legend has it
column5: used it to spy on his errant wife as she canoodled with a farmer.

column1: During World War II it was used as a lookout post. While the castle was torn down in 1951
column2: the tower remained
column3: but fell into disrepair before being rescued by artist Bernard Hailstone.

column1: Over the next few decades
column2: arty owners came and went. But its raciest years came during its 26-year ownership by a flamboyant hotelier who used it as a venue for sex parties.

column1: What is now Christian's sleek media room and wine storage area was a sex dungeon
column2: the bed in the Rapunzel room was awash with cavorting couples and the spiral stairs were crammed with bare bottoms and leather whips as people rushed up and down to join in the fun.

column1: 'The poor local residents weren't very happy to be woken up by leather-clad people asking where the sex party was
column2: ' says Christian.

column1: Sadly
column2: some of them also weren't very pleased either
column3: when
column5: Christian snapped it up from the receivers for £425

column1: 'I got a very good price.' he says.
'The place was amazing
column2: Gorgeous
column3: the craftsmanship
column4: the finish
column5: the very modern fittings!' His timing was immaculate.

column1: The hotelier had been forced to sell
column2: and between 1997 and 2012 the tower had been given £3.25million in grants to repair and restore it.

column1: And
column2: driven by the very passionate local Save Hadlow Tower Action Group
column3: it had been sold for £1 to the Vivat Trust — a charity that preserved historic buildings — and transformed from storm-damaged wreck to a gleaming
column4: beaming
column5: beacon of extravagance again
column6: and perfect as an eccentric holiday rental for about £1
column7: 900 a week.

column1: But then Vivat went bust and Christian spotted an opportunity.
Cannily
column2: he also secured planning permission to change its use from holiday let to private residence and in 2017 he
column3: photographer wife Rebecca and their four sons
column4: now six
column5: eight
column6: 11 and 12
column7: moved in.

column1: 'The boys love the idea of living in a castle. That's the main reason why we bought it
column2: ' he says. 'But perhaps we did so with heart over head.'

column1: Indeed within a year
column2: and after having made only cosmetic changes to the decor
column3: it was back on the market.

column1: 'We realised it didn't suit our needs quite as well as we'd hoped
column2: ' says Christian. Two of their four boys are deaf
column3: and
column4: while most people might welcome the muffling effect of three-foot-thick castle walls
column5: they're not helpful to the hard of hearing.

column1: Sadly
column2: despite a flurry of interest
column3: it didn't sell. Perhaps all the stairs were a turn-off. And there are also a couple of teeny snags for any owner to negotiate — two covenants that still today have more than two years to run.

column1: To ensure your new home is well maintained at all times and — rather more onerous — to open it up to the public 28 days a year
column2: if required.

column1: 'It's surprisingly flexible . You could just do the whole of January if you like
column2: ' insists Christian. 'People book ahead online but we don't get much interest.'

column1: Last year he held just three open days.
Meanwhile
column2: a friend of Christian's suggested raffling it.

column1: 'It wasn't a bad idea
column2: ' he says. 'We thought we could make a bit of money for deaf charities
column3: too.'

column1: So in 2018
column2: he started selling raffle tickets for £4.50 each with the idea that
column3: when he hit a certain amount
column4: he'd draw a winner.

column1: If the members of the action group were cross about him snapping up the tower for a song and trying to sell it on for £2 million
column2: they were apoplectic at the indignity of a raffle.

column1: Even Andre Lloyd Webber waded in at the time
column2: saying: 'I don't think the public purse should be used to speculate.'

column1: 'We never really understood why they were all so against it
column2: ' says Christian. 'It wasn't us who received the grants. That was way before our time.'

column1: In the event
column2: the raffle didn't go to plan
column3: either. Ticket sales were disappointing.

column1: Eventually a cash prize of an undisclosed sum went to the winner. So the Tyms carried on living there
column2: admiring the views
column3: the peregrines and the craftsmanship and throwing murder mystery parties.

column1: Until a couple of weeks ago
column2: when it went back on the market again
column3: this time at a discounted price.

column1: 'We're trying to be realistic — we've had Brexit and now this awful Covid thing
column2: ' says Christian. 'Of course we'll all shed a tear when we leave.'

column1: So here
column2: dear reader
column3: is your chance — if you have a spare £1.6million to hand — to move up in the world in every possible way."

2339	ComicBook	952670	Jenna Anderson	10 Indie to Catch Up on During Coronavirus Self-Quarantine	"The COVID-19 pandemic has had a particularly profound impact on the comic industry
column2: as publishers and fans try to adjust to a ""new normal"" in terms of distribution and release. A majority of new comics are on hold for the immediate future
column3: leaving some to check out digital comics and collected editions of series to pass the time. While there are thousands of comics to check out on services like DC Universe and Marvel Unlimited (with Marvel recently uploading some significant free titles to that latter app)
column4: that's only the tip of the iceberg in terms of comics fans can explore. There are plenty of titles - either from other publishers or self-published entirely - that are just a few clicks away.

column1: Many of these titles are available through Comixology (if you're wanting to lend a few bucks to the industry)
column2: as well as free services through your local library
column3: such as Hoopla. Other titles are available entirely for free
column4: partially because they got their start as webcomics. So
column5: if you're looking for a good jumping-off point of indie comics to dive into while you're stuck at home
column6: read on to find out our suggestions.

column1: Check
column2: Please!

column1: (Photo: Check Please!)Available on: Official website
If you've been on Tumblr for the past eight-or-so years
column2: you've probably heard something about Check
column3: Please!. The series follows Eric ""Bitty"" Bittle
column4: a former figure skater who joins his college's hockey team as a freshman. Through a series of ""vlogs"" set in real-time
column5: we follow Bitty and his teammates throughout college
column6: as well as Bitty's journey as a young gay man.

column1: Ngozi Ukazu's series has been published in physical volumes
column2: but it got its start as a free webcomic in 2013
column3: and its storytelling blossomed into an official Tumblr
column4: Twitter
column5: and various other forms of storytelling. If you want a queer
column6: heartfelt story to get you through self-quarantine - or you're just really missing sports - Check
column7: Please! might be a good place to start.

column1: Coffin Bound
(Photo: Image Comics)Available on: Comixology
column2: Hoopla

column1: Coffin Bound follows Izzy
column2: a young woman who is sent on a literal trip down memory lane after being targeted by a hitman. With the help of a macabre cast of characters
column3: Izzy sets out on one major road trip
column4: as she seeks to erase all trace of herself — and prevent the men in her life from manipulating her history.

column1: While only a few issues in
column2: Coffin Bound is one of the coolest and most profound comics that has been published in the past year. Dan Watters and Dani craft a punk rock
column3: grindhouse tale of legacy
column4: self-preservation
column5: and body horror
column6: and now is as good of a time as ever to dive into it.

column1: Crowded
(Photo: Image Comics)Available on: Comixology
column2: Hoopla

column1: For a completely-different kind of assassin-tinged road trip story
column2: you should absolutely pick up Crowded. The series is set in an alternate version of our present
column3: where assassinations are crowdfunded through an app called Reapr. This begins to cause a major headache for Charlie Ellison
column4: a seemingly-average young woman who suddenly has a very expensive bounty on her head. Teaming up with Vita - the lowest-rated bodyguard on the ""Dfend"" app - and an adorable chihuahua
column5: Charlie needs to stay alive... and figure out who wants her dead.

column1: Christopher Sebela
column2: Ro Stein  Ted Brandt
column3: and company craft a hilarious and action-packed tale
column4: which will make you look at human interaction and relationships in a whole new way.

column1: Hark! A Vagrant
(Photo: Kate Beaton)Available on: Official website

Kate Beaton might be one of the best cartoonists to rise to prominence in the past decade and a Hark! A Vagrant is the best distillation of her skills. The long-running webcomic has lampooned everything from centuries-old history to Nancy Drew covers
column2: with some legitimately hilarious results.

column1: No matter where you dive into Hark! A Vagrant
column2: each comic will bring a satisfying
column3: but brilliantly-constructed short-form storytelling.

column1: iZombie
(Photo: Vertigo Comics)Available on: Comixology
column2: Hoopla

column1: iZombie is about as self-contained and genuinely creative as you can get. The series
column2: which was part of DC's (now-defunct) Vertigo label from 2010-2012
column3: follows Gwen Dylan
column4: a young-woman-turned-zombie in Eugene
column5: Oregon. Gwen is forced to moonlight as a gravedigger to feed her appetite for brains
column6: which allows her to access the memories of the brains she's eating.

column1: While the comic is definitely different from The CW's fan-favorite television adaptation
column2: both versions of iZombie have quite a lot to love. Plus
column3: what other comic has a supporting cast that includes a ghost from the 1960s and a ""were-terrier""?

column1: Lady Killer
(Photo: Dark Horse Comics)Available on: Comixology
column2: Hoopla

column1: Another female-led and obsession-worthy comic that deserves more attention is Joelle Jones' Lady Killer. The series
column2: which is published in two volumes
column3: follows Josie Schuller In the 1950s. A seemingly-perfect housewife
column4: Josie moonlights as a contract killer
column5: only the two sides of her life to intersect in a deadly way.

column1: If you've been following Jones' recently-concluded Catwoman run
column2: Lady Killer is a perfect way to keep the momentum going. If not
column3: it's still just an incredibly entertaining and gorgeously-rendered comic.

column1: On a Sunbeam
(Photo: Avery Hill Publishing)Available on: Official website
Tillie Walden is another cartoonist and artist who has put out consistently-stellar work
column2: and On a Sunbeam is no exception. The series
column3: which was initially published as a webcomic
column4: follows Mia
column5: the member of a team in charge of rebuilding structures in space. As the story goes along
column6: Mia and her fellow crew members must come to terms with their own losses.

column1: On a Sunbeam is bizarre and truly breathtaking with visuals to match. While you should also buy the collected edition

column1: Next

column3: unbeknown to me

column1: They asked me to create a range for the supermarket and be a regional supplier.

column1: No one could have foreseen that our soap would be suddenly playing a crucial role in the fight against the spread of coronavirus.

621	Quartz	1182578	Katherine Ellen Foley	How to read coronavirus news like a science writer	"In the current climate of Covid-19
column2: health and science news dominates headlines everywhere.

column1: It’s arguably the first “infodemic
column2: ” as news spreads literally virally across social media and media outlets. In a time of uncertainty
column3: we hunger for information. Yet even though internet access means much news is at our fingertips
column4: it’s not always easy to evaluate the quality of what we’re reading—and what it actually means about the state of science.

column1: If you’re being bombarded with facts about Covid-19 and aren’t sure whether to trust them
column2: think like we do here at Quartz. Questioning new information with a measured sense of skepticism and a little digging can help you avoid taking in sensationalized information. The following is good advice not just during this pandemic
column3: but any time you pick up the health and science section of a given publication.

column1: Remember the warp-speed timeline
Covid-19 is caused by a virus
column2: SARS-CoV-2
column3: that no one knew about until a few months ago. Scientists have not had time to study it in-depth. Much of what they’re learning is based on what we’re observing from an epidemiological standpoint and what we know about other viruses
column4: like the flu and SARS.

column1: The quality of science is good—it just isn’t as robust as other fields are yet. The pandemic has sparked an unprecedented amount of international research collaboration. Scientists are working around the clock to figure out new ways to treat the virus and develop vaccines against it. Journals are publishing pre-prints of papers as soon as they can to make sure that everyone has access to the most up-to-date information
column2: rather than waiting for a period of review and to publish within a particular issue.

column1: Remember that new information may be true
column2: but hasn’t had time to be validated by other studies just yet. “This kind of healthy skepticism does not mean you’re dismissing everything as false—it simply means remembering the things you hear could be false
column3: but they could also be true…or they could be something in between
column4: ” Emma Frans
column5: an epidemiology and psychiatry researcher at Oxford University in the UK and Karolinska Institutet in Sweden
column6: told TED.

column1: Weigh the scientific evidence
When a headline claims a new study uncovered a truth about Covid-19
column2: look for a link to the study in the article—or at least a scientific journal named so you can find it on your own. You don’t have to read the whole paper (if you can access it) to get a sense of what it’s about
column3: although it’s great if you can.

column1: First
column2: make sure the actual scientific article seems to reflect what the news is saying. Is it even
column3: in fact
column4: about Covid-19? Or is it about another biological process that may have implications for the spread or severity of the disease?

column1: If it is about Covid-19
column2: see what kind of research it is. Many of the papers coming out about Covid-19 are observational studies
column3: in which researchers report what happened to a group of people in a certain setting. These studies can be great—particularly if they have a sample size of more than 1
column4: 000 people. They can point researchers to correlations
column5: or patterns of outcomes in certain circumstances. (You should be skeptical of papers that only write up one person
column6: called a case study
column7: or a handful of people. These are too small to make meaningful assumptions about the general public.)

column1: Observational studies may be biased in the kinds of people they study (for example
column2: only those who got sick enough to go to the hospital). They also can’t tell scientists why something is happening on a biological level
column3: or the causation. They’re reporting what happened to a group of people in a way that may be able to inform what may happen to others in similar circumstances.

column1: Ideally
column2: any observational study would have some sort of lab study that presents more research that could lead to a reason why the observed outcome happened (as with this study and accompanying article). Scientists haven’t had time to do many lab studies on SARS-CoV-2 just yet
column3: so unfortunately this information isn’t widely available.

column1: For any research claiming that a treatment or vaccine works
column2: remember that the highest standard of evidence is a randomized controlled trial. In these experiments
column3: some participants receive a placebo intervention
column4: some get the tested intervention
column5: and neither clinicians nor participants know what they received. Researchers may not have time to do these kinds of studies—which
column6: again
column7: doesn’t mean that anything less is bad. It’s just a reminder that the science isn’t certain just yet.

column1: It’s also common for scientists to publish reviews or meta-analyses
column2: which are papers that gather and weigh the evidence of specific papers. Given that Covid-19 is so new
column3: many researchers are putting forth ideas that could be good places to look in the future. These papers are helpful
column4: but they can’t be taken as the absolute truth. Unfortunately
column5: one such paper hypothesizing that ibuprofen could worsen cases of Covid-19 led to a panic about the pain reliever
column6: despite the fact that there’s only anecdotal evidence. It could be true—but again
column7: scientists don’t know yet.

column1: See where the information is coming from…
Did you read your information on a news website? Or did it come from a social media post? If the latter
column2: were you asked to share it on? If so
column3: tell us—but also increase your skepticism.

column1: If you’re having trouble figuring out if your source is a trusted one
column2: remember that no trusted news outlets will be touting remedies or cures—those don’t exist for this virus (or most conditions
column3: frankly).

column1: Quality science writing outlines all of the information described above about a study
column2: and states which research institutions the scientists came from. Ideally
column3: there’s also an outside source weighing in on the new information being presented. And it should always note the study’s limitations
column4: or what it can’t tell researchers.

column1: …And who else supports it
If you’re reading a news story that no other outlet else is reporting on
column2: and the information doesn’t seem like anything else you’ve read—chances are you should be extra skeptical.

column1: And above all
column2: the top sources you should trust for research about Covid-19 are the national and international public health groups. As Quartz previously reported
column3: the World Health Organization
column4: the US Centers for Disease Control
column5: the National Health Service in the UK
column6: or the Public Health Agency of Canada are your best bets."

column1: Image copyright
Tony Hammock
Image caption
Zoe Newsam is a kayaking coach based in Beauly
Zoe came up with alternative ways of earning a little money such as offering personal training via video calling
column2: but she said: ""Every other trainer did the same thing
column3: so the market is suddenly flooded with fitness coaches.""

column1: She said the government self-employed assistance scheme would help ""a little"" but
column2: because her profits have been consistently low

column1: Zoe is going to work part-time as a temporary supermarket delivery driver to help make ends meet

column1: She said: ""I'm trying very hard not to think about the future. The scale of what lies ahead just feels too large.
I worry that the market for outdoor sports won't return for a while
column2: as people struggle with lack of money once the crisis is eventually over.

column1: I worry that we will be restricted in our travel for some time to come
column2: meaning that some of my work will be impossible to undertake.

column1: This crisis certainly brings home the fragility of our industry
column2: and the lack of security inherent in it. We spend many thousands of hours and pounds on training
column3: but rarely make much money from it.""

column1: 'My work diary emptied overnight'
Lochaber-based Matt Haydock's paddle sports business Rapid Development had a full work diary through to the middle of 2021 before the coronavirus outbreak.
Since the prime minister's first big announcement on 16 March
column2: which put in place the initial social distancing measures
column3: my entire work diary emptied literally overnight. All planned activities
column4: trips
column5: coaching sessions were cancelled outright
column6: he said.

column1: More stringent measures soon followed
column2: and Matt said: ""My Google Calendar emptied itself
column3: and I was looking at no possible income stream

column1: Coming to terms with this was pretty daunting to say the least

column1: Matt holds on to a hope the industry can bounce back

column5: I am deeply fearful for the outdoor industry when we exit this crisis.

column1: For most in the outdoors
column2: many have just come out the other side of a harsh winter with little work
column3: ready to make money to cover themselves as the main season commences.""

column1: 'Work has come to a crashing halt'
Climbing instructor and guide Alan has been working for himself under his business Climb When You're Ready and as a freelance for others for 11 years.
His work includes providing training and assessments at Glenmore Lodge
column2: the Scottish National Outdoor Training Centre in the Cairngorms.

column1: My first day's work cancelled was 16 March. All work for the immediate future went on hold overnight
column2: he said.

column1: I should have had 13 days of work since then and I've cancelled 44 more days up to the end of May.

Beyond that I've another 50 days beyond that that are all threatened. I'm also usually busy filling my diary up to six months ahead at this point but all new enquiries have disappeared and ongoing discussions on dates with existing clients are on hold indefinitely.
Work has come to a crashing halt and income has dried up overnight.""
Alan said one regular employer had honoured a payment as a cancellation fee for a handful of bookings and one larger overseas contract had a 25% cancellation fee built it.
He said those in the outdoor industry were trying to find alternative employment
column2: and also offer help to their communities.

column1: Outdoors professionals are all first aiders
column2: are often good at problem solving and quite resilient
column3: he said.

column1: I know some have taken jobs in supermarkets and others are volunteering with the NHS and other bodies. We aren't used to being inactive.""
Image copyright
Chris Townsend
Image caption
Writer and photographer Chris Townsend believes the impact on the outdoor industry will be felt for years to come
Outdoor writer and photographer Chris Townsend said he was ""very concerned"" for instructors and guides.
He said: ""No-one works in the outdoors field to make money - we do it because we love it - so people don't have reserves to fall back on.
It can take years to build a reputation and a business that just about provides a living.
Doing this again will be very difficult."""
