column1: 1551	The Sun - UK	1380607	Adam Sonin	The Queen’s stirring message felt like a rallying call to a nation at war- but then so it should
column2: as we are	"IF the Queen’s stirring message felt like a rallying call to a nation at war
column3: then so it should. We are.

column1: This invisible but deadly enemy will not be defeated by our brave Army
column2: Navy or RAF personnel
column3: though as always they are doing their bit.

column1: Give now to The Sun's NHS appeal BRITAIN’s four million NHS staff are on the frontline in the battle against coronavirus. But while they are helping save lives
column2: who is there to help them? The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £1MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need. We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid-19 Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it. The Sun is donating £50
column3: 000 and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds
column4: to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare
column5: please donate today here thesun.co.uk/whocareswinsappeal

column1: It is our frontline NHS heroes
column2: the thousands of volunteers supporting them and the tireless key workers striving to keep the country going who will pull us through.

column1: People like nurse Shirley Watts
column2: who revealed in an emotional video message how she and her colleagues are “on their knees” trying to do their best.

column1: And the rest of us? All we are asked to do is sit tight and resist the urge to sunbathe for a few weeks.
It’s hardly the greatest sacrifice in order to save lives
column2: is it?

column1: There will of course be a few who blatantly flout the restrictions
column2: putting us all at risk of more draconian measures.

column1: But the vast majority are ready to justify Her Majesty’s faith in our generation and help win this war.
SCIENTISTS believe the coronavirus crisis will peak in the next seven to ten days.
With 621 more deaths reported it looks likely we will still fall short of the 18
column2: 000 ventilators and millions of items of Personal Protection Equipment the NHS will need by then.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: doctors and nurses say they are having to hold their own breath just to protect themselves.

column1: The deaths of 23-year-old nurse John Alagos and midwife Lynsay Coventry from Covid-19 highlight the extraordinary sacrifices made by NHS workers
column2: for whom The Sun’s Who Cares Wins appeal was launched.

column1: John was the third nurse and ninth medic to fall victim.
His mother said he did not have the right protective equipment.
Now is not the time to play the blame game.
But our frontline heroes MUST have the protection they need and no effort should be spared to get it for them.
WHILE Premier League clubs squabble with mega-rich footballers over how their sky-high wages should be cut
column2: philanthropist

column1: Bill Gates knows the real value of money.
The Microsoft magnate
column2: who has devoted vast sums to the fight against malaria
column3: is investing billions in businesses seeking a coronavirus vaccine.

column1: He knows much of the money will be wasted on the ones that fail.
But he says waiting to invest in the one that will succeed will delay that success by months
column2: and his billions are a drop in the ocean compared with the trillions the disease is costing world economies."

1478	Stuff	941156	Stuff	Kiwi Willi Heinz on why Eddie Jones is his best rugby coach	"England head coach Eddie Jones announces an 'exciting' squad for the 2020 Six Nations. The 34-man squad features eight uncapped players.
England's Kiwi halfback Willi Heinz has backed the reappointment of Eddie Jones
column2: describing him as ""the best coach I've played under"".

column1: Heinz says Jones' attention to detail is second to none with the Australian signing a contract extension to coach England through to the next World Cup in France in 2023.

Whether Heinz gets there is doubtful. The former Crusaders and Canterbury No 9 is already 33 and admits his selection for the last World Cup in Japan where England finished runner-up to South Africa in an absorbing final came as a surprise.
All I can say on behalf of the squad about Eddie is that we love the environment he creates
column2: Heinz told The Rugby Paper.

column1: READ MORE:
* The greatest rugby team of all time
* Buck Shelford - rugby's hardest player
* NZ Rugby's revenue sharing play
* RFU: This could cost us $100m

He's certainly the best coach I've played under in terms of attention to detail and the support he provides. It's a challenging environment but with that comes all that support and he makes sure you're in the best possible place to execute on any given day.""
Heinz played 58 games for the Crusaders from 2010-15 under the guidance of Todd Blackadder but also got to experience the magic of Scott Robertson with Canterbury.

Heinz felt Jones had proved his worth by the way he had righted the rocky England outfit in the leadup to the last World Cup and continued that with a strong Six Nations campaign this year that was eventually stalled by the coronavirus pandemic.

I know England had a run of losses in 2018 but apart from that he's done amazing things with this team. To get to a World Cup final was impressive and although we lost that and then came back and dropped another game against France
column2: since then our consistency has been good and that's down to the environment he creates
column3: Heinz told The Rugby Paper.

column1: The players have a ton of respect for him and one of the things I've really noticed since being involved are the one-on-one relationship he seems to have with guys in the squad
The relationships are there
column2: you can see it in the conversations he has
column3: and with 30-40 players to deal with he puts so much time into it.""

column1: Heinz said he had benefited from that first-hand with Jones easing any doubts Heinz had about being called into test rugby at such a late age.
Personally
column2: that's helped me massively because coming into the set-up relatively late in your career
column3: you do have question marks over whether you should be there or whether you're up to it. But he's been so good at simplifying the game and getting the best out of me
column4: Heinz said.

column1: I love what he does for the No 9s and 10s in having loads of conversations between us about trends in the game
column2: where the game's heading and what we can do to keep learning and influencing things ourselves. It's been an awesome experience under Eddie.""

column1: Heinz is contracted to Gloucester in the English Premiership and has played 13 tests for England
column2: including the World Cup semifinal demolition of the All Blacks. He was injured in that match
column3: ruling him out of the final."

column1: 18	Hacker News	2431996	Dave Lieber	If you imagine that a local business making surgical face masks is working 24/7
column2: guess again	"When the history of the coronavirus epoch is written
column3: The Watchdog hopes historians don’t neglect to mention Prestige Ameritech and its owner
column4: Mike Bowen. The North Richland Hills company is America’s No. 1 maker of hospital surgical masks.

column1: During this crisis
column2: you’d think the company would be pushing forward on all cylinders
column3: working 24/7 to manufacture the one commodity that Americans and the rest of the world want so badly.

column1: You’d be wrong.
The company is only operating weekday shifts. You drive by nights and weekends and the employee parking lot is empty.
“People are curious why there aren’t any cars in the parking lot
column2: ” North Richland Hills Mayor Oscar Trevino told me.

column1: And why is that
column2: Mr. Mayor?

column1: “The system got him
column2: the mayor said about Bowen
column3: who is executive vice president of the company. “And he’s unhappy about it.”

column1: The story of Bowen’s unhappiness is a cautionary tale about what can happen if Americans searching for cheaper prices send entire industries offshore to countries like Mexico and China.

Everything Bowen has warned about has come true. He warned that allowing another country to serve as our main supplier of personal protection equipment has the potential to become a national security nightmare.
Bowen declined to talk to The Watchdog for this story. He’s busy.
“There is 200 times more demand than there is supply
column2: ” he told former presidential adviser Steve Bannon on Bannon’s podcast. “My phone is ringing every two minutes. Every one minute I am getting an email.”

column1: An examination of his warnings going back more than a dozen years tells the story.
The common theme is that during an outbreak like this
column2: everybody wants to be his customer. But as soon as an outbreak subsides
column3: his customers dump him and run back to China. The reason? His masks may cost a dime each
column4: but a made-in-China mask might go for two cents.

column1: “Last time he geared up and went three shifts a day working his tail off
column2: ” the mayor recalled. “As soon as the issue died
column3: he didn’t have any sales. He had to pay unemployment for all these people
column4: and he had to gear down.”

column1: As Bowen explained to Bannon
column2: “I’ve been preaching this American-made story since 2007. Nobody listened. The whole mass market was only interested in price. I’ve been everywhere trying to get people to listen. I’ve talked to congressmen. I’ve talked to generals. I’ve written the president. I wrote President Obama five or six letters
column3: and he sent me a presidential proclamation suitable for framing.”

column1: Bowen wants a guaranteed contract
column2: not a proclamation. It’s tough to win a bid to supply U.S. hospitals through their group purchase agreements that seek the cheapest price when your competitor pays low wages
column3: ignores environmental concerns and is subsidized by a Communist government.

column1: Last month
column2: he got another proclamation but no contract to go with it. U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio
column3: R-Florida
column4: named Prestige Ameritech the “Senate Small Business of the Week.” The citation notes that the company “has ramped up their daily production to 600
column5: 000 masks.”

column1: The company could do so much more.
The best intentions
The company is in a building originally used by Kimberly-Clark to make medical masks. But that company moved its operations to Mexico. When Prestige Ameritech opened in 2005
column2: it was touted as a great day for the made-in-America movement.
the company had grown strong enough to meet the demand caused by the H1N1 swine flu outbreak. Hospitals promised to stick with him afterward
column3: but they broke their promise. The allure of cheaper Chinese masks was too great for hospital purchasing groups to ignore.

column2: the company celebrated a grand “reopening” when it renamed its factory the Global Pandemic Preparedness and Response Center. The event was attended by then-Gov. Rick Perry
column3: who said
column4: “It’s good news for America as America becomes competitive back in this arena again.”

column1: VIDEO
But the news wasn’t so good. The next year
column2: Bowen and company president Dan Reese had to lay off 150 workers. Bowen told Wired magazine
column3: “150 people that saved a lot of hospitals from closing their doors were rewarded by losing their jobs. And that’s not going to happen again.”

column1: The company nearly went bankrupt. In 2012 the company took out a million-dollar loan.
Mayor Trevino recalls escorting Bowen around the Texas Capitol in Austin as Bowen made his case with state lawmakers for more government support.
“He was begging them to understand that we shouldn’t have all our masks made in China. He wanted a federal government contract that would keep him in steady business
column2: ” the mayor said
column3: adding that Bowen wanted to help build a future stockpile for a pandemic that Bowen predicted would happen.

column1: Trevino recalls Bowen saying
column2: “If y’all don’t care about me in good times when everybody’s OK
column3: how am I going to be there when you need me?”

column1: The city wrote letters on his behalf to federal lawmakers
column2: Trevino said.

column1: “Everything he was saying fell on deaf ears
column2: ” the mayor said.

column1: Or as Bowen asked in a 2017 Dallas Morning News interview
column2: “If the government doesn’t even buy American
column3: who will?”

column1: In that same interview
column2: Bowen showed stacks of dismantled office cubicles.

column1: Stacks of unused cubicles sat in the warehouse at the Prestige Ameritech manufacturing plant in North Richland Hills in 2017.(Rose Baca / Staff Photographer)“Every one of those represents somebody who used to have a job
column2: ” he said
column3: adding that he nicknamed an empty
column4: unlit corridor in his factory the “hall of death.”

column1: He’s tired of being “the backup guy
column2: ” he said. “Create American jobs. Buy American. … It’s hot air.”

column1: An empty darkened hallway at the Texas factory that serves as America's top domestic maker of medical face masks is nicknamed ""the Hall of Death"" — in memory of workers who were laid off when business was lost to China.(Rose Baca / Staff Photographer)Ramping up
That’s why if you drive by America’s No. 1 mask maker on a night or weekend
column2: the parking lot is ghostly. But the lot isn’t completely empty. There’s a North Richland Hills police car parked outside near a police observation tower. The mayor said the business has received threats.

column1: A mobile police tower and vehicle are positioned near the main entrance of Prestige Ameritech in North Richland Hills.(Tom Fox / Staff Photographer)Bowen told CBSDFW.com that he could only make about 1 million masks a day if he ran his machines 24/7. He said that would have little impact on global demand.
He told Bannon he is ramping up
column2: but it takes weeks to build new machines and train employees. His company’s street sign announces it is hiring.

column1: The nation's top domestic medical mask maker in Texas is hiring.(Tom Fox / Staff Photographer)The company is not selling to the general public or to non-American buyers. Now
column2: it’s only selling to U.S. hospitals. But Bowen asks hospitals to sign contracts. Who can blame him?

column1: Or as the mayor puts it
column2: “He’ll gear back up
column3: and he’ll produce
column4: and they’ll probably do it to him again.”

column1: In this 2017 photo
column2: a worker makes medical masks at a Texas plant.(Rose Baca / Staff Photographer)Become a citizen of Watchdog Nation. Join Dave Lieber and learn to be a super-consumer.

column1: 8639	Yahoo7 News Australia	2271495	By Dmitry Zaks	Italy's 'very long' lockdown to only end gradually	"Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte's government prepared Italians for a ""very long"" lockdown Sunday that would only be lifted gradually despite its economic hardship and traumatic impact on daily lives.

The message from ministers and health officials came as Italy's world-topping toll rose by 756 -- well bellow Friday's record of 969 -- and the rate of coronavirus infections slowed to under six percent for the first time.

Yet the government appeared more focused on the nearing April 3 deadline to lift a national lockdown that had never been tried by a Western democracy -- and has since been replicated across Europe and the United States.
The measures expiring on April 3 will inevitably be extended
column2: Regional Affairs Minister Francesco Boccia told Italy's Sky TG24 television.

column1: I think that
column2: at the moment
column3: talking about re-opening is inappropriate and irresponsible.

column1: We all want to go back to normal. But we will have to do it by turning on one switch at a time.""
Italy is effectively sacrificing almost all forms of business activity to fight the pandemic that first emerged in China last year.
Deputy Finance Minister Laura Castelli said that the government's initial 25 billion euro ($28 billion) rescue package for affected families and companies might have to be quadrupled in size.
In my opinion
column2: at least 100 billion (euros) will be needed
column3: Castelli told the La Stampa daily.

column1: - 'Even stricter' -
Italy's death toll now stands at 10
column2: 779 and the number of officially registered infections is just under 100

column1: But officials brushed aside various data suggesting that both rates were slowing and that Italy might have already lived through the worst.
We are in the midst of a pandemic
column2: Health Minster Roberto Speranza told reporters.

column1: It would be a mistake to let our guard down.""
Government medical adviser Luca Richeldi warned that data pointing to a slowdown ""are a reason for us to be even stricter.
We are in a very long battle
column2: said Richeldi. ""Through our behaviour
column3: we save lives.""

column1: Ministers are expected to decide on the length of an extension in the coming days.
Conte has the right to keep the lockdown -- in full or in part -- until the existing state of medical emergency expires on July 31.
But there is nothing preventing his government from declaring a new one should restrictions be needed into the second half of the year.
Conte has indicated that he would like to see most measures lifted by June.
- Discontent -
Yet the strains on Italian society imposed by measures that might have seemed unimaginable just weeks ago are gradually starting to show.
The starkest example came when armed police began guarding entrances to supermarkets in Sicily after reports of looting by people who could no longer afford food.
Newspaper stories about growing discontent in one of Italy's least-developed regions appeared to be at least partially behind Conte's decision to make another TV appeal to the nation on Saturday.
Conte used it to announce a food voucher programme that will cost the government another 400 million euros ($445 million).
We know that many suffer but the state is there
column2: Conte said.

column1: But this is only a stop-gap measure designed to help families cover grocery costs of between 25 and 50 euros on a one-time basis.
Projections from several global banks and think-tanks in the past week point to Italy's economic output shrinking by seven percent this year.
Those numbers are based on the assumption that the lockdown will not be extend far beyond April.
Catholics had to celebrate Mass from home
column2: as part of the lockdown measures

column1: 7109	Google News Italia (Italian)	980756	Bbc News	Calderwood resigns over lockdown trips	"Image copyright
WPA/Getty
Scotland's chief medical officer has resigned after making two visits to her second home during the coronavirus lockdown.
Dr Catherine Calderwood had apologised for her actions
column2: and initially said she planned to continue in the role.

column1: She was backed by First Minister Nicola Sturgeon
column2: who said Dr Calderwood had made a mistake but should stay in her job.

column1: But Dr Calderwood released a statement later on Sunday saying she had quit.
She said she had done so after speaking again to the first minister
column2: and had agreed that the ""justifiable focus"" on her actions risked distracting from the pandemic response.

column1: Dr Calderwood had earlier been given a police warning for breaking the lockdown rules after the Scottish Sun published photographs taken on Saturday of her and her family visiting Earlsferry in Fife - more than an hour's drive from her main family home in Edinburgh.
The chief medical officer had fronted TV and radio adverts urging the public to stay at home to save lives and protect the NHS
column2: and took part in daily televised media briefings alongside Ms Sturgeon.

column1: Image copyright
Getty Images
Image caption
First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and Dr Catherine Calderwood have held regular briefings
Dr Calderwood issued an apology on Sunday morning and said she did not want her ""mistake"" to distract from the guidance on social distancing.
She later admitted during a press briefing that she had also made another visit to the property in Fife last weekend with her husband
column2: but insisted she would be remaining in her post.

column1: Ms Sturgeon said repeatedly during the briefing that she wanted Dr Calderwood to remain in her role as her advice and expertise were ""invaluable"" during the coronavirus crisis.
However
column2: the first minister announced later on Sunday that Dr Calderwood would not be be attending any more briefings ""for the foreseeable future"" - although she would continue to offer the Scottish government scientific and medical advice.

column1: 'Further conversation'
Dr Calderwood then released another statement at about 22:00
column2: in which she said she was ""deeply sorry for my actions and the mistakes I have made"" and confirmed she was standing down as the country's chief medical officer.

column1: She added: ""The first minister and I have had a further conversation this evening and we have agreed that the justifiable focus on my behaviour risks becoming a distraction from the hugely important job that government and the medical profession has to do in getting the country through this coronavirus pandemic.
Having worked so hard on the government's response
column2: that is the last thing I want.""

column1: She also said she would work to ensure a smooth transition to her successor.
Image copyright
Scottish government
Image caption
Videos of the chief medical officer urging people to stay at home formed part of the campaign
Ms Sturgeon said it was ""clear"" that Dr Calderwood's mistake ""risks distracting from and undermining confidence in the government's public health message at this crucial time.
That is not a risk either of us is willing to take.""
The first minister added that the ""very serious mistake"" made by Dr Calderwood should not detract from her ""highly valuable contribution to the medical profession and to health in Scotland"".
Dr Calderwood was appointed as Scotland's chief medical officer in March 2015.
A former national director for maternity and women's health at NHS England
column2: she was a leading medical expert in the inquiry into maternity care at Morecambe Bay.

column1: Her deputy is Dr Gregor Smith
column2: a GP and former medical director for primary care in NHS Lanarkshire.

column1: Scottish Conservative leader Jackson Carlaw described Dr Calderwood's decision to stand down as ""embarrassing and inevitable"".
Scottish Labour's health spokeswoman Monica Lennon said Ms Sturgeon should have ""nipped this in the bud"" earlier."

column1: 202	The New York Times	2431977	Jennifer Senior	Opinion | This Is What Happens When a Narcissist Runs a Crisis	"Since the early days of the Trump administration
column2: an impassioned group of mental health professionals have warned the public about the president’s cramped and disordered mind
column3: a darkened attic of fluttering bats. Their assessments have been controversial. The American Psychiatric Association’s code of ethics expressly forbids its members from diagnosing a public figure from afar.

column1: Enough is enough. As I’ve argued before
column2: an in-person analysis of Donald J. Trump would not reveal any hidden depths — his internal sonar could barely fathom the bottom of a sink — and these are exceptional
column3: urgent times. Back in October
column4: George T. Conway III
column5: the conservative lawyer and wife of Kellyanne
column6: wrote a long
column7: devastating essay for The Atlantic
column8: noting that Trump has all the hallmarks of narcissistic personality disorder. That disorder was dangerous enough during times of prosperity
column9: jeopardizing the moral and institutional foundations of our country.

column1: But now we’re in the midst of a global pandemic. The president’s pathology is endangering not just institutions
column2: but lives.

column1: Let’s start with the basics. First: Narcissistic personalities like Trump harbor skyscraping delusions about their own capabilities. They exaggerate their accomplishments
column2: focus obsessively on projecting power
column3: and wish desperately to win.

column1: What that means
column2: during this pandemic: Trump says we’ve got plenty of tests available
column3: when we don’t. He declares that Google is building a comprehensive drive-thru testing website
column4: when it isn’t. He sends a Navy hospital ship to New York and it proves little more than an excuse for a campaign commercial
column5: arriving and sitting almost empty in the Hudson. A New York hospital executive calls it a joke.

column1: Second: The grandiosity of narcissist personalities belies an extreme fragility
column2: their egos as delicate as foam. They live in terror of being upstaged. They’re too thin skinned to be told they’re wrong.

column1: What that means
column2: during this pandemic: Narcissistic leaders never have
column3: as Trump likes to say
column4: the best people. They have galleries of sycophants. With the exceptions of Drs. Anthony Fauci and Deborah Birx
column5: Trump has surrounded himself with a Z-team of dangerously inexperienced toadies and flunkies — the bargain-bin rejects from Filene’s Basement — at a time when we require the brightest and most imaginative minds in the country.

column1: Faced with a historic public health crisis
column2: Trump could have assembled a first-rate company of disaster preparedness experts. Instead he gave the job to his son-in-law
column3: a man-child of breathtaking vapidity. Faced with a historic economic crisis
column4: Trump could have assembled a team of Nobel-prize winning economists or previous treasury secretaries. Instead he talks to Larry Kudlow
column5: a former CNBC host.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Fauci and Birx measure every word they say like old-time apothecaries
column3: hoping not to humiliate the narcissist — never humiliate a narcissist — while discreetly correcting his false hopes and falsehoods. They are desperately attempting to create a safe space for our president
column4: when the president should be creating a safer nation for all of us.

column1: Third: Narcissistic personalities love nothing more than engineering conflict and sowing division. It destabilizes everyone
column2: keeps them in control.

column1: What that means
column2: during this pandemic: Trump is pitting state against state for precious resources
column3: rather than coordinating a national response. (“It’s like being on eBay
column4: ” complained Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York last week.) His White House is a petty palace of competing power centers. He picks fights with Democratic officials and members of the press
column5: when all the public craves is comfort.

column1: Narcissistic personalities don’t do comfort. They cannot fathom the needs of other hearts.
Fourth: Narcissistic personalities are vindictive. On a clear day
column2: you can see their grudges forever.

column1: What that means
column2: during this pandemic: Trump is playing favorites with governors who praise him and punishing those who fail to give him the respect he believes he deserves. “If they don’t treat you right
column3: don’t call
column4: ” he told Vice President Mike Pence.

column1: His grudge match with New York is now especially lethal. When asked on Friday whether New York will have enough ventilators
column2: Trump bluntly answered “No
column3: ” and then blamed the state.

column1: And most relevant
column2: as far as history is concerned: Narcissistic personalities are weak.

column1: What that means
column2: during this pandemic: Trump is genuinely afraid to lead. He can’t bring himself to make robust use of the Defense Production Act
column3: because the buck would stop with him. (To this day
column4: he insists states should be acquiring their own ventilators.) When asked about delays in testing
column5: he said
column6: “I don’t take responsibility at all.” During Friday’s news conference
column7: he added the tests “we inherited were “broken
column8: were obsolete
column9: ” when this form of coronavirus didn’t even exist under his predecessor.

column1: This sounds an awful lot like one of the three sentences that Homer Simpson swears will get you through life: “It was like that when I got here.”
Most people
column2: even the most hotheaded and difficult ones
column3: have enough space in their souls to set aside their anger in times of crisis. Think of Rudolph Giuliani during Sept. 11. Think of Andrew Cuomo now.

column1: But every aspect of Trump’s crisis management has been annexed by his psychopathology. As Americans die
column2: he boasts about his television ratings. As Americans die
column3: he crows that he’s No. 1 on Facebook
column4: which isn’t close to true.

column1: But it is true that all eyes are on him. He’s got a captive audience
column2: an attention-addict’s dream come to life. It’s just that he
column3: like all narcissistic personalities
column4: has no clue how disgracefully — how shamefully
column5: how deplorably — he’ll be enshrined in memory."

According to the federal agency for indigenous affairs
column2: Funai
column3: there are 107 known indigenous groups in Brazil's Amazon that have no contact with the outside world.

column1: However
column2: illegal loggers
column3: hunters and evangelical missionaries are operating in their territories. And indigenous organisations and NGOs say there has been a sharp increase in incursions in recent years.

column1: Funai has also had its budget slashed by consecutive administrations
column2: making it harder for the agency to protect remote communities.

column1: There are now fears that the battle against the coronavirus will further reduce its resources to protect the forest and those living in it.
While most indigenous groups agree they should avoid visiting cities to reduce the risk of infection
column2: many leaders say people could go hungry if they have no access to markets.

column1: In São Gabriel da Cachoeira
column2: an Amazonian municipality that borders Colombia and Venezuela
column3: thousands of members of local groups travel on boats to the city each month to receive pensions and access government cash-transfer programmes.

column1: The expansion of such programmes in recent decades means some communities have stopped hunting for and growing their own food
column2: and now rely on them to survive.

column1: Marivelton Baré
column2: president of the Federation of Indigenous Organizations of Rio Negro (Foirn)
column3: says many local communities are ""in a panic"".

column1: We'll need to take the food to the villages so that they don't expose themselves during this critical moment
column2: he says.

column1: There are no ventilators in São Gabriel da Cachoeira's hospital
column2: so a seriously ill patient would need to be sent to the capital of Amazonas
column3: Manaus - a 1
column4: 000km-long (620-mile) boat journey away.

column1: Speaking on condition of anonymity
column2: a nurse working for the Special Secretariat for Indigenous Health (Sesai) says its staff have no testing kits to detect Covid-19
column3: and that there are not enough protective masks and other equipment to deal with cases in indigenous villages.

column1: The Special Secretariat for Indigenous Health is monitoring the spread of Covid-19
More
Sesai itself told the BBC it had provided ""a series of technical documents
column2: so that indigenous peoples
column3: managers and employees could be guided to adopt measures to prevent coronavirus infection"".

column1: The agency added that all its health teams had received training on how to treat patients.
But it did not comment on the fears of food shortages in villages.
Funai
column2: the federal agency for indigenous affairs
column3: did not say how it would tackle hunger and land invasions during the pandemic.

column1: Mr Baré says the government has not offered any help and that people will start to ignore the advice to stay in their villages if their food stocks run out.
If the choice is either being infected or going hungry
column2: most will choose the first
column3: he warns. ""Then the consequences will be dire."""
